Run at large means to be free of restraint while outside the boundaries of the real property of the owner. 
Stray animal means any animal not under restraint. 
Vicious animal means any animal that exhibits fierce or vicious behavior or that has attacked a person or animal with such severity as to cause physical injury or property damage, however, the fact that the animal has attempted to bite a person when that person has provoked or teased it shall not constitute the animal being a vicious animal. 
Wild animal means any nonhuman primate, racoon, skunk, fox, wolf, coyote, leopard, panther, tiger, lion, lynx, bobcat, or other warm-blooded animal, or any poisonous or dangerous snake which can be found in the wild state, or any animal incapable of being completely domesticated. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2001, § 2)  
Sec. 6-2. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this chapter is to protect the public health, safety and general welfare of the community and the inhabitants of the City by adopting the established uniform rules and regulations to set local standards for the enforcement control that are compatible with and equal to or more stringent than the rules and regulations established and adopted by the State Board of Health for the local enforcement control of dogs and cats and all other animals within the City and its extraterritorial jurisdiction (ETJ). 
(Ord. of 11-14-2001, § 1)  
Secs. 6-3—6-22. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - ANIMAL CONTROL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Extent of extraterritorial jurisdiction is within one mile of the boundaries of a municipality with a population of 5,000 to 24,999 inhabitants, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 42.021(a)(2). 
 
Sec. 6-23. - Vaccination. 
(a)  No person shall own, keep, harbor, or have control over any dog or cat in the City limits over the age of four months, unless said animal shall have been vaccinated with an antirabies vaccine. 
(b)  All dogs and cats shall be vaccinated against rabies annually in accordance with the State law. 
(c)  The provisions of this section shall in no way be construed to limit the Director of Animal Control from establishing clinics for the purpose of vaccinating dogs and cats. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2001, § 3)  
Sec. 6-24. - Enforcement. 
(a)  For the purpose of discharging the duties imposed by this chapter and enforcing its provisions, the Animal Control Officer, any police officer designated by the City Council, and State Health Department Officer is empowered to enter upon any premises upon which a dog, cat or animal is kept or harbored, and to demand and secure the owner's exhibition of such animal. 
(b)  Those officials named herein are further empowered to enter into the premises where any animal is reportedly kept in a cruel or inhumane manner to examine such animal and to take possession thereof when it reasonably appears that such animal requires humane treatment. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of these officials to enforce the animal cruelty laws of the State. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2001, § 4)  
Sec. 6-25. - Interference with enforcement. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere in any manner with the Animal Control Officer while he is discharging his duties or has in his custody any animal. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to remove from the animal control facility any animal unless the Animal Control Officer or other person in charge of the facility has authorized the release of said animal. 
(c)  It is unlawful for any person to do any damage or destroy any portion of the animal control facility. 
(d)  Any person violating any portion of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished upon conviction by assessment of a fine according to the schedule of fines in Chapter 28, Municipal Fees, Rates, and Deposits. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2001, § 5)  
Sec. 6-26. - Citations. 
(a)  The Animal Control Officer, the Police Department and Health Department are hereby authorized to issue citations for violations of this chapter. 
(b)  Persons in violation of this chapter shall have a period of not less than ten days nor more than 30 days to comply with citations at the discretion of the Animal Control Officer. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2001, § 6)  
Sec. 6-27. - Animal Control Officer identification. 
It shall be required by this article that because the Animal Control Officer's job has a high level of public visibility and public contact and because he is an officer of the City and the State, the Officer be issued a vehicle with visible identification. It shall be required that the Officer wear neat, clean street clothes, or a uniform if he prefers, and he shall be required to wear an ID badge while performing his duties. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2001, § 7)  
Sec. 6-28. - Number of animals permitted. 
(a)  It shall hereafter be unlawful for any person to own, keep or harbor more than three dogs and/or cats on his premises, within the corporate limits of the City and its ETJ. 
(b)  This provision shall not apply to proprietors of animal hospitals or veterinarians, where and when such animals are kept on premises used by such business. 
(c)  This provision shall also apply to owners of animals who are animal breeders and/or kennel operators. Such businesses are required to be registered with the Animal Control Department in accordance with this article. 
(d)  Animal breeders and/or kennel operators keeping on the premises more than three dogs or cats shall be prima facie evidence of violation of this section, with the following exception: the limit on the number of dogs and cats permitted shall not include pups and kittens of a litter until they are four to six months old first, and this shall be at the discretion of the Animal Control Officer. After the pups and kittens of a litter are four to six months old the owner or keeper shall have a period of not less than 15 days nor more than 30 days to reduce the number to the number required by this article through legal channels. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2001, § 8)  
Sec. 6-29. - Confinement of animals. 
(a)  From and after the passage of the ordinance from which this article is derived any person owning animals, whether vaccinated or unvaccinated, shall confine such animal within an adequate fence or enclosure, or within a house, garage or other building on his own premises so the animal will be in compliance with this article. 
(b)  Any such animal not confined within the animal owner's real property or within the boundaries of the owner's real property will be considered to be running at large and in violation of this article and shall be impounded by the Animal Control Department. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2001, § 9)  
Sec. 6-30. - Prohibited animals. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to keep within the corporate limits of the City and its ETJ any of the dogs substantially conforming to the standards of the American Kennel Club for American Staffordshire Terrier or Staffordshire Bull Terrier or the United Kennel Club for American Pit Bull Terrier. These dogs may be permitted if the owner registers the animal with the Animal Control Department and local veterinarian and the owner will be required by this section to meet all the requirements of dangerous animal owners, as provided herein by this article. 
(b)  Other prohibited animals are: 
(1)  Any ape or other nonhuman primates; 
(2)  Any member of the genus canis, including, wolf, hybird wolf, coyote, jackal, or fox, and similar species except canis familiaris; 
(3)  Any member of the genus fells, including, leopard, lion, tiger, lynx, bobcat, cheetah, acelot margay, jaguarundi and any similar species except felis domesticus; 
(4)  A skunk, opossum, raccoon, armadillo and squirrel. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2001, § 10)  
Sec. 6-31. - Nuisance animals. 
Owners of nuisance animals shall be subject to fines. Nuisance animals are any animals which infringe upon the rights of another animal or person or: 
(1)  Molest passersby or passing vehicles; 
(2)  Attack other animals; 
(3)  Trespass on school grounds; or 
(4)  Damage private or public property by the following acts or omissions of an animal owner: 
a.  Dig in lawns and gardens; 
b.  Polluting, with animal waste, public sidewalks, public rights-of-way, and public and private property; 
c.  Injure or kill pets, livestock, birds or other wild animals; or 
d.  Barks, whines or howls in an excessive, continuous or untimely fashion. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2001, § 11)  
Sec. 6-32. - Animals creating public nuisance. 
It shall be unlawful for any person within the corporate limits of the City and its ETJ to allow an animal to create a public nuisance within the City and its ETJ by the following acts or omissions of an animal owner: 
(1)  The keeping of an animal in such a manner whereby the animal is free of restraint to roam or run at large and at will, while outside the boundaries of the real property of the owner. 
(2)  The keeping of an animal which barks, whines, or howls in such excessive duration, so as to annoy, distress or disturb the quiet comfort or repose of persons of normal nervous sensibilities within the vicinity of hearing thereof. 
(3)  The refusal or failure of an animal owner or keeper to prevent his animal from biting or injuring without provocation, any animal or person. 
(4)  The keeping of an animal which has a propensity to damage or destroy public property or private property or a person other than his owner's private property. 
(5)  The keeping of more than a total of three dogs or cats in any lot or premises within the City. 
(6)  The refusal or failure of an animal owner or keeper to take corrective action which allows the accumulation of animal waste on any premises in a quantity sufficient to create an odor offensive to a person of normal sensibilities standing on any adjacent property not owned or controlled by the subject animal's owner. 
(7)  The refusal or failure of an animal owner to take corrective action which allows any quantity of animal waste to create a condition conducive to the breeding of flies or other pests. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2001, § 12)  
Sec. 6-33. - Animals running at large. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for an animal owner or keeper to allow his animal to run at large and at will, free of restraint while outside the boundaries of the real property of the owner. 
(b)  Any animal found running at large will be impounded by the Animal Control Department whether the dog is wearing tags or is untagged. 
(c)  The Animal Control Officer or other law enforcement officers shall have the power to impound or have impounded an unrestrained animal for the purpose of abating the following nuisance circumstances: 
(1)  When an unrestrained animal is on public property, in all cases; 
(2)  When an unrestrained animal is on private property, if the consent of the resident or property owner is obtained; 
(3)  When an unrestrained animal is on private property, in all cases except the rear yard of residences, if the Officer reasonably believes that the animal will run at large if not impounded; 
(d)  Owners and keepers of animals running at large will be cited and fined; 
(e)  Owners and keepers of animals running at large shall incur the cost of impoundment. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2001, § 13)  
Secs. 6-34—6-54. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - IMPOUNDMENT 
 
Sec. 6-55. - Impounding nuisance animals. 
The Animal Control Officer or other law enforcement officers shall have the power to impound animals which create an animal nuisance, per se, for the purpose of abating the nuisance as follows: 
(1)  When the animal creating the nuisance is on public property, in all cases; 
(2)  When the animal creating the nuisance is on private property if the consent of the resident or property owner is obtained; 
(3)  When the Officer reasonably believes there is immediate and imminent danger or peril to the public if the animal in question is not impounded; 
(4)  If directed and authorized by appropriate courts of law. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2001, § 14)  
Sec. 6-56. - Notifying owner of impounded animal. 
If the known owner of an impounded animal can be identified, the Animal Control Officer shall immediately, upon impoundment, notify the owner at the address where the owner resides or by mail. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2001, § 15)  
Sec. 6-57. - Maximum impoundment time; release or euthanasia authorized. 
(a)  Impounded dogs and cats, owned or unowned, shall be kept for not less than 72 hours or three working days. 
(b)  In the case of impounded, tagged, identified animals, where the owner can be notified by certified mail, with return receipt requested, the owner after having received verified notification of impoundment will have a period of 72 hours or three working days to get the animal. 
(c)  If after reasonable effort to locate the owner of an animal, which has the owner's identification, has failed, or if the owner of such animal fails or refuses to claim and repossess such animal, the Animal Control Officer may deliver custody and possession of such animal to a suitable person for adoption, or after ten days of impoundment the animal may be euthanized; this will be at the discretion of the Animal Control Officer. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2001, § 16)  
Sec. 6-58. - Return of captured animal to owner. 
(a)  In addition to the issuance of a citation, the Animal Control Officer may return an animal found at large to the known owner in lieu of impounding the animal. 
(b)  The owner may redeem the impounded animal during normal business hours by paying the impoundment fee, boarding fees and the prerelease rabies vaccination fee, if required by law for the subject species and proof of valid vaccination cannot be produced. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2001, § 17)  
Sec. 6-59. - Unclaimed animals. 
Any animal not reclaimed by its owner within the period of 72 hours or three working days shall become the property of the City. The City may offer said animal for adoption, sale, or humanely euthanize the animal at the discretion of the City veterinarian. The selection of an animal for adoption during the reclamation period or the following adoption period shall not confer any ownership right or right of possession to the animal. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2001, § 18)  
Sec. 6-60. - Adopting impounded animals; liability of claimant. 
(a)  Any citizen claiming or adopting any animal under the provisions of this section shall be liable only for the payment of fees for vaccination and spay or neuter surgery, if necessary. 
(b)  All animals adopted from the animal control facility shall be spayed or neutered within 30 days: 
(1)  Unless the procedure has already been accomplished; or 
(2)  The animal is less than six months of age. 
(c)  Persons adopting an animal from the animal control facility shall put up a spay/neuter deposit which will be collected and deposited with the City for each animal adopted that has not yet been spayed or neutered. This deposit will be returned by the City upon application and presentment of a valid spay/neuter certificate. The Animal Control Department is authorized to collect a fee for each animal spayed or neutered. 
(d)  Any animal which becomes the property of the Animal Control Department may not be sold or given to persons or medical laboratories for experimental purposes. 
(e)  The Animal Control Department or the City are not liable nor do they guarantee the health of any animal adopted from the facility. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2001, § 19)  
Secs. 6-61—6-82. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - OFFENSES AGAINST ANIMALS 
 
Sec. 6-83. - Abandoning animals. 
It is unlawful for any person to abandon an animal anywhere within the City limits or its ETJ. Any person violating this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished upon conviction by assessment of a fine at the discretion of the Court. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2001, § 20)  
Sec. 6-84. - Killing or wounding animals and fowl. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to wound or kill any animal, bird or fowl of any description within the City limits, its ETJ or any public parks of the City, and this will be punishable by a fine. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2001, § 21)  
Sec. 6-85. - Reports of motor vehicles striking domestic animals. 
Any person who, as the operator of a motor vehicle, strikes a domestic animal shall at once report the accident to the Animal Control Officer or the Police Department. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2001, § 23)  
Sec. 6-86. - Safety of animals in motor vehicles; seizure of cruelly treated animals. 
(a)  Animals in moving vehicles. No person shall transport or carry on any public roadway or street any animal in a motor vehicle unless the animal is safely enclosed within the vehicle; and if traveling in an unenclosed vehicle including, but not limited to, convertibles, pickup trucks, jeeps, and flatbed trucks, the animals shall be confined by a vented container or cage, or by chain, rope or other device cross-tied to prevent the animal from falling or jumping from the motor vehicle or from strangling on a single leash. 
(b)  Animals in parked vehicles; removal if endangered. No person shall leave any animal in any standing or parked vehicle in such a way as to endanger the animal's health or safety. Any Animal Control Officer or police officer is authorized to use reasonable force, including the breaking of a side window, to remove an animal from a vehicle whenever it appears the animal's health or safety is, or soon will be, endangered and said neglected or endangered animal shall be impounded. 
(c)  Seizure powers utilized liberally in cruelty cases. The Animal Control Officer shall liberally utilize the authority granted by section 821.022 of the Texas Health and Safety Code (V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 821.022) to seize and impound any animal if the investigating Animal Control Officer has reason to believe that an animal has been or is being cruelly treated, pending a hearing before any Justice of the Peace of the County or any Municipal Court Judge on the issues of cruelty and disposition of the animal. Seizure of the subject animal prior to receiving a warrant is hereby authorized if such a delay endangers the life of the animal, or if it would unreasonably prolong the suffering of the animal needing immediate attention. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2001, § 24)  
Secs. 6-87—6-108. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - DANGEROUS/VICIOUS ANIMALS 
 
Sec. 6-109. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Dangerous/vicious animal means any animal who meets any or all of the following criteria: 
(1)  An animal which by species or nature is dangerous or vicious to man. 
(2)  Any animal that has killed a domestic animal or fowl without provocation while off the owner's property. 
(3)  Any animal that, when unprovoked, inflicts severe, injury or death to a person or bites a person on public or private property. 
(4)  Any animal which, when unprovoked, chases or approaches a person upon the street, sidewalks, or any public or private property in lawful possession of a person other than the animal owner, in a menacing fashion or apparent attitude of attack such that the person reasonably believes that the animal will cause physical injury to that person. 
(5)  Any animal with a known propensity, tendency or disposition to attack unprovoked, to cause injury, or threaten the safety of persons or domestic animals. 
(6)  Any animal that has bitten two or more people or one person on two or more occasions. 
(7)  Any animal that has killed a person or another pet or livestock animal. 
(8)  Any animal that has attacked a human being and the nature of the attack or the resulting injury was such as might endanger the life or permanent health of the human. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2001, § 25)  
Sec. 6-110. - Penalties for dangerous animal violations. 
(a)  The owner or keeper of an animal which, when unprovoked, inflicts severe injury or death to a person or bites a person on public or private property, or which kills a domestic pet or animal without provocation while off the owner's property, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be subject to a fine not less than $200.00, but not more than $2,000.00. 
(b)  It shall be a violation of this chapter for an owner or keeper to fail to prevent a dangerous animal from killing or wounding, or assisting in the killing or wounding, of any pet or domestic animal belonging to or in possession of another person, or for an owner or keeper to fail to prevent a dangerous animal from attacking, assaulting, biting or otherwise injuring any person, or assisting in the attack, assault, biting or other injury of any person: 
(1)  Whether out of or within the enclosure of the owner or keeper. 
(2)  Whether or not such dangerous animal was on a leash or securely muzzled. 
(3)  Whether or not the dangerous animal escaped without the knowledge or consent of the owner or keeper. The Animal Control Officer shall seize and destroy such dangerous animal in an expeditious and humane manner. 
In addition the owner or keeper shall be cited for the offense, which shall be subject to a fine of not less than $200.00 and not more than $2,000.00. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2001, § 30)  
Sec. 6-111. - Animal declared to be dangerous. 
(a)  An animal shall be automatically declared to be a dangerous animal by an Animal Control Officer under section 6-109(2), (3), (4) and (7). 
(b)  Upon receipt of an affidavit of complaint signed by one or more individuals, made under oath before an individual authorized by law to make sworn statements, or made at the Office of the Animal Control Officer, setting forth the nature of the event: 
(1)  The owners of the animals; 
(2)  The address of the owners; 
(3)  The description of the animals doing such act. 
The Animal Control Officer shall investigate the complaint, including discussing the matter with the owner if that person can be located, and may determine if a dog is a dangerous animal under section 6-109(3) or (4). 
(c)  The owner of an animal shall have the right to provide such an affidavit or statement concerning his own animal. 
(d)  If the investigator concludes that seizure is a reasonable precaution to ensure the health and safety of people and animals nearby, pending a hearing by the Municipal Court, the Municipal Court may order the immediate seizure of the animal. 
(e)  An administrative search warrant shall be obtained from any Municipal Court Magistrate to enter onto private property to search for the previously declared or allegedly dangerous animal if permission to enter the subject premises is denied by a person in lawful possession. 
(f)  If the animal cannot be safely approached, a tranquilizer gun may be used by the Animal Control Designee Veterinarian. The costs of securing said animal pending the determination hearing shall be borne by the owner. 
(g)  Upon receipt of a completed affidavit of complaint the animal will be confined at a facility or other location designated by the Animal Control Officer until the dangerous animal determination hearing has been conducted, and the appeal if any is conducted, resulting in a final determination. 
(h)  If the animal under consideration is determined to be dangerous, it will remain in confinement at the facility directed by the Animal Control Officer until the animal owner is able to demonstrate the ability to comply with all requirements of the dangerous animal provisions as outlined in this article. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2001, § 26)  
Sec. 6-112. - Notification of dangerous animal declaration. 
(a)  Within five working days after declaring an animal dangerous, the Animal Control Officer shall notify the owner, by certified mail, return receipt requested, of the reason for the declaration, and of all requirements for the owner of a dangerous animal as set out in this article. 
(b)  If the animal is declared to be dangerous under section 6-109(3) and (4) the notice shall inform the owner of the animal that a determination hearing must be requested to contest the declaration. 
(c)  The request for a determination hearing must be in writing and must be received by the Animal Control Officer no later than five working days from receipt by the owner of the dangerous animal declaration. 
(d)  Failure to appeal the declaration of a dangerous animal within five days shall result in the Animal Control Officer's declaration being final with no appeal. 
(e)  The cost of securing said animal, boarding and final disposal shall be borne by the owner. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2001, § 27)  
Sec. 6-113. - Defense of dangerous animal declaration. 
It is a defense to the determination of an animal as dangerous and the prosecution of the owner of an animal if: 
(1)  Threat, injury or damage was sustained by a person who at the time was committing a willful trespass or other tort upon the premises occupied by the owner of the animal. 
(2)  The person was teasing, tormenting, abusing or assaulting the animal or has in the past been observed as reported to have teased, tormented, abused or assaulted the animal. 
(3)  The person was committing or attempting to commit a crime. 
(4)  The domestic animal killed was at the time teasing, tormenting, abusing or assaulting the animal. 
(5)  The animal was protecting or defending a person within the immediate vicinity of the animal from an attack or assault. 
(6)  The animal was protecting her offspring, itself or its kennelmate. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2001, § 28)  
Sec. 6-114. - Requirements of dangerous animal owners. 
(a)  An owner of an animal that is dangerous or vicious, whether by species or nature, or if declared dangerous by an administrative appeal hearing official, must comply with all of the following requirements: 
(1)  Before the owner can keep a dangerous animal, the owner must arrange to have the residence inspected where the animal is to be kept, and the Animal Control Officer must be satisfied that the requirements, which could have already been complied with, have been complied with by the owner. 
(2)  The animal has to be registered with the Animal Control Department as a dangerous animal. 
(3)  The dangerous animal shall at all times wear a collar, approved by the Animal Control Department and local veterinarian, visible at 50 feet so that the animal can be identified as a dangerous animal. 
(4)  The dangerous animal must be kept in a proper enclosure, such as a fence or a structure/pen, and the: 
a.  Fence or structure/pen must have minimum dimensions of five feet by ten feet; 
b.  Fence or structure/pen must form an enclosure suitable to prevent entry of small or young children; 
c.  Enclosure must be locked and secured such that an animal cannot climb, dig, jump or otherwise escape on its own volition; 
d.  Enclosure shall be securely locked at all times; 
e.  Structure/pen must have secured sides to prevent the dangerous animal from escaping from the enclosure; 
f.  Structure/pen shall provide protection from the elements for the dangerous animal; 
g.  Fence around the structure/pen must be no less than six feet in height unless the Animal Control Officer requires that the fence be higher than six feet or requires a secure top and/or bottom be added to the structure/pen if the need is demonstrated. 
(b)  These additional requirements shall be based upon the type of animal to be kept in the enclosure and its anticipated ability to escape: 
(1)  The owner shall post a sign on his premises warning that there is a dangerous animal on the property. The sign shall be visible and capable of being read from the public street or highway. In addition the sign shall have a design or uniform dangerous animal symbol or decal understandable by small children which must be displayed on or about the sign. 
(2)  The owner must present to the Animal Control Department a certificate of public liability insurance in the amount of $100,000.00 to cover any injuries caused by the dangerous animal. The insurance shall be kept in effect continuously and shall not be canceled unless the animal is no longer kept by the insured owner. 
(3)  The dangerous animal, when taken outside the enclosure, must be securely muzzled in a manner that will not cause injury to the animal nor interfere with its vision or respiration, but shall prevent it from biting any person or animal; and the dangerous animal must be restrained by a chain or cable leash having a minimum tensile strength of 1,000 pounds and not to exceed six feet in length. 
(4)  If the owner of an animal declared to be dangerous is unable or unwilling to comply with the ownership requirements listed above at any time, the animal must be euthanized by an animal shelter, animal control agency, or licensed veterinarian. An animal declared to be vicious under this article shall not be offered for adoption or sale. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2001, § 29)  
Secs. 6-115—6-138. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - LIVESTOCK, HORSE, FOWL AND SWINE 
 
Sec. 6-139. - Livestock. 
It shall be unlawful to keep or maintain any livestock within the City limits. In conformity with "The City of Pearsall, Texas Zoning Ordinance," no private stable, swine, cattle, horses, goats or other livestock, fowl or animal of any kind shall be permitted to be kept inside the City limits, with the exception of: 
(1)  Domestic pets, dogs and cats, and only with the permitted number per section 6-28. 
(2)  Temporary school livestock, fowl or agricultural projects and then only with the approval of the Zoning Administrator and the Animal Control Department. 
(3)  Animals kept in a veterinarian hospital or clinic. 
(4)  Property which falls under the grandfather clause. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2001, § 31)  
Sec. 6-140. - Horses. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to keep or maintain a horse or any member of the horse family within the City limits. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to ride any horse or any member of the horse family within any street, park, downtown, school or anywhere within the City limits for the safety, health and general welfare of the community and the inhabitants of the City, except when a permit has been requested and issued by the City and the requirements and conditions of such permit are met. 
(c)  Permits may be obtained at City Hall for parades; festivals; special events or occasions. Any person or organization requesting such permit within the City limits is required to: 
(1)  Have liability insurance and proof of such insurance in case of any accident or damage that might occur. 
(2)  Have poop scoopers to remove and clean any area where the animal deposits any kind of waste matter anywhere within the City. 
(3)  Remove horses or any other livestock within the City limits as soon as possible after the event is over. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2001, § 32)  
Sec. 6-141. - Domestic fowl. 
It shall be unlawful to keep or maintain any domestic fowl or poultry on any premises within the City, provided that: 
(1)  Parakeets. It shall be unlawful to keep or maintain more than ten parakeets on any premises within the City, provided that the parakeets are kept within a building at least 25 feet from any dwelling or business building owned or occupied by any person other than the owner. 
(2)  Parrots. It shall be unlawful to keep or maintain more than two parrots on any premises within the City, provided that the parrots are kept within 25 feet from any dwelling or business building owned or occupied by any person other than the owner. 
(3)  Poultry. It shall be unlawful to keep or maintain any poultry on any premises within the City, provided that the poultry is a school project of a FFA member under the supervision of a high school vocational agricultural teacher or of a 4-H member under the supervision of the County Agricultural Agent, other than for the purposes and at the location indicated herein: 
a.  When kept at the home of a FFA member and/or 4-H member with the supervision of the persons referenced in subsection (3) of this section. 
b.  They will only be allowed a limited period of time, not yearround. 
c.  The poultry must be registered with the Animal Control Department and Zoning Administration for periodic inspections by such City officials. 
d.  No more than four poultry may be kept on a single lot and they must be confined within a pen. 
e.  The pen or enclosure shall not be less than 20 feet from any dwelling or business building owned or occupied by any person other than the owner. 
f.  All poultry owners or keepers shall maintain sanitary standards for collecting and disposing of waste by placing it in a disposable container, sealing the container, and disposing of it as household garbage. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2001, § 33)  
Sec. 6-142. - Swine. 
It shall be unlawful to keep or maintain swine within the City limits other than for the purpose and at the location indicated: 
(1)  When located at and on the property of any vocational high school, with facilities properly constructed as determined by the Animal Control Officer. 
(2)  When kept at the home of a FFA member under the supervision of a high school vocational agricultural teacher or 4-H member under the supervision of the County Agricultural Agent, and subject to the following conditions: 
a.  The property upon which the FFA or 4-H member resides and maintains the swine must be a minimum of one acre in area with a maximum of five swine. 
b.  The minimum pen size shall be 625 square feet per swine, for those over 50 pounds, and the pen must be covered with a roof having a minimum of 100 square feet per hog with a minimum pen width of 15 feet. 
c.  All swine must be grain fed. 
d.  Hog wallows are prohibited. 
e.  Swine must be on self-watered or similar equipment approved by the Animal Control Officer. There shall be a slap or other solid type construction under the tank covering the area of four feet in each direction. 
f.  The open and adjacent areas must be kept clean. 
g.  The student or member must be under close supervision of a vocational teacher or the County Agricultural Agent. If the student or member does not conform to the City's regulations, such advisor will report the violations to the Animal Control Officer, or if the City, through periodic inspections, finds violations, it shall terminate immediately the keeping and maintaining of the swine at such location. 
h.  All pens or enclosures shall be a minimum of 150 feet from any residential dwelling or business building owned or occupied by any person other than the owner of the swine or person keeping and maintaining same. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2001, § 34)  
Sec. 6-143. - Removal of animal waste. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful not to clean, or remove any animal waste or manure of animals, fowl and livestock from, pens, cages, enclosures, corrals or standings at least once each day. All animal waste and fowl waste shall be disposed of by placing it in a disposable container, sealing the container, and disposing of it as household garbage. 
(b)  Livestock waste or manure shall be deposited in a manure storage bin of concrete or metal construction and shall be provided with a fly-tight lid. Such manure and other livestock animal waste shall be removed from this bin at least once each week to a disposal site approved by the Director of Public Health. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2001, § 35)  
Sec. 6-144. - Breeding and harboring of flies. 
It shall be unlawful to permit or allow fly breeding on premises on which animals, fowl or livestock are kept. Punishable by fine, and any permitting or allowing of such use shall be authorized denial, suspension or revocation of such use and the location shall be terminated immediately. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2001, § 36)  
Chapter 8 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— General enforcement authority of municipalities for preservation of health, property and good government, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 54.001 et seq.; municipal regulation of structures, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 214.001 et seq. 
 
Sec. 8-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Board means the Board of Adjustment of the City. 
Building means an enclosed structural unit, anchored to a permanent foundation, and having exterior or party walls and a roof, designed for the shelter of persons, animals or property. 
Commercial means occupied with business and commerce, designed mainly for profit. 
Conditional use means a use which may be permitted in a district subject to meeting certain conditions or procedures, as set forth in the Zoning chapter. 
Homestead means the fixed residence of the head of the family, with the land and buildings surrounding the main house. 
Planning and Zoning Commission means the Planning and Zoning Commission of the City. 
Residential means used as a residence or by residents. 
Special exception means permission given by the Board of Adjustment, properly authorized by ordinance, in specific cases for an applicant to use his property in a manner contrary to the provisions of the Zoning chapter, provided such use subserves the general welfare and preserves the community interest. 
Structure means any construction, or any production or piece of work artificially built up or composed of parts joined together in some definite manner; that which is built or constructed; an edifice or building of any kind. 
Variance means relief from or variation of the provisions of regulations, other than use regulations, as applied to a specific piece of property, as distinct from rezoning. It is an authorization given by the Board of Adjustment granting relief and doing substantial justice in the use of the applicant's property by the owner where, owing to special conditions, a literal enforcement of the provisions of the Zoning chapter, will result in unnecessary hardship. 
Zoning Administrator means a member of the City, appointed by the City Manager, who has the duty of administering the Zoning chapter. 
(Ord. of 1-10-1996(4), § 2)  
Sec. 8-2. - Penalty for violation. 
(a)  Any person who violates or fails to comply with the requirements of this chapter shall have committed an offense under this chapter punishable as a class C misdemeanor as defined in the Texas Penal Code, which imposes a fine not to exceed $500.00. 
(b)  Each day such violation shall be permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(c)  If the Zoning Administrator shall find, or if any person files with him a complaint in writing alleging that, any of the provisions of this chapter are being violated, he shall immediately investigate and, when necessary, give written notice to the person responsible to cease such violations forthwith. Said notice may be delivered in person or by certified mail to the violator or to any person of the property or by certified mail to any person of the property where a violation is occurring. 
(Ord. of 1-10-1996(4), § 7; Ord. of 8-30-2004, § 7)  
Sec. 8-3. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this chapter is to establish a uniform system of fees, charges and expenses for building, occupancy and other related permits issued by the City. 
(Ord. of 1-10-1996(4), § 1)  
Sec. 8-4. - City powers. 
Pursuant to section 20.13 of the Home Rule Charter, the City shall have the power to prohibit the erection or construction of any building or structure of any kind within the City and its ETJ without permits having been issued by the City for the construction or erection of such building or structure, as well as the installation of plumbing, electrical, gas, air conditioning/heating and other related building or structural systems, and may authorize a fee to be charged for such permits, and in pursuance of said authority may authorize the inspection by the City of all buildings or structures. 
(Ord. of 1-10-1996(4), § 3)  
Sec. 8-5. - Building permits required. 
(a)  No building or other structure shall be erected, moved, added to or structurally altered without a permit, therefore, issued by the Building Official. 
(b)  A building permit shall not be issued except in conformity with the provisions of the Zoning chapter, unless otherwise authorized in a written order from the Board of Adjustment in the form of an administrative review of variance and/or special exception. 
(c)  The Building Official shall be empowered to act within the provisions of this chapter upon all applications for building permits, and the same shall be approved or denied not later than the fifth business day succeeding the day of filing. In the event of refusal to issue a permit upon application, as herein provided, the applicant may perfect an appeal to the Board of Adjustment as provided for hereafter: 
(1)  Building permit becomes invalid. If the work described in any building permit has not begun within six months from the date of the issuance thereof, said permit shall be cancelled by the Building Official and written notice thereof shall be given to the persons affected. 
(2)  Conformity of construction and use. A building permit may be revoked by the Building Official at any time prior to the completion of the building or structure for which the same was issued, when it shall appear that there is departure from the plans, specifications or conditions as required under the terms of the permit; that the same was procured by false representation or was issued by mistakes, or that any of the provisions of this chapter, are being violated. Upon the failure, refusal or neglect of any owner, his agent, contractor or duly authorized representative to secure such permit and pay the prescribed fee therefor, as herein provided, the Building Official may issue a stop order; provided, however, 24 hours' written notice of such revocation or order to stop shall be served upon the owner, his agent or contractor, or upon any persons employed upon the building or structure for which such permit was issued, and thereafter no such construction shall proceed. 
(3)  A conditional use permit is required for all conditional uses. A conditional use permit may have a specified time limitation attached and may impose conditions other than those which are specifically set forth in this chapter. Granting a conditional use permit does not exempt the applicant from complying with other applicable ordinances. 
(4)  Appeals. Appeals to the Board of Adjustment may be taken by any person aggrieved or by any officer, department, board or bureau of the City affected by any decision of the Zoning Administrator. Such appeal shall be taken within a reasonable time, as provided by the rules of the Board, by filing with the Zoning Administrator and with the Board of Adjustment a notice of appeal specifying the grounds thereof. The Zoning Administrator shall forthwith transmit to the Board all the papers constituting the record upon which the action appealed from was taken. 
(5)  Appeals from action of the Board of Adjustment. Any person, jointly or severally, aggrieved by any decision of the Board, or any taxpayer, or any officer, department, board or bureau of the City, may present to a Court of Record a petition, duly verified, setting forth that such decision is illegal, in whole or in part, specifying the grounds of the illegality. Such petition shall be presented to the Court within ten days after the filing of the decision in the Office of the Board. 
(6)  Special exceptions. In conformity with the provisions of the Zoning chapter, a special exception may be granted on an application when the Board finds that the granting of such special exception: 
a.  Will not be injurious or otherwise detrimental to the public health, safety, morals and general welfare of the general public; 
b.  Will not be detrimental or injurious to the property or improvements in such zone or neighborhood in which the property is located; and 
c.  Will be in harmony with the general purpose and intent of the Zoning chapter. 
(7)  Variances. In conformity with the provisions of the Zoning chapter, a variance may be granted on an application when the Board finds that: 
a.  There are special circumstances or conditions applying to the land or building for which the variance is sought, which circumstances or conditions are peculiar to such land or buildings and do not apply generally to lands or buildings in the same zone or neighborhood and, that said circumstances or conditions are such that the strict application of the provisions of the Zoning chapter, would deprive the applicant of the reasonable use of such land or building; 
b.  The granting of such variance will not be detrimental to the public welfare or injurious to the property or improvements in such zone or neighborhood in which the property is located; 
c.  The granting of the variance is necessary for the reasonable use of the land or building and that the variance, as granted by the Board, is the minimum variance that will accomplish this purpose; 
d.  That the literal enforcement and strict application of the provisions of the Zoning chapter, will result in unnecessary hardship and be inconsistent with the general provisions and intent of the chapter and, that in granting such variance, the spirit of the Zoning chapter, will be preserved and substantial justice done; and 
e.  In addition to considering the character and use of adjoining buildings and those in the vicinity the Board, in determining its findings, shall take into account the number of persons residing or working in such buildings or upon such land and traffic conditions in the vicinity. 
(Ord. of 1-10-1996(4), § 4)  
Sec. 8-6. - Certificates of Zoning Compliance and Occupancy. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to use, occupy or permit the use or occupancy of any building or premises or both, or part thereof, hereafter created, erected, changed, converted, or wholly or partly altered or enlarged in its use or structure, nor will permanent utility connections to serve the premises be made, until a Certificate of Zoning Compliance/Occupancy shall have been issued therefore by the Zoning Administrator stating that the proposed use of the land conforms to the requirements of the Zoning chapter. 
(b)  A temporary Certificate of Zoning Compliance/Occupancy may be issued by the Zoning Administrator for a period not to exceed six months during alterations or partial occupancy of a building pending its completion, provided that such temporary certificate may include such conditions and safeguards as will protect the safety of the occupants and the public. 
(c)  The Zoning Administrator shall maintain a record of all Certificates of Zoning Compliance/Occupancy, which shall be open to public inspection. 
(d)  Failure of the owner/landlord to obtain a Certificate of Zoning Compliance/Occupancy shall be a violation of this section and punishable under the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. of 1-10-1996(4), § 5)  
Sec. 8-7. - Liability of Building Inspector. 
Where action is taken by the Building Inspector to enforce the provisions of this chapter, such action shall be in the name of and on behalf of the City, and the Inspector in so acting shall not render himself personally liable for any damage which may accrue to persons or property as a result of an action committed in good faith in the discharge of his duties, and any suit brought against any inspector by reason thereof shall be defended by the City Attorney until final determination of the proceedings contained therein. 
(Ord. of 1-10-1996(4), § 8)  
Sec. 8-8. - Responsibility for defects unchanged. 
This chapter does not relieve from or lessen the responsibility or liability of any person owning, operating, or controlling any electrical workmanship, for damages to person or property caused by any defect therein, nor shall the City be regarded as assuming any such liability by reason of the inspection authorized herein or certificate of approval issued as herein provided. 
(Ord. of 1-10-1996(4), § 9)  
Chapter 10 - BUSINESSES AND BUSINESS REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Licensing authority's power to deny, suspend, or revoke business license due to criminal background, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 53.001 et seq.; municipal regulation of miscellaneous businesses, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 215.001 et seq.; home rule municipal authority to license any lawful business or occupation that is subject to its police powers, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 215.075; uniformity required in the issuance of local permits, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 245.001 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 10-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Pool or billiard table means any table surrounded by a ledge or a cushion with or without pockets, upon which balls are propelled by a stick or cue, and where the player thereon does not or is not required to make a coin deposit causing an electrical connection of any nature or kind before such game may actually commence. 
(Ord. of 8-11-1966, § 1)  
Sec. 10-2. - Hours of operation. 
No person may engage in the operation for profit of any pool or billiard table within the City on weekdays between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 7:00 a.m. following; provided, further, that such table may be operated on Sundays only between the hours of 1:00 p.m. and 7:00 p.m. 
(Ord. of 8-11-1966, § 2)  
Secs. 10-3—10-24. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PEDDLERS AND ITINERANT VENDORS 
 
Sec. 10-25. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Designated, established business location within Frio County, Texas, means the ownership and occupancy of a lot or other tract of land, and building thereon, within Frio County, Texas, used by the person, or the person, partnership, firm, association, corporation or other form of business entity he represents, in direct selling of the product or service within the City, or the leasing or renting of a building within Frio County, Texas, by such a person, or the person, partnership, firm, association, corporation, or other form of business entity he represents, such building being used in the direct selling of the product or service within the City, provided that the leasing or renting of such building is for a continuous period of time, or not less than 90 days. 
Designated, established residence within Frio County, Texas, means the ownership and legal and continuous occupancy of a lot or other tract of land and residence located thereon within Frio County, Texas, by such person, or by the person he represents, or the prior continuous occupancy, for a period of not less than 90 days, of rented or leased quarters within Frio County, Texas, by such person, or the person he represents, as the only residence or place of abode of either such person. 
Itinerant or transient vendor means any person representing himself, or representing another person, partnership, firm, association, corporation, or other form of business entity, selling any product or service within the City, when neither such person, or the person, partnership, firm, association, corporation or other business entity he represents, has a designated, established residence or business location within Frio County, Texas. 
Product or service means any physical or material object or item, or any service of whatsoever nature, or any property right of any value represented by an oral or written promise or contract. 
Selling means selling, leasing or renting direct to the ultimate owner or user of such product or service, or to the agent or other representative of the ultimate owner or user of such product or service, whether such selling involves the delivery of the product or service at the time of the sale, or the taking of orders for future delivery, and whether such selling involves payment in advance, payment on delivery, by whatever means of delivery, or deferred payment after the delivery of the product or service sold. 
Ultimate owner or user means any member of any family for any other member of such family. 
(Ord. of 9-24-1985(2), § 2)  
Sec. 10-26. - Penalty. 
Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be subject to a penalty not to exceed $200.00 for each offense. 
(Ord. of 9-24-1985(2), § 14)  
Sec. 10-27. - Purpose. 
This entire article is and shall be deemed an exercise of the police powers of the State and of the City, for the purpose of establishing a reasonable method and system of inquiring into the history and background of transient and itinerant persons engaged in selling any product or service in the City, for the purpose of determining the honesty and integrity of such persons, and whether or not they are engaged in fraudulently representing the product or service they sell, and whether or not they are engaged in the selling and receiving of valuable consideration for a product or service which does not exist or is not intended to ever exist, all for the safety, protection, and best interest of the citizens of the City, and all of the provisions of this article shall be construed for the accomplishment of that purpose. 
(Ord. of 9-24-1985(2), § 1)  
Sec. 10-28. - Entering premises without invitation. 
It shall be unlawful for any solicitors of orders for goods, wares, or merchandise; peddlers; itinerant merchants; or transient vendors of goods, wares, or merchandise, to go in or upon any private premises situated within the corporate limits of the City for the purpose of soliciting orders for the sale of goods, wares, or merchandise, or for the purpose of selling or disposing of or peddling the same, without having first been requested or invited to go in or upon such premises by the owner or occupant thereof for such purpose. 
(Ord. of 9-24-1985(2), § 3)  
Sec. 10-29. - Selling on City-owned property. 
No selling activities described in section 10-28 shall be allowed upon or within any municipally owned and operated premises within the City, regardless of the status of the person so selling, whether itinerant, transient, permanent, locally domiciled, or otherwise, unless such person obtains a written permit from the City Manager or designee under the terms, conditions and consideration to be determined by the City. This section shall not apply to streets, sidewalks, and alleys, and no permit shall be issued which would authorize the violation of section 10-28. 
(Ord. of 9-24-1985(2), § 4)  
Sec. 10-30. - Selling on streets, sidewalks and alleys. 
No person, regardless of nature, itinerant, transient, permanent, locally domiciled or otherwise, shall engage in any kind of selling activity described in section 10-28 on the public streets, sidewalks and alleys of the City unless such person shall first register with the City Manager or designee and obtain a permit therefor. Such permit shall only be issued by the City Manager or designee if the applicable provisions of sections 10-27, 10-32, 10-33, and 28-4 are met and applicants shall have filed proof with the City Manager or designee of compliance with City health codes, if applicable. If the selling activity involves the use or operation of a motor vehicle, the applicant shall also file with the City Manager or designee proof that such business entity has, in force, a policy of liability insurance issued by an insurance company licensed to do business in the State, with minimum policy limits as follows: $100,000.00 per person; $300,000.00 for any single occurrence for bodily injury or death; and $10,000.00 for any single occurrence for injury to or destruction of property. 
(Ord. of 9-24-1985(2), § 5)  
Sec. 10-31. - Registration required. 
Each itinerant or transient vendor, prior to engaging in the selling of any product or service within the City, shall first register with the City Manager or designee at the office of such Manager or designee in the City Hall, on registration forms provided for that purpose. No such person shall sell any product or service until the registration card provided for in this section has been issued to him and he is carrying it on his person at the time of his activities. 
(Ord. of 9-24-1985(2), § 6)  
Sec. 10-32. - Registration information. 
The form for registration shall require, and each person registering shall furnish, the following information: 
(1)  The full name of the person registering. 
(2)  Whether or not he has a permanent home and/or business address, and if so, setting out such address. 
(3)  Whether or not the registrant represents himself or another person or other business entity, and if so, the name and permanent home or business address, if any, of such other person or other business entity. 
(4)  The names, including state and county, of the last preceding cities or towns in which the person registering conducted selling operations, up to but not exceeding the last five such towns or cities immediately preceding his arrival in the City. 
(5)  A detailed description of the product or service to be offered for sale and sold by such person within the City, including display of samples, if any, at the time of registering. 
(6)  The names and address of references, if any, including banks and inspection and approval agencies. 
(7)  A statement by the registrant, under oath, as to whether he has ever been sued in a civil or criminal proceeding in a duly constituted court of law for any form of fraud, theft, or embezzlement; and whether or not the person or other business entity he may represent, has ever been, to the registrant's knowledge, convicted in a duly constituted court of law for any form of fraud, theft or embezzlement. 
(Ord. of 9-24-1985(2), § 7)  
Sec. 10-33. - Bond. 
No license shall be issued prior to the posting of a cash bond or surety bond with the City Manager or designee in an amount of not less than $1,000.00, which bond shall be payable to the City for the use and benefit of any person entitled thereto, and conditioned that the principal and surety will pay all damages to any person caused by or arising from or growing out of the wrongful, fraudulent or illegal conduct of the itinerant merchant while conducting the sale or exhibit in the City. The bond shall remain in full force and effect for the entire duration of the license as provided herein and one year thereafter. Any surety bond shall provide for ten days' written notice to the City Manager or designee prior to cancellation or material change. 
(Ord. of 9-24-1985(2), § 8)  
Sec. 10-34. - Investigation of registrant and his principal. 
The City Manager or designee shall, upon each registration, forthwith deliver a copy thereof to the Police Department, which shall thereupon conduct an inquiry of the reputation and background of the person registering and the person or other business entity, if any, that such registrant represents. Such investigation shall not exceed seven days in time. 
(Ord. of 9-24-1985(2), § 10)  
Sec. 10-35. - Issuance, denial of registration card. 
(a)  Upon completion of the investigation provided for in section 10-34, if no evidence of fraud, theft or embezzlement in the selling operations of the registrant, person or other business entity, if any, that the registrant represents, is discovered or determined, the Police Department shall issue to such a registration card bearing the name of such registrant, person, or other business entity, if any, that the registrant represents, a statement to the effect that such registrant has been registered and approved by the City for selling within the City the product or service he is selling, and bearing the signature of the Chief of Police. 
(b)  In the event evidence of fraud, theft or embezzlement, in the entity he represents, is developed and discovered in such investigation, the registrant shall be denied permission to operate in the City and no registration card shall be issued to him. 
(Ord. of 9-24-1985(2), § 11)  
Sec. 10-36. - Term and renewal of registration card. 
A registration shall be effective for a one-year period from the date issued. In the event the registrant desires to continue selling activities in the City in the state of an itinerant or transient vendor, he shall again register, pay the prescribed fee, and qualify for a new card, as provided for in this article, continuing such reregistration each year for so long as he shall continue his selling operations within the City; provided that, in the event the registrant, or the person or business entity, if any, that he represents, should establish a County residence or business site, as defined in section 10-25, the requirement of registering and licensing shall terminate for so long as such established residence or business site is maintained in the County. 
(Ord. of 9-24-1985(2), § 12)  
Sec. 10-37. - Exemptions. 
The provisions of this article shall not apply to or affect or control the following: 
(1)  The selling of products or services wholesale to retail dealers within the City. 
(2)  The selling of products or services within the City by use of the United States mail exclusively, and where no personal contact by the seller, or agents of the seller or purchaser, is had. 
(3)  The selling of insurance contracts by registered agents. 
(4)  The selling of products to be delivered to the purchaser direct from an out-of-state source in the original package. 
(5)  Solicitations for charitable purposes. 
(Ord. of 9-24-1985(2), § 13)  
Secs. 10-38—10-53. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - BUSINESS LICENSE 
 
Sec. 10-54. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Business shall be as defined by the Texas State Comptroller. 
(Ord. No. 2017-02-03, § 1, 2-21-2017)  
Sec. 10-55. - Registration requirements. 
Every business operating in the City of Pearsall is required to apply for and display a business license issued by the City of Pearsall and annually complete an application that shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name of the business and the business owner; 
(2)  The address of the business and the address of the owner; 
(3)  The business telephone number and the cell phone number of the owner or manager; 
(4)  Type of business and/or primary business operation; 
(5)  Legal description of the business site; 
(6)  Signature of applicant indicating all information submitted is correct. 
(Ord. No. 2017-02-03, § 2, 2-21-2017)  
Sec. 10-56. - Certificate of occupancy. 
In order to operate a business in the City of Pearsall, every business must have a valid certificate of occupancy in addition to a valid business license. 
(Ord. No. 2017-02-03, § 3, 2-21-2017)  
Sec. 10-57. - Application fee. 
The first application will be due by July 1, 2017. The application fee for those timely filed by July 1, 2017 shall be waived. Thereafter, every business operating in the City shall pay an annual business license fee that expires on December 31 of each year. 
(Ord. No. 2017-02-03, § 4, 2-21-2017)  
Sec. 10-58. - Issuance of license. 
The building development services director or his designee will issue an applicant a business license after complying with all the requirements in this article. 
(Ord. No. 2017-02-03, § 5, 2-21-2017)  
Sec. 10-59. - Enforcement. 
The duly constituted authorities of the City, including the building development services department and others having the duty of enforcing the ordinances of the City. 
(Ord. No. 2017-02-03, § 6, 2-21-2017)  
Sec. 10-60. - Penalty. 
Any person who shall violate any provision of this article shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine or not more than $500.00. 
(Ord. No. 2017-02-03, § 7, 2-21-2017)  
Secs. 10-61—10-79. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - GAME ROOMS AND AMUSEMENT REDEMPTION MACHINES 
 
Sec. 10-80. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Amusement redemption machine means any electronic, electromechanical, or mechanical contrivance that for a consideration affords the player an opportunity to obtain anything of value, the award of which is determined solely or partially by chance, even though accompanied by some skill, whether or not the prize is automatically paid by the contrivance, including but not limited to, gambling device versions of bingo, keno, blackjack, lottery, roulette, video poker, tic-tac-toe eight-liner or similar electronic, electromechanical, or mechanical games, or facsimiles thereof, that operate by chance or partially so. 
City official means a code enforcement officer or building official of the City of Pearsall or any peace officer of the State of Texas. 
Game room means a building, facility or other place that is open to the public and that contains one or more operational amusement redemption machines. 
Game room owner means a person who has any ownership interest in a game room or an owner, director, or officer of a business entity that has any ownership interest in a game room. 
Operational machine means a machine that is ready to be played and accessible to the public. 
(Ord. No. 2012-12-179, § 1(1.01), 12-18-2012)  
Sec. 10-81. - Licensing. 
(a)  Payment of fee and issuance of license. An owner, operator, or lessee of an amusement redemption machine game room shall be required to secure a license annually. An amusement redemption machine game room shall be required to secure a license by paying to the City an annual inspection and amusement redemption machine game room license fee. 
(b)  Application. Application shall not be approved until a completed application has been submitted and found to meet all application requirements. An applicant for a license or permit shall file with the Department of Community Development a written application on a form provided for that purpose, which shall be signed by the applicant, who shall be the owner, operator, or lessee of the amusement redemption machine game room. Should an applicant maintain an amusement redemption machine game room at more than one location, a separate application must be filed for each location. The following information is required in the application: 
(1)  Location, by address, of the proposed operation; 
(2)  A copy of the certificate of formation if the business is registered with the secretary of state, or the applicant's d/b/a, if applicable; 
(3)  Name, address, telephone number and driver's license number of the following persons, if applicable: 
a.  Applicant, if a natural person; 
b.  All persons who own 25 percent or more interest in the amusement redemption machine game room; 
c.  All corporate officers, if any, of such business; 
d.  If a partnership, each of the general and limited partners; 
e.  The property owner; and 
f.  The manager of the property and/or business. 
(4)  The previous occupation(s) of the applicant and, if applicable, all corporate officers and partners of the applicant within the preceding five years; 
(5)  Whether a previous license or permit of applicant, or, if applicable, corporate or partner of applicant, has been revoked within two years of filing of the application; 
(6)  Number of amusement redemption machines in the amusement redemption machine game room. 
(7)  An authorization to conduct a background check for all individuals included in subsection (b)(3) of this section. The license will be denied if any individual has any convictions, guilty pleas, or deferred adjudications related to gambling or organized crime or any felony within the prior five years. 
(8)  A sworn statement that: 
a.  That all the facts contained in the application are true and correct; 
b.  The location and operation of the amusement redemption machine game room will not violate any applicable deed restrictions; 
c.  The amusement redemption machine game room will be operated in accordance with all laws and City Ordinances, including V.T.C.A., Penal Code ch. 47; 
d.  Acknowledgment that the Application and Permit Processes of this article do not in any way legalize anything prohibited under V.T.C.A., Penal Code ch. 47; and 
e.  Acknowledgment that V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 47.01(4)(b)'s exclusion includes only those machines that are in good faith intended, produced, and made fit only for the single, limited purpose of entertainment. 
(9)  Name, address, and telephone number of any emergency contact person who can be reached after hours. 
(c)  Expiration and renewal. 
(1)  Expiration. An annual amusement redemption machine game room license issued by the City shall automatically expire on December 31 following its issuance, except as otherwise stated herein. Such license shall automatically expire if the licensee sells the property or the business, transfers equity to accomplish same, or otherwise disposes of such devices. An amusement redemption machine game room license is not assignable or transferable. The City shall not refund any portion of a license after the license is issued, nor shall it prorate or reduce in amount any fee due to the City. 
(2)  Late penalty. Upon the expiration of a license, the licensee shall obtain a renewal if the licensee wishes to continue operating an amusement redemption machine game room. Failure to obtain the renewal within 30 days after expiration will require such person to pay an additional late fee in an amount equal to 20 percent of the fee actually due or 20 percent of the previous year's fee, whichever is greater, in order to obtain reinstatement of his license. Nothing herein authorizes the licensee to operate after the expiration of a license and before a renewal is effective. 
(d)  Posting of license. The license shall be conspicuously posted inside the building. 
(e)  Restrictions, regulations, controls, and limitations. The following restrictions, regulations, controls, and limitations shall apply to all amusement redemption machine game rooms: 
(1)  Condition of premises. All building and fire code standards must be met. A certificate of occupancy shall be requested before license is issued. Game room must be located in an area zoned for that activity. 
(2)  Methods of conduction of business. Amusement redemption machines are not allowed outdoors. 
(3)  Hours of operation. May only be operated between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 12:00 a.m. 
(4)  Parking requirements. One space for each two machines, plus one space per employee per shift. 
(5)  Location requirements. Premises shall not operate within 500 feet radius of an established church, school, day care or hospital. Premises shall not operate within 1,500 feet radius of another amusement redemption machine game room. 
(6)  Alcoholic beverages. No amusement redemption machine game room may be located on premises where alcoholic beverages are sold or served, with the exception of any Congressionally chartered, non-profit organization. 
(7)  The owner, operator, or manager of the premises must be present to supervise the operation of the machines. The machines shall not be left unattended. 
(8)  Machines must be situated within the premises as to be in full and open public view, which entails being visible to all patrons of the establishment. 
(9)  A game room operator must be a person who is at least 18 years of age. 
(10)  Total number of machines in one establishment shall be limited to 51. 
(11)  All machines must be permitted according to the permitting requirements of section 10-82. 
(Ord. No. 2012-12-179, § 1(2.02), 12-18-2012)  
Sec. 10-82. - Amusement redemption machine permitting. 
(a)  Permit application. An owner, operator, or lessee of an amusement redemption machine game room shall be required to obtain a permit for each amusement redemption machine. As part of the application, the owner, operator, or lessee must submit, at their own expense, each amusement redemption machine, including hardware and software source code, to an independent gaming compliance and testing laboratory approved in advance by the City to ensure that the machine does not generate the resultant outcome independent of the skillful actions of the player. Any game that is determined to be beyond the ability of a player to predict or control the outcome will not be permitted or allowed to operate within the incorporated limits of the City. 
(b)  Permit. Following approval by the independent gaming compliance and testing laboratory, the City shall issue a permit that will be permanently affixed to the approved machine. The permit shall include the name of the machine and the machine's serial number. 
(c)  Sealing or seizure. A person commits an offense if he owns an operational machine without a permit or with a tampered permit. In addition to other criminal or civil remedies outlined in this article, the City shall have the authority to seal or seize any coin-operated machine located in any amusement redemption machine game room for which a permit is not displayed. If any amusement redemption machine is found with evidence of permit tampering of any kind, including a permit issued to a different machine or a change in the game's hardware or software after the date of the permit issuance, the City shall have the authority to seal or seize all amusement redemption machines in the game room for retesting at the owner's expense and/or to revoke the owner's license to operate a game room. 
(Ord. No. 2012-12-179, § 1(2.03), 12-18-2012)  
Sec. 10-83. - Unrestricted access by City official. 
An owner, manager, or employee of a game room or other person exercising control over a game room, a portion of a game room or an operational amusement redemption machine, shall provide a City official with immediate unrestricted access during business hours to all areas of the game room and to all operational amusement redemption machines located in the game room. 
(Ord. No. 2012-12-179, § 1(2.04), 12-18-2012)  
Sec. 10-84. - Inspection by City officials. 
(a)  Any City official may inspect a game room or an operational amusement redemption machine located within the incorporated City limits to determine whether the game room or the operational amusement redemption machine complies with this Code and state law. 
(b)  An owner, manager or employee of a game room or other person who does not allow a City official to inspect a game room or operational amusement redemption machine commits an offense. 
(Ord. No. 2012-12-179, § 1(2.05), 12-18-2012)  
Sec. 10-85. - Transparent, uncovered windows required. 
(a)  Every game room shall have transparent unobstructed windows or open space on at least one side so that the area is open to view by the general public passing by on a public street or using a corridor, lobby or other room to which the public has access and is admitted without charge. The owner, manager or employee of a game room shall not permit any obstruction of such public view by the use of drawn shades, blinds, partitions, tinting or other structures or obstructions. 
(b)  The requirements of subsection (a) of this section may be waived or modified by the Building Official if the game room owner can demonstrate: 
(1)  The game room is located in a structure deemed a historic landmark, or the structure is within a historic district, and deemed to have architectural or historic significance; and 
(2)  Compliance with the unobstructed view requirement shall require alterations to the structure that will have a substantially detrimental effect on its historic or architectural features. 
(Ord. No. 2012-12-179, § 1(2.06), 12-18-2012)  
Sec. 10-86. - Hours of operation, ingress and egress. 
(a)  All game rooms shall have their hours of operation clearly marked on every entrance. 
(b)  All game room shall have all doors providing ingress and egress from the game room unlocked during the hours of operation. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, conduct or operate any game room for profit or to allow or permit any game room to remain open for business or open to the public before the hour of 10:00 a.m. or after the hour of 12:00 a.m. 
(Ord. No. 2012-12-179, § 1(2.07), 12-18-2012)  
Sec. 10-87. - Offense; penalty. 
Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this article or fail to comply therewith shall be deemed guilty of a Class C misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be fined not to exceed the maximum amount allowable by law. This offense is hereby declared to be a strict liability offense and the culpable mental state required by V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 6.02 is hereby specifically negated and clearly dispensed with. Each day that the violation occurs shall constitute a distinct and separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 2012-12-179, § 1(2.08), 12-18-2012)  
Secs. 10-88—10-106. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - SEXUALLY ORIENTED BUSINESSES 
 
Sec. 10-107. - Purpose and intent. 
It is the purpose and intent of this article to regulate sexually oriented businesses to promote the health, safety, morals and general welfare of the citizens of the City and to establish reasonable and uniform regulations to prevent the concentration of sexually oriented businesses within the City. The provisions of this article have neither the purpose nor effect of imposing a limitation or restriction on the content of any communicative material, including sexually oriented materials. Similarly, it is not the intent or effect of this article to restrict or deny access by adults to sexually oriented materials protected by the First Amendment, or to deny access by the distributors and exhibitors of sexually oriented entertainment to their intended market. 
(Ord. No. 2012-07-162, art. I, 8-14-2012)  
Sec. 10-108. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Adult motel means hotel, motel or similar commercial establishment that: 
(1)  Offers accommodations to the public for any form of consideration; provides patrons with closed-circuit television transmissions, films, motion pictures, video cassettes, slides, or other photographic reproductions that are characterized by the depiction or description of "specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas" and has a sign visible from the public right-of-way that advertises the availability of this adult type of photographic reproductions; 
(2)  Offers a sleeping room for rent for under a period of time that is less than ten hours; or 
(3)  Allows a tenant or occupant of a sleeping room to subrent the room for a period of time that is less than ten hours.
