Adult motion picture theater means a commercial establishment where, for any form of consideration, films, motion pictures, video cassettes, slides or similar photographic reproductions are regularly shown that are characterized by the depiction or description of "specified sexual activities" or " specified anatomical area". 
Adult theater means a theater, concert hall, auditorium, or similar commercial establishment that regularly features persons who appear in a state of nudity or live performances that are characterized by the exposure of "specified anatomical areas" or by "specified sexual activities". 
Department means the Frio County Regulatory Office, the Frio County Sheriff's Office, any Frio County Constable, any Frio County employee, Frio County Volunteer Fire Chief, the City of Pearsall Fire Chief, the City of Pearsall Police Department, City of Pearsall Code Compliance Officer, any law enforcement agency or division responsible for the issuance of any permit(s); enforcement of the sexually oriented businesses or enforcement of any laws of the State of Texas. 
Exempt business means (1) a bookstore, movie theater, or video store, unless that business is an adult bookstore, adult movie theater, or adult video store, as defined in § 2.01(c) of this Order; (2) a business operated by or employing a licensed psychologist, licensed physical therapist, licensed athletic trainer, licensed cosmetologist, or licensed barber engaged in performing functions authorized under the license held; or (3) a business operated by or employing a licensed physician or licensed chiropractor engaged in practicing the healing arts. 
Nudity, semi-nudity or a state of nudity means the appearance of a human bare buttock, anus, male genitals, female genitals, or female breast; or a state of dress that fails to completely and opaquely covers a human buttock, anus, male genitals, female genitals, or any part of the female breast or breasts that is situated below a point immediately above the top of areola. 
Residential use means of single family, duplex, townhouse, multiple family, or "mobile home park, mobile home subdivision, and campground" or "RV Park" used for residential purposes. 
Sexually oriented business means a sex parlor, topless dancing, nude dancing, nude studio, modeling studio, love parlor, adult bookstore, adult movie theater, adult video arcade, adult movie arcade, adult theater, adult video store, adult motel, escort agency, or other commercial enterprise the primary business of which is the offering of a service or the selling, renting, or exhibiting of devices or any other items intended to provide sexual stimulation or sexual gratification on the customer. 
Sign means any display, design, pictorial, or other representation that is constructed, placed, attached, painted, created, fastened, or manufactured in any manner whatsoever so that it is visible from the outside of a sexually oriented business; and used to seek the attraction of the public to any goods, services, or merchandise available at the sexually oriented business. 
Specified anatomical areas means any of the following, or any combination of the following, when less than completely and opaquely covered: 
(1)  Any human genitals, pubic region, or pubic hair; 
(2)  Any buttock; or 
(3)  Any portion of the female breast or breasts that is situated below a point immediately above the top of the areola; or 
(4)  Human male genitals in a discernibly erect state, even if completely and opaquely covered. 
Specified sexual activities means and includes any of the following: 
(1)  The fondling or other erotic touching of human genitals, pubic region, buttock, anus, or female breasts; 
(2)  Sex acts, normal or perverted, actual, stimulated or simulated, including intercourse, oral copulation, or sodomy; 
(3)  Masturbation, actual, stimulated or simulated; or 
(4)  Excretory functions as part of or in connection with any of the activities set forth in paragraphs of this subsection. 
(Ord. No. 2012-07-162, art. II, 8-14-2012)  
Sec. 10-109. - Administration. 
(a)  Pursuant to the above authority, the City Council hereby designates and authorizes the Department to inspect sexually oriented businesses to determine compliance with these regulations and to issue licenses in accordance with these regulations. 
(b)  Pursuant to the above authority, the City Council hereby designates and authorizes the Code Compliance Department or any law enforcement agency of the State of Texas to inspect sexually oriented businesses to determine compliance with these regulations and to issue citations for violating these regulations. 
(Ord. No. 2012-07-162, art. III, 8-14-2012)  
Sec. 10-110. - License required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to own or operate a sexually oriented business without a valid license issued therefore by Code Compliance Department in accordance with the provisions of these regulations. 
(b)  A license issued under these regulations shall be displayed at all times in an open and conspicuous place in the sexually oriented business for which it was issued. 
(c)  A license issued pursuant to these regulations shall be valid for one year from date of issue. Applicant must apply for renewal of their license at least 30 days before the anniversary date on which the license was issued. The sexually oriented business will not be permitted to operate if the license has expired and a new license has not been issued. 
(d)  Any license issued pursuant to these regulations may be revoked at any time for failure to comply with the regulations contained in this Order. 
(Ord. No. 2012-07-162, art. IV, 8-14-2012)  
Sec. 10-111. - Conditions issuance, renewal, and maintenance of license. 
(a)  A sexually oriented business and any owner or operator of a sexually oriented business shall comply with all the regulations promulgated herein and all laws of the State. Any failure to comply with the laws of the State shall be sufficient grounds for denial or revocation of any license required by these regulations. 
(b)  A license for a sexually oriented business shall be denied if the location of such business does not comply with these regulations. 
(c)  A license for a sexually oriented business shall be denied if an applicant has failed to provide information reasonably necessary for issuance of the license or has falsely answered a question or request for information on the application form or request for additional information from the agency issuing the license. 
(d)  A license for a sexually oriented business shall not be renewed if an applicant or applicant's spouse is overdue in payment to the City for taxes, fees, fines, or penalties assessed against or imposed upon the applicant or the applicant's spouse in relation to a sexually oriented business. 
(e)  A license for a sexually oriented business shall be denied if an applicant or applicant's spouse has been convicted of a crime involving: 
(1)  Any of the following offenses as described in V.T.C.A., Penal Code ch. 43: 
a.  Prostitution; 
b.  Promotion of prostitution; 
c.  Aggravated promotion of prostitution; 
d.  Compelling prostitution; 
e.  Obscenity; 
f.  Sale, distribution, or display of harmful material to minor; 
g.  Sexual performance by a child; 
h.  Possession of child pornography; 
(2)  Any of the following offenses as described in V.T.C.A., Penal Code ch. 21: 
a.  Public lewdness; 
b.  Indecent exposure; 
c.  Indecency with a child; 
(3)  Sexual assault or aggravated sexual assault as described in V.T.C.A., Penal Code ch. 22; 
(4)  Incest, solicitation of a child, or harboring a runway child as described in V.T.C.A., Penal Code ch. 25; 
(5)  Any gambling offense described in V.T.C.A., Penal Code ch. 47; 
(6)  Criminal attempt, conspiracy, or solicitation to commit any of the forgoing offenses. 
(f)  A license for a sexually oriented business shall be denied if an applicant or applicant's spouse has been convicted of a crime for which: 
(1)  Less than two years have elapsed since the date of conviction or the date of release from confinement for the convictions, whichever is the later date, if the conviction is a misdemeanor offense; 
(2)  Less than five years have elapsed since the date of last conviction or the release from confinement for the convictions, whichever is the later date, if the convictions are of two or more misdemeanor offenses or combination of misdemeanor offenses occurring within any 24-month period; 
(3)  Less than five years have elapsed since the date of conviction or the date of release from confinement for the convictions, whichever is the later date, if the conviction is a misdemeanor offense; 
(4)  The fact that the conviction is being appealed has no effect on the disqualification of the applicant or applicant's spouse. 
(5)  An applicant who has been convicted or whose spouse has been convicted of an offense listed above may qualify for a sexually oriented business license only when the time period required by subsection (f)(2) of this section has elapsed. 
(g)  A license for a sexually oriented business shall be denied if an applicant, applicant's spouse, a licensee, agent, or any employee has knowingly allowed any act of sexual intercourse, sodomy, oral copulation, masturbation, or sexual contact to occur in or on the licensed premises. The term "sexual contact" shall have the same meaning as it is defined in V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 21.02. 
(h)  The location of any sexually oriented business is hereby prohibited within 2,000 linear feet from a preexisting sexually oriented business, measured in a straight line from the nearest property line to the nearest property line. 
(i)  The location of any sexually oriented business is hereby prohibited within 2,000 linear feet from the following preexisting land uses which have been determined by the City Council to be inconsistent with the operation of a sexually oriented business, measured in a straight line from the nearest property line to the nearest property line: 
(1)  A residential neighborhood, trailer park, trailer park mobile home subdivision, campground or RV park; 
(2)  A commercial enterprise; 
(3)  A regular place of religious worship; 
(4)  A public or private school; 
(5)  A public university or college; 
(6)  A hospital or nursing home; 
(7)  A licensed daycare for children; 
(8)  A public park; 
(9)  A public building, including but not limited to the City Hall; 
(10)  A hotel or motel; 
(11)  A tourist information center; 
(12)  A convention center; 
(13)  A cultural institution such as a museum; and 
(14)  A historic district or landmark. 
(j)  The sexually oriented business must comply with all State fire code regulations. 
(k)  The sexually oriented business must comply with all State building and electrical code regulations. 
(l)  The sexually oriented business must post the maximum occupancy at all entrances and exits. 
(m)  The sexually oriented business cannot serve any alcoholic beverages without the appropriate licenses required by the State Alcoholic Commission. 
(n)  The sexually oriented business must have two licensed security guards inside their building. 
(o)  The sexually oriented business must post at least one licensed security guard outside its building and parking lot to prevent theft and other criminal activity. 
(p)  The sexually oriented business must have all entrances and roads to its business paved to assist law enforcement or the fire department to respond to any emergency situations in a timely manner. 
(q)  The sexually oriented business shall have installed a fire hydrant connected to their water source for the use of the fire department for any fires at the license premises or any surrounding premises, unless waived by the City Council. 
(r)  The sexually oriented business cannot use pyrotechnics inside or outside its sexually oriented business. 
(s)  The sexually oriented business cannot permit guests to smoke inside the building. 
(t)  If smoking is permitted outside, the sexually oriented business must take all precautions to insure that all matches or cigarettes do not cause a fire. 
(u)  The sexually oriented business will not be permitted to burn any garbage. 
(v)  The sexually oriented business will only be allowed to sell beverages in plastic container or cans. 
(w)  The sexually oriented business will only be allowed to serve mixed drinks in plastic containers or other non-glass cups. 
(x)  The sexually oriented business must have its business and parking lot fenced in with a six-foot privacy fence. 
(y)  The sexually oriented business must keep its business free of any garbage. 
(z)  The sexually oriented business cannot post a sign with flashing or neon lights and the sign cannot be larger than four feet wide and eight feet long. 
(aa)  The sign cannot have any nudity and cannot be posted in any areas designated in subsection (i) of this section. 
(bb)  The sexually oriented business must pay any additional fee for fire code inspections or for any other required inspections by law. 
(cc)  The sexually oriented business must operate all business activities within the four walls of its business. 
(dd)  All water wells must comply with TCEQ standards. 
(ee)  The septic system must also comply with all City, County and State standards. 
(ff)  The sexually oriented businesses are required to conduct background checks of their employees and operators, including medical documentation from a licensed physician relative to legitimate health concerns of the City, including but not limited to, sexually transmitted diseases. 
(gg)  The employees of any sexually oriented business must wear identification badges at all times. The operator of any sexually oriented business shall not permit any entertainer, server or other employee to appear nude or semi-nude or in a state of nudity, or semi-nudity on the premises and shall have no contact with the customer or clothing of the customer. 
(hh)  Customers of a sexually oriented business shall have no contact with any employee or the clothing of the employee at any time. 
(ii)  The sexually oriented businesses are not to have any eight-liners or other prohibited gambling devices prohibited by V.T.C.A., Penal Code ch. 47. 
(jj)  A licensee shall not transfer his license to another, nor shall a licensee operate a sexually oriented business under the authority of a license at any place other than the address designated to the application. 
(Ord. No. 2012-07-162, art. V, 8-14-2012)  
Sec. 10-112. - Application for license. 
(a)  Application for a license under these regulations may be made by submitting to the Code Compliance Department a completed application form and a check or money order made payable to the City to cover the cost of processing the application and, in the case of a license, investigating the applicant. Application forms may be obtained from the Code Compliance Department. 
(b)  A deed and plat must be attached to each application. If a deed and plat are not submitted, the application will be considered incomplete and will be rejected. 
(c)  The application must be accompanied by the building plans, a sketch or diagram showing the configurations of the premises, including a statement of total floor space occupied by the business. The building plans, sketch or diagram need not be professionally prepared but must be drawn to a designated scale or drawn with marked dimensions of the interior of the premises to an accuracy of plus or minus six inches. 
(d)  As part of the licensing process, notification of the application to the public and interested parties is required. The applicant must provide proof of notification of his intent to file an application to open or operate a sexually oriented business to the public by providing a publisher's affidavit from the local newspaper in which the notification was published for no less than two consecutive weeks. 
(e)  The Code Compliance Department shall notify any applicant for a license within 30 days of receiving the completed application whether the license shall be issued or denied. 
(f)  Prior to the expiration of the 30-day application process, any interested parties may request a public hearing on health and safety matters. If no public hearing is requested, depending on the approval of the application, the license may be granted. 
(Ord. No. 2012-07-162, art. VI, 8-14-2012)  
Sec. 10-113. - Appeal from denial or revocation of license. 
(a)  An applicant may appeal a denial or revocation of a license to own or operate a sexually oriented business, by submitting to the City Manager a written request for a hearing on a the denial or revocation within ten working days of the denial or revocation. 
(b)  The City Council shall hear any appeal. An applicant shall be notified of a hearing date within 30 days of receipt by the City Manager of a hearing request. 
(c)  At the hearing, the City Council shall determine whether a license to own or operate a sexually oriented business shall be issued or reinstated or denied. The applicant has the burden of proving by clear and convincing evidence that the enterprise meets all the requirements of this article such that the business is not or would not be detrimental to the public health, safety and welfare. 
(d)  If the City Council determines that a license to own or operate a sexually oriented business shall be issued or reinstated, the City Council shall direct the Code Compliance Department to issue or reinstate the applicant's license. 
(e)  If the City Council determines that no license to own or operate a sexually oriented business shall be issued or reinstated, the applicant may pursue further remedies in the County District Court pursuant to V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 243.007(c). 
(Ord. No. 2012-07-162, art. VII, 8-14-2012)  
Sec. 10-114. - Inspection. 
The Code Compliance Department may inspect any sexually oriented business within the City's authority to determine compliance with any of the regulations contained in this article. 
(Ord. No. 2012-07-162, art. VIII, 8-14-2012)  
Sec. 10-115. - Enforcement 
(a)  The City may sue in the County District Court for an injunction to prohibit the violation of any of the regulations contained in this article. 
(b)  A person commits an offense if he operates a sexually oriented business without a valid license, issued by the City. 
(c)  A violation of any the regulations contained in this article constitutes a criminal offense. Such an offense is a Class A misdemeanor, punishable by: 
(1)  A fine not to exceed $4,000.00; 
(2)  Confinement in jail for a term not to exceed one year; or 
(3)  Both such fine and confinement. 
(Ord. No. 2012-07-162, art. IX, 8-14-2012)  
Secs. 10-116—10-134. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - TOWING AND WRECKER SERVICES 
 
Sec. 10-135. - Findings of fact. 
The findings and recitations set out in the preamble of this article are found to be true and correct, and that they are hereby adopted by the City Council and made a part hereof for all purposes. 
(Ord. No. 2017-02-02, § 1, 2-21-2017)  
Sec. 10-136. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
City means the City of Pearsall, Texas. 
Consent tow means any tow of a motor vehicle initiated by the owner or operator of the vehicle or by a person who has possession, custody, or control of the vehicle. The term "consent tow" does not include a tow of a motor vehicle initiated by a police officer investigation a traffic accident or a traffic incident that involves the vehicle, or who arrests the operator of the vehicle for an alleged offense and is required by law to take the person into custody. 
Motor vehicle means every vehicle that is self-propelled. 
Non-consent tow means any tow of a vehicle that is not initiated by the owner or operator of the vehicle or by a person who has possession, custody or control of the vehicle. The term "non-consent tow" includes a tow of a motor vehicle initiated by a police officer. 
Owner means any person who holds the legal title of a motor vehicle or who has the legal right of possession thereof, or the legal rights of said vehicle. 
Permit holder means any person who holds a current, valid permit to provide non-consent towing services within the City meeting the requirements of section 10-142. 
Permitted wrecker list means the list of permitted companies prepared and used as provided in this article. 
Primary impound lot means any impound towing and storage facility located in the City limits, which is designated by the City as the primary impound towing and storage facility. 
Street means any public street, alley, public place, square or highway within the corporate limits of the City. 
Tow truck/wrecker means a motor vehicle used for the purpose of towing or removing disable or wrecked vehicles. 
Towing/wrecker company means the business of towing or removing disable or wrecked vehicles off the streets of the City an engaging in providing towing services to the general public. 
Vehicle means every device in or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a public highway, except devices moved only by human power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks, and shall include trailers and semi-trailers. 
Wrecker selection form means the form for selection of wrecker companies, prepared and used as provided in section 10-141. 
(Ord. No. 2017-02-02, § 2, 2-21-2017)  
Sec. 10-137. - Permitted wrecker list. 
The City Police Department shall establish and maintain a permitted wrecker list for each wrecker service permitted to provide non-consent towing or collision response towing, in response to a request for services from a police officer pursuant to the procedures set forth herein. Said permitted wrecker list shall be provided to the County's Sheriff's Office for dispatch purposes. The permitted wrecker list shall consist solely of permit holders holding a valid, current permit required by this article and who are in compliance with the terms of holding such permit at the time of the request for towing services. Said list shall contain names, in alphabetical order, of all permit holders qualified to be on said list. No towing or wrecker company may be listed more than once on the permitted wrecker list. 
(Ord. No. 2017-02-02, § 3, 2-21-2017)  
Sec. 10-138. - Procedure for contacting wrecker service. 
(a)  When a police officer investigating an accident determines that any vehicle which has been involved in a collision or accident upon a public street is unable to proceed safely under its own power or when the owner thereof is physically unable to drive such vehicle, such officer shall: 
(1)  If the owner of the vehicle is capable of requesting a specific wrecker service, the police officer or dispatcher shall contact that service for consent tows. 
(2)  If the requested towing or wrecker company does not have a wrecker available to move the vehicle, or the police officer/dispatcher is unable to contact the requested company, the owner shall be notified. 
(3)  In the event the owner is unable or unwilling to designate another towing or wrecker company, the requested company is unable to be contacted, or the company cannot respond in a timely manner and it is necessary to remove the vehicle for public safety reasons or to protect said vehicle in the event the owner is incapacitated, the next permit holder in line on the permitted wrecker list will be called to tow the vehicle to the location designated by the owner, provided that if the owner does not specify a designation to which the vehicle will be removed, the vehicle may be removed to the primary impound lot designated by the City. 
(b)  In the event the owner of a vehicle involved in an accident or collision is physically unable to designate the towing or wrecker company desired, or refuses to designate a towing or wrecker company or if a person is arrested for an alleged offense and the officer is required by law to take the person into custody, the police officer shall call the next permit holder in line on the permitted wrecker rotation list to tow the disabled vehicle and remove same from City streets. 
(c)  If a vehicle is operated by a person a police officer arrests for an alleged offense and the officer is required by law to take the person into custody, the officer may proceed under subsection (b) of this section. 
(d)  Failure of any permit holder selected from the permitted wrecker list to deliver a licensed wrecker from the permit holder's wrecker company, or a company who contracts with the company on the permitted wrecker list, of the type required to the scene within 20 minutes of notification without justification acceptable to the police officer shall cause the permit holder to forfeit that call. If selection of the entity occurred under subsection (a)(3) of this section, the police officer may proceed as he would under subsection (b) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2017-02-02, § 4, 2-21-2017)  
Sec. 10-139. - Authority of police officer at scene of disabled vehicle. 
The officer in charge at the collision scene or at the location of a disabled vehicle on a public roadway may, if the safety of the public requires it or if otherwise authorized under V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 545.30, as amended, take steps as needed to ensure public safety, including, but not limited to: 
(1)  Directing that any vehicle be taken to the primary impound lot owned or used by the City; 
(2)  Directing that any vehicle be delivered to a specific location authorized by V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 545.305, as amended; or 
(3)  Excluding any person from the investigation area who in the opinion of the officer may hinder an investigation. 
(Ord. No. 2017-02-02, § 5, 2-21-2017)  
Sec. 10-140. - Police officer, City employees or volunteer firefighters not permitted to recommend wrecker. 
No police officer, City employee or volunteer firefighter investigating or present at the scene of any accident on a public street shall recommend to any person the name of any particular person or business engaged in the towing or wrecker service or repair business. 
(Ord. No. 2017-02-02, § 6, 2-21-2017)  
Sec. 10-141. - Application for permit and fees. 
Every company approved by the City Council to provide non-consent towing services within the City and desiring to be placed on the permitted wrecker list shall make application in writing, on a form provided for that purpose, to the Chief of Police. Such application shall contain the name, address, telephone number, the number and types of wrecker equipment operated and the owner of the business. Every application when filed shall be sworn to by the applicant and accompanied by a fee. Said fees are non-refundable. The applicant shall file as an attachment to the application the following: 
(1)  A certificate or policy of public liability and property damage insurance meeting the requirements of section 10-142(6)a and b. 
(2)  A certificate or policy of public liability and property damage insurance meeting the requirements of section 10-142(6)a and b. 
(3)  Cargo insurance or a surety bond to cover damage to a towed vehicle during a hookup or towing, in an amount satisfying the requirements of section 10-142(6)c. 
(Ord. No. 2017-02-02, § 7, 2-21-2017)  
Sec. 10-142. - Permit requirements. 
The Chief of Police shall issue permits for towing or wrecker companies approved by the City Council eligible to provide towing at the request of the City, to be placed on the permitted wrecker list, and to provide non-consent towing within the City. The number of said towing or wrecker companies shall be unlimited complying with the provisions of this article. Said applications shall be submitted to the City Council for review and approval on an annual basis. No such permit shall be issued unless the applicant meets each of the following requirements: 
(1)  The applicant maintains at least two wreckers flat-bed/roll back tow trucks with wheel-lift capability to tow two vehicles at one time. Said vehicles shall be domiciled on location of the City-approved storage facility. 
(2)  The applicant maintains 24-hour wrecker service and has a telephone number that is answered 24 hours a day, seven days a week. The use of an independent answering service shall not be permitted. 
(3)  The applicant owns, leases or otherwise lawfully possesses and operates a garage or storage facility within three miles of the City limits and obtains a storage facility license according to the Vehicle Storage Act, provided, however, for all non-consent tows, all vehicles shall be impounded in the City-approved primary storage facility. 
(4)  A permanent six-foot fence, the gate to which shall be locked at all times when the permit holder, an agent or an employee, is not at the storage facility. The storage area shall be maintained in such a manner that it does not constitute a health hazard and is screened from the ordinary public view. The wrecker company shall have capabilities for auxiliary storage inside a locked building that is at least 1,800 square feet in size for day-to-day business and to be able to preserve property for evidence. A storage lot with a minimum of 10,000 square feet shall be located at the same location. A six-foot fence with barbed wire shall enclose said storage lot. The City shall approve appropriate fencing for the location, whether it should be a six-foot chain-link/barbed wire fence, a six-foot chain-link/barbed wire with slats, or a six-foot steel privacy fence with barbed wire. Any impounded vehicle with leaking fluid, or that is incapable of being totally secured, shall be stored in the building on concrete at no extra cost, to avoid any environmental damage or exposure, or to avoid any theft from the vehicle. 
(5)  The applicant must be capable of responding to any location in the City within 20 minutes of receiving notification. Weather conditions will be considered regarding the response time. 
(6)  The applicant procures and keeps in full force and effect, a policy of public liability and property damage insurance issued by a casualty insurance company authorized to do business in the State and in the standard form approved by the Board of Insurance Commissioners of the State with the insured provision of said policies including the City as an insured, and the coverage provision insuring the public from any loss or damage that may arise to any person or property by reason of the operation of a wrecker of such company and providing that the amount of recovery on each wrecker shall be in limits of no less that the following sums: 
a.  For Category A wrecker, together with the towed vehicle, having a gross vehicle weight, registered weight or actual weight of 26,000 pounds or less, $300,000.00 combined single limit for bodily injuries to or death of all persons injured or killed in any accident, and loss or damage in any one accident to the property of others; 
b.  For Category B wrecker, together with the towed vehicle, having a gross vehicle weight, registered weight or actual weight of exceeding 26,000, $500,000.00 combined single limit for bodily injuries to or death of all persons injured or killed in any accident, and loss or damage in any one accident to the property of others; 
c.  For injury to or destruction of property in any one accident, $50,000.00. 
(7)  The applicant procures and keeps in full force and effect a policy of cargo insurance to cover damage to on-hook cargo or a towed vehicle during hookup and/or towing, in the minimum amount of $50,000.00. 
(8)  The applicant complies with the provisions of Federal and State laws and rules applicable to tow vehicles and towing or wrecker company operations, as amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 2017-02-02, § 8, 2-21-2017)  
Sec. 10-143. - Inspection of storage facilities. 
The Chief of Police shall inspect any storage facilities and enclosures and his approval thereof must be first obtained before it can be used for storing consent tow vehicles therein. The Chief of Police shall also inspect the primary impound facility within the City used for all non-consent tows prior to said designation as the primary impound facility. 
(Ord. No. 2017-02-02, § 9, 2-21-2017)  
Sec. 10-144. - Issuance of permit. 
Upon determining compliance with the provisions and requirements of this article, and with City Council approval, the Chief of Police shall issue a permit as follows: 
(1)  A permit for the towing or wrecker company to be eligible to provide towing at the request of the City, to be placed on the permitted wrecker list, and to provide non-consent towing within the City. The permit shall include its date of issuance and date of expiration. A permit holder may operate more than two wreckers under the permit. 
(2)  A license is required for a wrecker to be eligible to provide towing at the request of the City, to be placed on the permitted wrecker list and to provide non-consent towing within the City. The license shall include, on its face, the date of its issuance and its expiration date and shall be in a form that can be easily stored in the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 2017-02-02, § 10, 2-21-2017)  
Sec. 10-145. - Display of permit. 
(a)  A permit issued pursuant to this article shall be prominently displayed at the permit holder's place of business. 
(b)  A permit shall be available in each vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 2017-02-02, § 11, 2-21-2017)  
Sec. 10-146. - Obligations of permit holder. 
A permit holder shall comply with each of the following obligations: 
(1)  A permit holder shall remove all wreckage and debris from a collision scene, except for vehicle cargo or hazardous waste as part of the services rendered in response to a call from the City or a call resulting from being on the permitted wrecker list. 
(2)  A permit holder shall exercise reasonable care and caution to avoid destruction or contamination of any item of which the permit holder has been informed by the police officer may be of evidentiary value. 
(3)  A permit holder shall perform services pursuant to this article in a professional manner and in compliance with all applicable local, state and federal laws and regulations. 
(4)  A permit holder shall be available to release the vehicles on which there are no investigative holds seven days a week, 24 hours a day, with one-hour notice, provided, however, that the primary impound yard is authorized to require proof of insurance prior to the release of any vehicle when the vehicle was a non-consent tow authorized by the City Police Department. When a vehicle is under investigative hold by the Police Department, the police officer in charge of the investigation shall inform the permit holder or its agent that the vehicle is under investigative hold, however, under no circumstances shall any vehicle be placed on investigative hold without approval of the Police Chief or the Department Head Investigator. The permit holder shall obtain the name of the officer charged with authorizing the release of any vehicle that has been impounded under the direction of the Police Department and shall hold such vehicle until its release is authorized by said officer, the Police Chief or the Department Head Investigator. 
(Ord. No. 2017-02-02, § 12, 2-21-2017)  
Sec. 10-147. - Revocation of permits. 
Any of the permits as defined herein may be revoked and the wrecker may be removed from the permitted wrecker list for violation of any provision of this article with seven days' written notice and opportunity to appeal to the City Administrator. The City Administrator's decision shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 2017-02-02, § 13, 2-21-2017)  
Sec. 10-148. - Renewal of permit; annual fees. 
All permits shall be renewed during the month of December each year. A newly issued permit shall be valid until December 31 of each year of its issuance and may be renewed at any time during the month of December. A permit may be renewed upon payment of the annual fee and the execution of a verified statement that the information on the original application form continues to be valid. If any of said information is no longer valid, the permit holder must present the corrected information at the time of renewal of the permit. 
(Ord. No. 2017-02-02, § 14, 2-21-2017)  
Sec. 10-149. - Operation without permit prohibited. 
No person shall tow a vehicle without the consent of the owner or operate a wrecker on the public streets of the City in response to a request for wrecker services from the City, or in response to a notice resulting from being on the permitted wrecker list, unless a valid permit for such wrecker company has been issued. 
(Ord. No. 2017-02-02, § 15, 2-21-2017)  
Sec. 10-150. - Exceptions. 
(a)  Wrecker permits shall not be required by any person, wrecker business, wrecker company or motor vehicles used: 
(1)  To tow a vehicle at the request of any owner that is not the City; 
(2)  To tow a vehicle at owner's direction from any place in the City to a shop for repairs or services; or 
(3)  To tow any vehicle upon the request of the owner of the vehicle or person lawfully in control of such vehicle, provided the owner is not the City and the person is not exercising control over such vehicle in the course of duties and employment with the City. 
(b)  Nothing herein shall require a towing or wrecker company to secure a permit to perform consent tows in the City. 
(Ord. No. 2017-02-02, § 16, 2-21-2017)  
Sec. 10-151. - Response to collision only upon request. 
No person shall drive or cause to be driven a wrecker to or near the scene of a collision on a street in the City unless such person has been called by the Police Department (or the on-the-scene officer in charge) or by a party involved in the collision; unless it is necessary to prevent bodily injury or death to any person involved in a collision. 
(Ord. No. 2017-02-02, § 17, 2-21-2017)  
Sec. 10-152. - Notification of impoundment. 
Each towing or wrecker company shall notify the operator or owner of any disabled or wrecked vehicle of the location of the facility to be used by the permitted wrecker service, or the location of the primary impound facility for non-consent tows. 
(Ord. No. 2017-02-02, § 18, 2-21-2017)  
Sec. 10-153. - Location of traffic accidents. 
No person shall drive a wrecker or other motor vehicle used in the business of towing motor vehicles to the scene of a traffic accident on the streets of the City unless such person has been called to the scene by the Police Department or the owner of a motor vehicle involved in the accident, unless it is necessary to prevent death or bodily injury to any person involved in the accident. 
(Ord. No. 2017-02-02, § 19, 2-21-2017)  
Sec. 10-154. - Solicitation at accident scene. 
No person shall solicit business at the scene of any traffic accident or collision on a public street. Proof of the presence of any person engaged in the towing for hire or wrecker business, or the presence of any wrecker or motor vehicle owned or operated by any person engaged in the towing for hire or wrecker business at or near the scene of an accident on any public street in the City, within one hour after the happening of such accident shall, absent such person or wrecker being called to the scene of such accident by the Police Department or owner of a vehicle involved in the accident, shall be evidence of a solicitation in violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2017-02-02, § 20, 2-21-2017)  
Sec. 10-155. - Interpretation and construction. 
This article does not require any person, repair or towing company to obtain any permit or to limit any fees charged, save and except such persons, businesses and companies that voluntarily obtain a permit and meet the standards herein provided in order to receive requests from the City for towing vehicles and/or placement on the permitted wrecker list. 
(Ord. No. 2017-02-02, § 23, 2-21-2017)  
Sec. 10-156. - Penalty. 
Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction in the municipal court, shall be punished by a fine not to exceed the sum of $500.00 for each offense; and each and every day such violation shall continue shall be deemed to constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 2017-02-02, § 24, 2-21-2017)  
Sec. 10-157. - Ordinance cumulative. 
This article shall be cumulative of all laws of the State and the United States governing the subject matter of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2017-02-02, § 22, 2-21-2017)  
Chapter 12 - COURTS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Municipal courts, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 29.001 et seq. 
 
Sec. 12-1. - Creation. 
There is hereby created and established a court known as the Municipal Court of the City of Pearsall, Texas. 
(Ord. of 7-12-1974, § 1)  
Sec. 12-2. - Location; officers. 
(a)  Municipal Courts. The Municipal Court shall hold regular Court sessions in the City Hall, or at such other location as the Municipal Judge may desire within the corporate limits of the City. 
(b)  Municipal Judge. The Municipal Judge shall be appointed by the City Council and shall serve the same term of office as the Mayor and shall serve at the pleasure of the City Council. He shall have such powers and duties as provided by the laws of the State. He shall receive a salary as may be fixed by the City Council from time to time. 
(c)  Court Clerk. The City Manager shall appoint the Clerk of the Municipal Court, and the deputy clerks. The Clerk and his deputy clerks shall have the power to administer oaths and affidavits, make certificates, affix the seal of the City thereto, and generally do and perform any and all acts usual and necessary by Clerks of Municipal Courts in issuing process of said Courts and conducting the business thereof. 
(d)  Absence of Municipal Judge. In the case of disability or absence of the Judge of the Municipal Court, the City Council shall appoint a Municipal Judge to sit in his place. 
(Ord. of 7-12-1974, § 3)  
Sec. 12-3. - Municipal Court practice and procedure. 
(a)  Sessions of Court. Sessions of Court shall be held on any day except Saturday or Sunday, on a weekly, bimonthly or monthly basis depending on the cases filed in the Court and other matters requiring the attention of the Court. Court sessions may be held either in the morning or in the afternoon, or at such times and places as desired by the Municipal Judge. 
(b)  Clerk of the Court. The Clerk of the Municipal Court shall keep all records, attend all Court sessions, administer oaths, take affidavits, prepare complaints, issue warrants, subpoenas, and any other process required by the Municipal Judge, however, the Municipal Judge may also administer oaths, take affidavits, prepare complaints, issue warrants, subpoenas, and any other process of the Courts. 
(c)  Procedure in Court on traffic offense. The Municipal Judge shall be the only authorized person to dismiss a case. When a person charged with an offense (an actor) is, for any reason, unable to attend court in person and applies to the arresting officer or some employee of the City to have his case dismissed, such officer or other person shall be required to submit the question of dismissal to the Court for determination. 
(d)  Payment of fine; procedure. Any person charged with an offense may pay his fine at the City Hall prior to the date of trial by presenting his ticket and the amount in cash to the City Hall cashier. The cashier shall so notify the Clerk of the Court of such payment so that proper notations can be made in the docket book of the Court. The Texas Code of Criminal Procedure shall be followed in all matters and in the event of any conflict between this chapter and the Texas Code of Criminal Procedure. 
(e)  Issuance of process. All process issued by the Municipal Court shall be executed by the police officers of the City. All process issued by the Court to be executed beyond the corporate limits of the City shall be served by the Police Officer in conjunction with some other law enforcement officer, and mileage fees may be allowed for such officers in executing said process, similar to the fees paid in Justice courts, and provisions of law governing taxable costs in misdemeanor cases in Justice courts shall, in all instances, govern in Municipal Court. 
(f)  Actor required to sign bond or cash receipt. An actor will be required to sign the cash bond prescribed by the Court when posting cash for his appearance, and the cash bond receipt shall be also signed in the amount stated in the cash bond. 
(g)  Forfeiture of bond. When an actor has made a cash bond and fails to appear at the time the case is set for trial, his name shall be called, and if he or his representative fails to appear, the cash bond shall be forfeited by the Municipal Judge by making a notation on the docket after hearing the evidence and satisfying himself that the forfeiture of the cash bond is sufficient punishment for the offense for which the bond was given and the fact that there is no need for a capias warrant to be issued for said actor's rearrest. 
(h)  Plea on failure to appear. The cash bond receipts shall be prepared in such a manner so that the actor may enter a plea of nolo contendere on failure to appear at the time set in the bond. 
(i)  Issuance of capias warrants. Forfeiture of cash bonds shall be considered as a fine except in instances where it appears to the Municipal Judge, after hearing evidence, that forfeiture of the bond is insufficient punishment, and then the Judge shall order a capias warrant for the actor's rearrest and trial. 
(j)  Writs, issuance of. All writs issued out of the Municipal Court shall be in the name of the Municipal Court. 
(k)  Jurors. All jurors shall be residents of the City and shall possess the same qualifications as jurors in the State courts. Jurors shall be selected from the voter registration lists of the precincts located within the City and shall be paid the statutory jury fee only in the event that they serve on a jury. 
(l)  Fines; failure to pay. Any person who, upon conviction, shall fail or neglect to pay any fine or costs imposed under any law or ordinance for any breach or violation of the same, shall be committed to County jail until such fines and costs have been fully paid or satisfied at the rate of $50.00 per day. The Municipal Judge may allow persons to pay their fine in installments, in lieu of being sent to jail, if such installment agreements are in writing and filed with the Clerk of the Court. 
(m)  Schedule of fines . There shall be a schedule of fines, approved by the City Council, for certain offenses, which may be printed on the reverse side of the copy of the traffic summons that is given to the actor. The actor shall pay the fine listed on said schedule, which includes the appropriate Court costs and fees as per the legislative laws and allotted by the Comptroller of Public Accounts. No fine shall be accepted that is not listed on the schedule, unless set by the Municipal Judge in open Court. The following schedule of fines is hereby adopted by the City Council. Fines are classified as class C misdemeanors, which carry a maximum fine not to exceed $500.00. All fines are subject to State court costs as periodically amended.

No case shall be disposed of, except as provided in subsection (m)(5) of this section, after an appearance has been made in open Court. 
(Ord. of 7-12-1974, § 4; Ord. of 4-10-1996, §§ 2—6; Ord. of 3-11-2004, § 1)  
Sec. 12-4. - Information. 
The form of the information shall be as established by the City Council, from time to time. 
(Ord. of 4-10-1996, § 7)  
Sec. 12-5. - Court Technology Fund. 
(a)  Establishment of Municipal Court Technology Fund. 
(1)  There is hereby created and established a Municipal Court Technology Fund, hereinafter known as the Fund, pursuant to article 102.0172 of the Texas Code of Criminal Procedure. 
(2)  The Fund may be maintained in a City interest-bearing account and may be maintained in the City's General Revenue account. 
(b)  Establishment of amount of the fee and assessment and collection. 
(1)  The fee shall be assessed against and collected from the Defendant upon conviction for a misdemeanor offense in the Municipal Court as a cost of court. A Defendant is considered convicted if: 
a.  Judgment, sentence, or both are imposed on the person; 
b.  The person is placed on deferred disposition, including deferred adjudication and community supervision; or 
c.  The Court defers final disposition or imposition of the judgment and sentence. 
(2)  The fee shall be collected on conviction for an offense committed on or after the effective date of adoption of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived. 
(3)  The Clerk of the Court shall collect the fee and pay the fee to the Financial Director of the City, who shall deposit the fee into the Municipal Court Technology Fund. 
(c)  Designated use of the Fund and administration. 
(1)  The Fund shall be used only for the purpose of financing the purchase of or to maintain technology enhancements for the Municipal Court. Technology enhancements shall include any and all items described in article 102.0172 of the Texas Code of Criminal Procedure. 
(2)  The Fund shall be administered by the City's Finance Director under the direction of the City Manager and the City Council. 
(d)  Administration of Fund. The purpose for the use of any monies remaining in the Fund shall continue to be used and administered as required by this section and for that purpose this section remains in effect. 
(Ord. No. 2008-09-043, §§ 1—3, 7, 9-9-2008)  
Sec. 12-6. - Municipal Court Building Security Fund. 
(a)  There is hereby created and established a Municipal Court Building Security Fund (the "Fund") pursuant to Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 102.017. 
(b)  The Municipal Court of the City (the "Municipal Court") is hereby authorized and required to assess a municipal court building security fee (the "fee") against all defendants convicted of a misdemeanor offense by the Municipal Court. Each misdemeanor conviction shall be subject to a separate assessment of the fee. 
(c)  A person is considered to have been convicted in a case if: 
(1)  Judgment, sentence, or both are imposed on the person; 
(2)  The person is placed on deferred disposition; or 
(3)  The court defers final disposition or imposition of the judgment and sentence. 
(d)  The fee shall be collected on convictions for offenses committed on or after the ordinance from which this section is derived is adopted. 
(e)  The Municipal Court Clerk is hereby authorized and required to collect the fee and to pay same to the treasury of the City. All fees so collected and paid over to the treasury of the City shall be segregated in the Fund. 
(f)  The Fund shall be used only for the purpose of financing the purchase of security devices and/or services for the building or buildings housing the Municipal Court. The term "security devices and/or services" shall include any and all items described in Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 102.017(d-1). 
(g)  The Fund shall be administered by or under the direction of the City Council. 
(h)  Fee may only be assessed and collected on offenses occurring on or after August 28, 1995. The fee may not be assessed or collected retroactively if the Fund is established at a later date than August 28, 1995. 
(Ord. No. 2015-10-02, § 1, 10-27-2015)  
Chapter 14 - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AND SERVICES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Texas Disaster Act of 1975, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 418.001 et seq.; local emergency management, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 418.101 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 14-1—14-18. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - EMERGENCY PREPAREDNESS 
 
Sec. 14-19. - Organization. 
There exists the Office of Emergency Management Director of the City which shall be held by the Mayor in accordance with State law. 
(1)  An Emergency Management Coordinator may be appointed by and serve at the pleasure of the Director. 
(2)  The Director shall be responsible for a program of comprehensive emergency management within the City and for carrying out the duties and responsibilities set forth in this article. He may delegate authority for execution of these duties to the Coordinator, but ultimate responsibility for such execution shall remain with the Director. 
(3)  The operational Emergency Management Organization of the City shall consist of the officers and employees of the Emergency Management Plan, as well as organized volunteer groups. The functions and duties of this Organization shall be distributed among such officers and employees in accordance with the terms of the Emergency Management Plan. 
(Ord. of 3-14-1990, § 1)  
Sec. 14-20. - Emergency Management Director; powers and duties. 
The duties and responsibilities of the Emergency Management Director shall include the following: 
(1)  Conduct an ongoing survey of actual or potential hazards which threaten life and property within the City and an ongoing program of identifying and requiring or recommending the implementation of measures which would tend to prevent the occurrence or reduce the impact of such hazards if a disaster did occur. 
(2)  Supervision of the development and approval of an Emergency Management Plan for the City, and shall recommend for adoption by the City Council all mutual aid arrangements deemed necessary for the implementation of such Plan. 
(3)  Authority to declare local state of disaster. The declaration may not be continued or renewed for a period in excess of seven days except by or with the consent of the City Council. Any order or proclamation declaring, continuing, or terminating a local state of disaster shall be given prompt and general publicity and shall be filed promptly with the City Manager. 
(4)  Issuance of necessary proclamations, regulations or directives which are necessary for carrying out the purposes of this article. Such proclamations, regulations, or directives shall be disseminated promptly by means calculated to bring its contents to the attention of the general public and, unless circumstances attendant on the disaster prevent or impede, promptly filed with the City Manager. 
(5)  Direction and control of the operations of the Emergency Management Organization as well as the training of Emergency Management personnel. 
(6)  Determination of all questions of authority and responsibility that may arise within the Emergency Management Organization. 
(7)  Maintenance of liaison with other municipal, county, district, state, regional or federal Emergency Management Organizations. 
(8)  Marshaling of all necessary personnel, equipment or supplies from any department of the City to aid in the carrying out of the provisions of the Emergency Management Plan. 
(9)  Supervision of the drafting and execution of mutual aid agreements, in cooperation with the representatives of the State and of other local political subdivisions of the State, and the drafting and execution, if deemed desirable, of an agreement with the County in which said City is located and with other municipalities within the County, for the County, for the Countywide coordination of emergency management efforts. 
(10)  Supervision of, and final authorization for, the procurement of all necessary supplies and equipment, including acceptance of private contributions which may be offered for the purpose of improving emergency management within the City. 
(11)  Authorizing of agreements, after approval by the City Attorney, for use of private property for public shelter and other purposes. 
(12)  Survey of the availability of existing personnel, equipment, supplies and services which could be used during a disaster, as provided for herein. 
(13)  Other requirements as specified in Texas Disaster Act 1975 (V.T.C.A., Government Code § 418.001 et seq.). 
(Ord. of 3-14-1990, § 2)  
Sec. 14-21. - Emergency Management Plan. 
A comprehensive Emergency Management Plan shall be developed and maintained in a current state. The plan shall set forth the form of the organization, establish and designate division and functions, assign responsibilities, tasks, duties, and powers and designate officers and employees to carry out the provisions of this article. As provided by State law, the Plan shall follow the standards and criteria established by the State Division of Emergency Management. Insofar as possible, the form of organization, titles and terminology shall conform to the recommendations of the State Division of Emergency Management. When approved, it shall be the duty of all departments and agencies to perform the functions assigned by the Plan and to maintain their portion of the Plan in a current state of readiness at all times. The Emergency Management Plan shall be considered supplementary to this article and have the effect of law during the time of a disaster. 
(Ord. of 3-14-1990, § 3)  
Sec. 14-22. - Interjurisdictional program. 
The Mayor is hereby authorized to join with the County Judge and the mayors of the other cities in said County in the formation of an Emergency Management Council for the County and shall have the authority to cooperate in the preparation of a Joint Emergency Management Plan and in the appointment of a Joint Emergency Management Coordinator, as well as all powers necessary to participate in a Countywide program of emergency management insofar as said program may affect the City. 
(Ord. of 3-14-1990, § 4)  
Sec. 14-23. - Override. 
At all times when the orders, rules, and regulations made and promulgated pursuant to this article shall be in effect, they shall supersede and override all existing ordinances, orders, rules and regulations insofar as the latter may be inconsistent therewith. 
(Ord. of 3-14-1990, § 5)  
Sec. 14-24. - Liability. 
This article is an exercise by the City of its governmental functions for the protection of the public peace, health and safety and neither the City, the agents and representatives of said City, nor any individual, receiver, firm, partnership, corporation, association, or trustee, nor any of the agents thereof, in good faith carrying out, complying with or attempting to comply with, any order, rule or regulation promulgated pursuant to the provisions of this article shall be liable for any damage sustained to persons as the result of said activity. Any person owning or controlling real estate or other premises who voluntarily and without compensation grants to the City a license of privilege, or otherwise permits the City to inspect, designate and use the whole or any part of such real estate or premises for the purpose of sheltering persons during an actual, impending or practice enemy attack or natural or manmade disaster shall, together with his successors in interest, if any, not be civilly liable for the death of, or injury to, any person on or about such real estate or premises under such license privilege or other permission or for loss of, or damage to, the property of such person. 
(Ord. of 3-14-1990, § 6)  
Sec. 14-25. - Commitment of funds. 
No person shall have the right to expend any public funds of the City in carrying out any emergency management activity authorized by this article without prior approval by the City Council, nor shall any person have any right to bind the City by contract, agreement or otherwise without prior and specific approval of the City Council unless during a declared disaster. During a declared disaster, the Mayor may expend and/or commit public funds of the City when deemed prudent and necessary for the protection of health, life, or property. 
(Ord. of 3-14-1990, § 7)  
Sec. 14-26. - Offenses; penalties. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person willfully to obstruct, hinder, or delay any member of the Emergency Management Organization in the enforcement of any rule or regulation issued pursuant to this article, or to do any act forbidden by any rule or regulation issued pursuant to the authority contained in this article. 
(b)  It shall likewise be unlawful for any person to wear, carry or display any emblem, insignia or any other means of identification as a member of the Emergency Management Organization of the City, unless authority to do so has been granted to such person by the proper officials. 
(c)  Any unauthorized person who shall operate a siren or other device so as to simulate a warning signal, or the termination of a warning, shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this article and shall be subject to the penalties imposed by the general provisions in section 1-13. 
(Ord. of 3-14-1990, § 8)  
Secs. 14-27—14-55. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - SHELTER MANAGERS 
 
Sec. 14-56. - Duties and responsibilities. 
In case of a national emergency, public shelter managers duly appointed by the Emergency Management Director shall open public shelters, take charge of all stocks of food, water, and other supplies stored in said shelter, admit the public according to the City's shelter use plan and take whatever control measures are necessary for the protection and safety of the occupants. 
(Ord. of 1-14-1981, § 1)  
Sec. 14-57. - Use of reasonable restraint. 
Shelter managers are authorized to use reasonable restraint against those who refuse to cooperate with the routine of shelter living under emergency conditions. Refusal to carry out the order of the shelter manager and his appointed staff shall be deemed a misdemeanor punishable according to the general penalties described in section 1-13. 
(Ord. of 1-14-1981, § 2)  
Secs. 14-58—14-87. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - AMBULANCES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Emergency Health Care Act, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 773.001 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 14-88. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Advanced life support means emergency prehospital care provided by a certified, emergency medical technician-intermediate or an emergency medical technician-paramedic using invasive medical acts under the medical supervision and control of a licensed physician. 
Ambulance means any motor vehicle used, designed, redesigned or constructed, and equipped for the transportation of sick or injured persons. 
Basic emergency medical technician means an individual who has successfully completed the State Department of Health's Basic Emergency Medical Technician course and is currently certified. 
Basic life support means emergency prehospital care provided by a certified prehospital care provider using noninvasive medical acts. The provision of basic life support may be under the medical supervision and control of a licensed physician. 
Basic life support emergency medical services vehicle means a vehicle that is designed for transporting the sick or injured and that has sufficient equipment and supplies for providing basic life support, and is certified by the State Department of Health as such. 
Credentialed personnel means an individual who holds a valid certification from the State that allows them to practice at any of the following levels: Medical Responder, Emergency Care Attendant (ECA); Emergency Medical Technician Basic (EMT-B); EMT-Intermediate (EMT-I); EMT-Paramedic (EMT-P); Licensed Paramedic (LP) as defined in the State General Statutes and any rules promulgated pursuant thereto by the State Department of State Health Services. 
Emergency means any circumstance that calls for an immediate action and which the element of time in transporting the sick, wounded or injured for medical treatment is essential to the health or life of any person. Such circumstances include, but are not limited to, general accidents, traffic accidents and acts of violence resulting in personal injury, and sudden illness. 
Emergency ambulance means any ambulance responding to an emergency call using warning lights or horn or sirens. 
Emergency call means any request for an ambulance that is made by telephone or other means of communication in circumstances which are or have been represented to be an emergency requiring emergency prehospital care or transport to a medical facility. 
Emergency care attendant means an individual who has successfully completed the State Department of Health's emergency care attendant course and is currently certified. 
Emergency medical service personnel means an emergency care attendant, basic emergency medical technician, specially skilled emergency medical technician, or a paramedic emergency medical technician. 
Emergency prehospital care means care provided to the sick or injured either on the scene or during emergency transport to a medical facility, or both. 
Emergency transfer means the immediate transportation of a patient in an ambulance requiring any or all of the following: 
(1)  Monitoring of EKG; 
(2)  Administration of intravenous fluids or medications; and 
(3)  Airway maintenance. 
Emergency transfer request means a request made by a physician directly or through a registered nurse for an emergency transfer. 
EMS means the Emergency Medical Service Division of Frio County, Texas and other providers serving in an emergency capacity. 
Medical facility means any building or place of business established for the purpose of examination or treatment by a licensed physician of individuals who are sick or injured. 
Nonemergency transportation services means the operation of an ambulance for any purpose other than transporting emergency patients. 
Nurse/paramedic means an individual who is a paramedic and, in addition, holds a State license as a registered nurse. 
Paramedic emergency medical technician means an individual who has successfully completed the basic emergency medical technician requirements and an additional minimum of 400 hours of training approved by the State Department of Health and who is certified by the State Department of Health as minimally proficient to provide emergency prehospital care by providing advanced life support that includes initiation under medical supervision of intravenous therapy, endotracheal or esophageal intubation or both, electrical cardiac defibrillation or cardioversion, drag therapy and other invasive procedures. 
(Ord. No. 2007-04-026, § 5-1(art. I), 4-10-2007)  
Sec. 14-89. - Use of emergency and transfer service. 
(a)  All calls for emergency ambulance service within the City limits shall be directed to and responded to solely by the County Emergency Medical Service unless directed otherwise in accordance with subsection (b) of this section. This article shall not apply to emergency or transfer services operated by other political subdivisions or governmental agencies. 
(b)  When there exists in the City a licensed and franchised private ambulance service then, in that event, nonemergency transfer calls and related nonemergency services shall be responded to by said City franchise holder under the rules and regulations of this article and of the local franchise. 
(Ord. No. 2007-04-026, § 5-2(art. I), 4-10-2007)  
Sec. 14-90. - Standards of service. 
(a)  Standards for credentialed personnel shall be as developed by the State Department of State Health Services and the County Emergency Medical Services System, and shall be applied to the same as if incorporated herein by reference. 
(b)  Standards for vehicles and equipment shall be as developed by the State Department of State Health Services and the County Emergency Medical Services System, and shall be applied to the same as if incorporated herein by reference. 
(Ord. No. 2007-04-026, § 5-3(art. I), 4-10-2007)  
Sec. 14-91. - Communications and dispatch requirements. 
(a)  Each ambulance shall be equipped with UHF and VHF two-way communications compatible with those used by County Emergency Services. The County shall assign frequencies and record movements of the applicant's ambulances. 
(b)  Each ambulance shall be required to render assistance to the County Emergency Medical Services (EMS) in the case of a major catastrophe or emergency or when County EMS units are unavailable to respond to emergency calls. 
(c)  Assigned emergency calls will have priority over scheduled nonemergency calls. 
(d)  When County EMS units are dispatched to an emergency scene and the franchisee's ambulance is available, closer to the scene, that ambulance is authorized to respond to the scene and provide assistance prior to County EMS if: 
(1)  The County Dispatch Center is notified; and 
(2)  The franchisee's ambulance is dispatched. 
(e)  If on arrival, it is found that the situation is not an emergency, the patient may be transported by the franchisee's ambulance. The County EMS will continue to the scene if there is any question of the patient's actual condition. The patient's medical needs will be given priority. When necessary, the patient will be released to the County EMS for treatment and transport. 
(f)  Any emergency call received at a base or office of the franchisee will be immediately referred to County Dispatch and the appropriate response will be determined. 
(Ord. No. 2007-04-026, § 5-3(art. I), 4-10-2007)  
Secs. 14-92—14-110. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICE 
 
Sec. 14-111. - Private service regulation. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to furnish, operate, advertise or otherwise engage or profess to be engaged in the operation of an emergency ambulance upon the streets of the City unless said person is: 
(1)  A member of the County EMS unit officially on duty; 
(2)  An authorized and properly certified employee of another political subdivision or agency of the State licensed/certified to provide EMS; 
(3)  A person providing service to or from a hospital located in the City going to or from a hospital located outside of the City limits; or 
(4)  Any person meeting the requirements of the State for credentialed personnel, vehicles and equipment who responds to a request from either the City Fire Department or the County EMS unit, or any area Director of Emergency Management, to lend assistance when a major disaster or other occurrence results in emergency calls exceeding the capacity of the County. 
(Ord. No. 2007-04-026, § 5-15(art. II), 4-10-2007)  
Sec. 14-112. - Emergency medical service by the County. 
It is hereby recognized and authorized by the City that the primary EMS provider to the citizenry of Pearsall is the County Emergency Medical Service (EMS). 
(Ord. No. 2007-04-026, § 5-16(art. II), 4-10-2007)  
Sec. 14-113. - Persons to whom available. 
Emergency medical service shall be available to all persons within the City limits. The service shall also be available to persons in other portions of the County, within the City's extraterritorial jurisdiction as governed by the County. 
(Ord. No. 2007-04-026, § 5-17(art. II), 4-10-2007)  
Sec. 14-114. - Rates. 
Any person who uses the emergency medical services of the County shall pay the County for such services. Charges for emergency medical services may include, but not be limited to, standing time, standby time, oxygen, medication, and other related expenses incurred by County EMS. The County Commissioners shall, by resolution, set the rates for emergency medical services including, but not limited to, emergency calls, standing time, and emergency prehospital care provided by the County EMS. 
(Ord. No. 2007-04-026, § 5-18(art. II), 4-10-2007)  
Sec. 14-115. - Standby service. 
(a)  All requests for standby emergency medical service shall be made to the County EMS at least 24 hours in advance of the time such services will be necessary. The County EMS shall not be required to provide standby service, but may provide such services where feasible. In the event the standby vehicle is used to transport a person to a hospital or other medical facility from the standby site, each person transported shall be charged by the County EMS for an emergency call and any additional services rendered. 
(b)  The City Council shall by periodic resolution and negotiation of interlocal contract amendment with the County, adopt the rates for standby and other emergency services as determined by the County Commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 2007-04-026, § 5-19(art. II), 4-10-2007)  
Secs. 14-116—14-143. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - PRIVATE AMBULANCE SERVICE FRANCHISE 
 
Sec. 14-144. - Franchise required; cause for revocation. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to furnish, operate, advertise or otherwise engage or profess to be engaged in the operation of private ambulance service upon the streets of the City without a franchise as provided by this division. Ambulance services provided and operated by a private medical facility within the City's municipal corporate boundaries, with no separate charge for such transport, are not precluded by this section. 
(b)  A private ambulance service franchise shall be subject to City revocation if it is found that the holder of said franchise or any company, service or corporation with which the holder is affiliated, or in partnership with, is duplicating emergency service in areas in which the County EMS is providing such service, unless requested to do so by the County EMS, the City Fire Department, or any area director of emergency management. Furthermore, if a private ambulance franchise holder receives an emergency call from any source to respond either in the City or those areas under EMS contract with the County, franchisee shall immediately notify the County EMS dispatcher, and shall not respond unless requested to do so by the County dispatcher. 
(Ord. No. 2007-04-026, § 5-35(art. III), 4-10-2007)  
Sec. 14-145. - Review and public hearing. 
(a)  Copies of each application for a private ambulance service franchise shall be forwarded to the City Manager for review and recommendation to the City Council. The City Council shall hold a public hearing on an application for a private ambulance service franchise under this division at the time and place specified in the notice published in a newspaper of general circulation 15 days prior to the hearing, and no such franchise shall ever be granted until a resolution, an ordinance granting the same, has been read at two regular meetings of the City Council and passed by vote of the majority of the City Council. 
(b)  An applicant therefore shall not be granted a private ambulance franchise unless the City Council finds and determines that the public convenience will be served by the issuance thereof. In all hearings, the burden of proof shall be upon the applicant to establish clear, cogent and convincing evidence that the public convenience will be served by the granting of a private ambulance service franchise. 
(c)  In determining public convenience, the City Council shall consider the following: 
(1)  The distance from the permanent address at which the applicant proposes to operate the ambulance service to City hospitals and other area medical facilities. 
(2)  The number of ambulance vehicles which will be covered by the ambulance franchise and the hours during the day and days during the week that the applicant proposes to furnish such service. 
(3)  In the event the applicant has previously participated, or is currently participating, in a private ambulance service, evidence as to whether the applicant performed or is performing in a satisfactory manner shall be presented. 
(d)  Public convenience shall further mean that the local address from which the ambulance service is proposed to be operated, and where the ambulance will be temporarily or permanently garaged, will be within the City limits. 
(e)  Any authority hereby granted to provide private ambulance services in the City is not and shall not be deemed to be an exclusive right or permission. The City expressly reserves the right to grant similar nonexclusive franchises to other persons at any time or for any period of time. No additional franchise granted by the City shall in any way affect the obligations of the franchise hereunder 
(Ord. No. 2007-04-026, § 5-37(art. III), 4-10-2007)  
Sec. 14-146. - Prerequisite to issuance of franchise. 
No ambulance service franchise will be granted unless: 
(1)  The City Council determines that the application as required by section 28-5 is true and correct; and 
(2)  The City Council determines that the proposed operation of the ambulance service will be in compliance with all provisions of this article, and all applicable County, State and federal statutes and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 2007-04-026, § 5-38(art. III), 4-10-2007)  
Sec. 14-147. - Length of franchise. 
The length of the franchise will be for not more than two years ending on September 30 of the second year, whether or not two full years have elapsed, however, the ambulance service franchise holder will be subject to review and analysis by appropriate City staff monitoring ambulance operations on an annual basis, with results being presented to the City Manager, Fire Chief and City Council. 
(Ord. No. 2007-04-026, § 5-39(art. III), 4-10-2007)  
Sec. 14-148. - Insurance. 
No ambulance vehicle shall be operated on the public streets of the City unless the applicant provides evidence to the City Manager that he has in full force and effect a Commercial General Public Liability Insurance policy and a Comprehensive Business Vehicle Liability policy on that applicant company and the ambulance vehicle, with such insurance policies to be issued by a reputable insurance company licensed to do business in the State. Such insurance policies shall: 
(1)  Provide the franchisee with a primary public Commercial General Liability Insurance policy to a limit not less than $1,000,000.00 per occurrence and $3,000,000.00 in the aggregate for bodily injury, death, or damage to property, including loss of use thereof. In addition, the franchisee shall provide Excess or Umbrella Liability Insurance with minimum limits of $1,000,000.00 per each occurrence and $1,000,000.00 in the aggregate; 
(2)  Provide Comprehensive Business Vehicle Liability coverage for each vehicle of not less than $250,000.00 per person, or $500,000.00 per occurrence, for personal injury or death, and $100,000.00 for property damage; 
(3)  Name the City, its public officials, officers and employees as additional insured, and provide a waiver of subrogation in favor of the City; 
(4)  Not contain a passenger liability exclusion; and 
(5)  Provide for at least 30 days' prior written notice of any proposed insurance policy modification or cancellation to the City Manager. 
(Ord. No. 2007-04-026, § 5-40(art. III), 4-10-2007)  
Sec. 14-149. - Performance bond and revocation clause. 
(a)  The ambulance service franchise holder shall establish a $5,000.00 performance bond with a reputable commercial surety with the City listed as the obligee/beneficiary. The purpose of this bond is to incentivize franchisee compliance with this article and recover administrative, monitoring and enforcement costs to be incurred by the City for terminating the franchise of an ambulance service for cause, in the event the franchise is revoked.
