(b)  Bulk sales water service classification, rates and fees schedule: 
(1)  Bulk sales through fire hydrant water meters temporarily installed at locations remote from the West San Marcos Street water plant: 
a.  Advance, nonrefundable payment of $50.00 to the City at City Hall for setting the meter connection at the fire hydrant or other appropriate locations as the City may determine; 
b.  Payment of bulk sales rate of $50.00 per month for the first 1,000 gallons of water dispensed, or any fraction thereof; $20.00 per month per 1,000 gallons dispensed, or any fraction thereof, beyond the initial 1,000 gallons dispensed; and 
c.  Advance, refundable fire hydrant meter deposit payment of $200.00 to the City at City Hall. 
(2)  Bulk sales through permanently installed water meter dispensation point at the West San Marcos Street water plant: 
a.  No requirement for payment of meter setting fee; 
b.  Payment of bulk sales rate of $50.00 for the first 1,000 gallons of water dispensed, or any fraction thereof; $20.00 per 1,000 gallons dispensed, or any fraction thereof, beyond the initial 1,000 gallons dispensed; and 
c.  No requirement for payment of the $200.00 fire hydrant meter deposit, however, each water dispensation transaction authorized under subsection (b)(1) of this section must be prepaid to the City at City Hall where a one-day dispensation voucher will be issued for presentation to the water plant operator to authorize a one-day dispensation of a not to exceed amount of water in gallons. The one-day dispensation voucher identifying the cumulative number of gallons purchased will allow for scheduled multiple withdrawals of water, but only during the same City working day upon which initial dispensation commences. 
(c)  Bulk sales water service customers must provide a suitable mobile water containment vessel of sound quality for receiving and hauling water for use or consumption at any location within the City water system. 
(d)  Public or private volunteer firefighting organizations that procure water only for fire prevention and control purposes and do not resell such water for other purposes, are exempt from this classification, rates and fees schedule. Contractors constructing City public works projects requiring potable water for dust control and construction operations, shall also be exempt from this classification, rates and fees schedule. 
(e)  The established rates in this section include any incidental fuel adjustment charges related to electrical consumption during the City's water supply and dispensation functions. 
(f)  Any $200.00 refundable fire hydrant meter deposit paid to the City may be applied by the City to the payment of any bulk sales customer unpaid bills, and when so partially consumed through past-due account application, shall be restored by the bulk sales customer to the original $200.00 amount. The City shall pay six percent interest per annum on the average monthly deposit balance to the depositor, his heirs or assigns, from the time of such deposit, the same to be calculated and/or paid annually on demand, or sooner if such account status is discontinued. When such service classification is discontinued, such deposit, together with any unpaid interest thereon, or such part of such deposit and unpaid interest not consumed in bills past due for such service, shall be returned to such depositor, his heirs, assigns or legal representatives. 
(g)  Bulk sales water service dispensation to consumers having only an occasional need for such water service are encouraged to utilize the permanently installed water meter dispensation point at the City water plant located on West San Marcos Street pursuant to subsection (b)(2) of this section. 
(h)  Use of the West San Marcos Street permanently installed water meter dispensation point requires advanced payment by check or cash to the City at City Hall and at least four hours advanced scheduling of prospective water withdrawals which shall also only occur during the following City working hours: Monday through Friday 9:00 a.m. to 12:00 noon and 1:00 p.m. to 4:00 p.m., Saturday, Sunday and City holidays excluded. 
(Ord. of 7-25-1983(2), § 9; Ord. of 1-13-1993, § I; Ord. of 6-9-1999, § I; Ord. No. 2009-090-071, § I(9), 9-17-2009; Ord. No. 2012-06-160, § I, 9-27-2012)  
Sec. 28-15. - Water service payment due. 
Where service has been disconnected for failure to pay for water service furnished, a charge of $5.00 shall be made as reconnection fee for each and every meter disconnected before such service shall be restored or water turned on again. 
(Ord. of 7-25-1983(02), § 10)  
Sec. 28-16. - Water tapping fees and charges for connection. 
The tapping fees and charges for connection with the City water mains and laterals shall be as follows: 
(1)  Water tap fees. 
Inside City Tap 	Tap Fee 
¾" 	$200.00, plus cost of meter. 
1" 	$350.00, plus cost of meter. 
2" 	$200.00, plus cost of meter, material, equipment, and labor. 
4" 	$600.00, plus cost of meter, material, equipment, and labor. 
6" 	$900.00, plus cost of meter, material, equipment, and labor. 
 
Outside City Tap 	Tap Fee 
¾" 	$375.00, plus cost of meter. 
1" 	$475.00, plus cost of meter. 
2" 	$200.00, plus cost of meter, material, equipment, and labor. 
4" 	$600.00, plus cost of meter, material, equipment, and labor. 
6" 	$900.00, plus cost of meter, material, equipment, and labor. 
 
(2)  The tap fees provided in subsection (1) of this section shall apply to service connections made on dirt streets. Whenever a tap is made on a paved street, an additional charge equivalent of the actual cost of labor and materials required to repave the street shall be added to the tap fee. 
(3)  For each service connection on a dirt street where the meter size used is not herein provided, whether the connection is inside the corporate limits of the City or outside the City limits the tap fee shall be the actual prevailing cost of labor, parts and materials necessary to complete the connection. For each service connection on a paved street where the meter size used is not herein provided, whether the connection is inside the corporate limits of the City or outside the City limits, the tap fee shall be the actual prevailing costs of labor, parts and materials necessary to complete the connection and the actual prevailing costs of labor and materials required to reconstruct or repave the street. 
(4)  Whenever a tap is requested for the purpose of connection to an automatic fire water sprinkler device system, the tap fee shall be equivalent to the actual prevailing costs required to complete the connection. 
(5)  None of the tap fees or one-time rental fees as herein provided shall be refundable to the consumer upon termination of the water service. 
(6)  For each service connection tap on noncommercial, permanent, single-family dwellings within the corporate limits of the City, constructed in accordance with the City housing code, the City waterworks system shall furnish, if necessary, 200 feet of pipe extension. The customer will pay for the difference of the actual cost of labor, materials, and equipment. Any customer desiring water service outside the City limits will be required to pay the City for the entire cost of extension, including labor, material and equipment. The material used shall be of equal quality to the material used by the City waterworks system. The material and the construction of said line outside of the City limits shall be installed under the supervision of the Water Works Superintendent or his assistants. The customer shall then deed the completed water line to the City Water Works System. All customers desiring water service outside the City limits shall comply with all the rules and regulations herein provided or the service will not be extended. 
(Ord. of 7-25-1983(2), § 11; Ord. of 8-30-2004, § 11; Ord. No. 2006-12-016, exh. A, 12-12-2006)  
Sec. 28-16.5. - Wastewater rates. 
The following uniform monthly rates shall be charged to all persons, firms or corporations for the use of the City's wastewater system within the corporate limits of the City. Customers provided wastewater service outside of the corporate limits of the City shall be charged 1.5 times the rate of the applicable customer class within the City limits.

Sec. 28-18. - Methods, penalties and fees for billing. 
(a)  Request for check read fee. The fee is $10.00. Each customer will get one free check read during the calendar year. After the one free check read is performed, any customer requesting that a meter be checked for accuracy will be assessed the fee if the reading is found to be correct. If the reading is incorrect, no charge shall be assessed. 
(b)  Reconnection fee. A customer whose water or gas service has been disconnected for failure to pay shall be assessed the following fees in order to effect a reconnect: 
Reconnect for nonpayment during business hours 	$12.50 per service (water and gas) 
Collection fee 	$12.50 
	Total 	$25.00 
 
Customers 65 years and older are exempt from paying the reconnect/collection fees. 
(c)  Redisconnection. A redisconnection fee of $100.00 shall be charged to any customer who reconnects service after the City has disconnected service for failure to pay. Any customer who illegally reconnects or attempts to reconnect services, or anyone who benefits from services received at a location where service has been reconnected by someone other than an authorized employee of the City, shall be subject to the penalties specified in section 1-13. 
(d)  NSF checks. Any checks found to be without sufficient funds will be charged a $25.00 fee. After two such offenses the customer will be prohibited from making any further payment with checks. From then onward, the customer shall pay exclusively in cash or C.O.D. 
(Ord. of 9-11-1990, § 3; Ord. of 12-13-2000, § 1; Ord. of 9-10-2002, § 1)  
Sec. 28-19. - Sewer service monthly surcharge. 
(a)  User charge rates. There shall be charged for sanitary sewer service in the City for each month the following rates. The monthly sewer rate shall be charged as follows: 
First 	6,000 gals. 	Minimum $9.00 
Next 	10,000 gals. 	$0.35 per thousand gals. 
Next 	15,000 gals. 	$0.40 per thousand gals. 
Above 	31,000 gals. 	$0.45 per thousand gals. 
 
(b)  In addition to the charges stated in subsection (a) of this section, a 50 percent surcharge shall be added at billing time to the total monthly billing of each customer furnished sewer service outside the corporate limits of the City. 
(Ord. of 7-16-1986, § 16; Ord. of 6-13-2001, § I)  
Sec. 28-20. - Sewer tap fees. 
Sewer tap fees are as follows: 
4-inch tap 	$275.00, plus cost of parts, material, equipment, and labor. 
6-inch tap 	$500.00, plus cost of parts, material, equipment, and labor. 
 
(Ord. No. 2006-12-016, exh. A, 12-12-2006)

Residential and commercial consumers will be assessed a fee to make a gas tap on an existing main in accordance with the schedule of tap fees below. If it is necessary to excavate into a paved street to make a gas tap, an additional tapping charge equivalent to the actual cost of parts, material, equipment, and labor required to repave the street, shall be collected by the City to cover costs of repair to the paved street.

Sec. 28-22. - Gas service connect or reconnect fee. 
(a)  Whenever gas customers request to connect or re-connect to the City's gas distribution system, a fee of $50.00 will be charged to connect or re-connect per meter during regular working hours, and a $100.00 fee will be charged to connect or re-connect per meter after regular working hours. These gas connect or re-connect fees are in addition to any other charges included in this Code. 
(b)  Whenever gas customers request to temporarily discontinue service from the City's gas distribution system, the request must be submitted to the City in writing. The charges for re-connection of service shall be as set forth in subsection (a) of this section. 
(Ord. of 7-25-1983(1), § 5; Ord. of 12-10-2003, § 1; Ord. No. 2015-10-01, § 1(5), 10-27-2015)  
Sec. 28-23. - Deposits for gas service. 
(a)  Required; amount. On all requests for gas service and connections to the City's gas distribution system a deposit will be required. The following schedule sets forth the required deposits to open an account and receive gas service from the City: 
Deposits 
Gas meter deposit - Residential 	$100.00 
Gas meter deposit - Commercial 	$200.00 
 
While deposits may be applied to the payment of any unpaid bills, they must be restored to the original amount when so used. When gas service is discontinued, customer deposits, or such deposit balance not consumed in application to gas bills due will be returned to such customer, his heirs, or legal representatives. 
(b)  Residential or domestic gas consumers—Renters. Each residential or domestic gas consumer, who is renting the premises to which gas is to be supplied, shall put up a $75.00 meter deposit, which may be applied to the payment of any unpaid bills, and when so used, the deposit shall be restored to the original amount. When such service is discontinued, such deposit or such part of such deposit not consumed in bills due for such service, shall be returned to such depositor, his heirs, or legal representatives. 
(c)  Commercial gas consumers. Each commercial gas consumer shall put up a meter deposit as follows: 
(1)  $250.00 deposit per gas meter measuring less than 750 cubic feet. 
(2)  $500.00 deposit per gas meter measuring 750 cubic feet and larger, including cleaners, laundries, etc. 
(3)  $500.00 deposit per gas meter for manufacturing companies plus one month's average calculated usage. 
Deposits may be applied to the payment of any unpaid bills, and when so used, the deposit shall be restored to the original amount. When such service is discontinued, such deposit or such part of such deposit not consumed in bills due for such service, shall be returned to such depositor, his heirs, or legal representatives. 
(d)  Use of deposit. Any residential or commercial consumer who has put up a deposit according to subsection (a), (b), or (c) of this section is entitled to use such deposit as deposit on any additional house or building; provided, however, that such consumer has been a continuous customer in good standing of the City gas distribution system for the past 18 months from the date of such request. 
(Ord. of 7-25-1983(1), § 9; Ord. of 12-10-2003, § 1; Ord. No. 2015-10-01, § 1(9), 10-27-2015)  
Sec. 28-24. - Gas rates. 
(a)  For each defined customer class, monthly bills shall be comprised of the following three components: a minimum charge, a base consumption charge, and a purchased fuel adjustment charge. 
(1)  Minimum charges will be assessed to all active accounts irrespective of consumption. 
(2)  Base consumption charges are designed to partially recover the City's administrative and distribution costs related to delivering natural gas to retail customers. 
(3)  Purchased fuel adjustment charges ("PFACs") are designed to fully recover the City's cost of purchased wholesale natural gas. The PFAC shall be established in the wholesale billing statement provided by the City's natural gas provider for the corresponding billing month. 
(4)  The sum of the base consumption charge and the PFAC shall be applied to the customer's meted consumption for the purpose of calculating the customer's monthly bill. The sum of the customer's minimum charge, consumption charge, and purchased fuel adjustment charge will equal the total amount payable. 
(5)  Billed consumption shall be based on metered natural gas consumption converted into therms. This conversion shall be calculated each month by multiplying the metered natural gas consumption expressed in CCFs, or hundreds of cubic feet, by the energy factor of the natural gas, which is provided by the City's Wholesale Natural Gas Provider in its corresponding monthly statement. Therm billing will enable Pearsall's natural gas customers to pay for the heating value of their natural gas, not the volume of gas used. 
(b)  The following tables illustrate the scheduled natural gas minimum charge and base consumption charge adjustments that will begin on December 1, 2015, and continue every year that follows through December 2019.

(a)  Residential and commercial connect fees. 
(1)  $25.00 gas connect fee and re-connect fee per meter, during regular working hours. 
(2)  $50.00 gas connect fee and re-connect fee per meter, after regular working hours. 
(b)  Gas tap fees. 
(1)  Residential: 
Residential: 
Inside City 	$150.00, plus cost of parts, material, equipment, and labor. 
Outside City 	$200.00, plus cost of parts, material, equipment, and labor. 
 
(2)  Commercial: 
a.  Inside City limits: $250.00 gas tap fee, plus parts, material, equipment, and labor when excavating through a paved street. 
b.  Outside City limits: $300.00 gas tap fee, plus parts, material, equipment, and labor when excavating through a paved street. 
(c)  Deposits. 
(1)  Residential or domestic consumers: $75.00 deposit per gas meter. 
(2)  Commercial consumers: 
a.  $250.00 deposit per gas meter measuring less than 750 cubic feet. 
b.  $500.00 deposit per gas meter measuring 750 cubic feet and larger, including cleaners, laundries, etc. 
c.  $500.00 deposit per gas meter for manufacturing companies plus one month's average calculated usage. 
All charges for gas service furnished or rendered by the gas distribution system shall be due and payable in accordance with this chapter and chapter 44, Utilities. Where services have been disconnected for failure to pay for gas service furnished, a charge of $25.00, during regular working hours, and $50.00, after regular working hours, shall be made as reconnection fee for each and every meter disconnected before such service shall be restored or gas turned on again. 
(Ord. of 7-25-1983(1), § 11; Ord. of 12-10-2003, § 1; Ord. No. 2006-12-016, exh. A, 12-12-2006)  
Sec. 28-26. - Taxicab permit fee. 
A permit shall be required as provided in section 46-21 for each vehicle operated as a taxi or taxicab, and the fee for such permit shall be $50.00 per year, per car or vehicle operated as a taxi or taxicab within the City, and shall be payable on an annual basis not later than January 10 of each year of operation. If any permit to operate any taxicab is granted during a current year, the fee shall be made pro rata for the balance of the calendar year on the basis of the number of months and fractions thereof remaining in said calendar year, and such pro rata rates to be figured from the first day of each month. In the event a taxicab on which the fee has been paid for the current year is sold, wrecked or destroyed, the operator thereof shall have the right to replace the taxicab with another vehicle, and upon written application to the Director of Public Safety, the license and inspection fee therefore paid on said taxicab shall be applicable to the vehicle designated to replace such taxicab, and the permittee shall surrender the permit certificate to the City. There shall not in any event, be any refund of permit or inspection fees paid under this section. The fee shall be paid to the Tax Assessor and Collector of the City, who shall issue receipt therefor on a form to be prepared by him for that purpose. 
(Ord. No. 2008-04-039, § 1(80-23), 4-8-2008)  
Sec. 28-26.5. - Taxicab driver's license application fee. 
Every person driving a taxicab must be licensed as such and each applicant for a driver's license shall pay a one-time $25.00 fee to the City upon making any such application, and, before any such license is finally issued, pay an additional $10.00 to defray the City's cost in physically making the operator's license, for a total fee of $35.00, but if such license is not issued, said applicant shall not be entitled to a refund of the $25.00 paid on filing his application. 
(Ord. No. 2008-04-039, § 1(80-31), 4-8-2008)  
Sec. 28-27. - Taxicab inspection fee. 
In order to defray part of the expense necessary to provide surveillance, supervision and inspection of taxicabs required under the terms and provisions of article II of chapter 46 and other ordinances of the City regulatory thereof, there is hereby levied a permit and inspection fee of $25.00 per year for each taxicab so operated, which fee shall be collected by the Tax Assessor and collected from every person operating taxicabs on the streets of the City. Said fee shall be payable on an annual basis and shall be due and payable for any year not later than January 10 of said year, such fee to cover the upcoming calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 2008-04-039, § 1(80-24), 4-8-2008)  
Sec. 28-27.5. - Taxicab fares. 
Each owner or operator of a taxi or taxicab shall be entitled to charge the following rates for operation within the City for 24-hour-a-day service: 
(1)  $1.50 for the first one-sixth of a mile; 
(2)  $0.28 for each additional one-sixth of a mile; 
(3)  $1.50 for each additional passenger; 
(4)  $0.12 for each minute of waiting time when the taxicab is requested to wait for a passenger; 
(5)  A minimum charge of $2.00 for each trip, if the amount due for such trip as shown on the taximeter, calculated in accordance with subsections (1) through (4) of this section, is less than $2.00; 
(6)  A gas surcharge of an additional $0.50 when the average gas prices for regular unleaded fuel are over $3.50 per gallon in the City. The calculation to test the $3.50 gas surcharge cap will be conducted at three intervals of the calendar year: April, July, and October. The average gas price is equal to the sum of the price of regular unleaded gasoline for the four Saturdays of the test month at gas service stations divided by the number of gas service stations used in the calculation. When obtaining the gas prices of gas service stations, the minimum number of gas service stations to use in the test should be four and they must be verifiable and located within the City limits. 
(Ord. No. 2008-04-039, § 1(80-34), 4-8-2008)

(c)  Due to the health, safety and general welfare need to provide continuous solid waste collection services to benefit area citizenry, a public emergency is hereby officially declared and the ordinance from which this section is derived shall take effect immediately upon passage.

Sec. 28-29. - Brush collection rates. 
(a)  The City Council hereby adopts "Attachment A," attached to the ordinance from which this section is derived and incorporated by reference, setting forth the brush collection rates and establishing the regulations and procedures for the disposal of brush collection at the City's waste collection station in order to promote the health, safety and general welfare of the area citizenry. 
(b)  The City Council hereby authorizes the City Manager to implement, administer and enforce the regulations and rates as set forth by this chapter. 
(c)  The ordinance from which this section is derived, upon passage, shall be published twice in the newspaper of general circulation in the City, effective from and after the date of its publication, as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 2009-090-070, §§ I—III, 9-17-2009)  
Sec. 28-30. - Brush dumping fees. 
(a)  Brush dumping fees shall be as follows: 
(1)  $3.00 per pickup load. 
(2)  $10.00 for trailers up to 16 feet. 
(3)  $20.00 for commercial vehicles larger than 16-foot trailers but smaller than 18 wheelers. 
(4)  $50.00 for 18 wheelers and larger vehicles. 
(b)  Free brush dumping will be allowed for the first two pickups or one trailer up to 16 feet during designated annual and/or semi-annual City cleanups. 
(Ord. No. 2009-090-070, exh. A, 9-17-2009)

(b)  Brush fees during regular operations. 
(1)  For residential customers showing valid I.D. and current utility bill: no charge. 
(2)  For commercial customers showing valid I.D. and current utility bill: 
a.  Two loads of brush (maximum 16-foot trailers) per month there will be no charge. 
b.  Additional loads during a month will be charged at $10.00 per load (maximum 16-foot trailers). 
c.  Loads larger than 16-foot trailers, but smaller than 18 wheelers, will be charged at $20.00 per load. 
(3)  For residential citizens not showing valid I.D. and current utility bill, the charge for a load of brush (maximum 16-foot trailers) will be $25.00. Maximum loads per day will be three. 
(4)  For commercial operators not showing valid I.D. and current utility bill 
a.  The charge for a load of brush (maximum 16-foot trailers) will be $25.00. Maximum loads per day will be three. 
b.  The charge for a load of brush larger than 16-foot trailers, but smaller than 18 wheelers, will be $35.00. Maximum loads per day will be three. 
c.  The charge for an 18 wheeler load of brush will be $100.00. Maximum loads per day will be two. 
(c)  Brush fees during designated City cleanup periods. 
(1)  Free brush disposal will be allowed for regular size pickup loads and/or one trailer up to 16 feet per household during designated City cleanup period. 
(2)  Currently our garbage contractor will have two cleanups per year for bulk waste. There will be one in the spring and the second one in the fall. Bulk waste will be limited to 4 cubic yards. Bulk waste must be placed at curb side. Cleanup is for residential customers only. 
(3)  The City's garbage contractor will pick up brush at curbside every first and third Thursday of every month. Brush must be in piles of no longer than four feet, no wider than three feet, and no higher than three feet. Customers must call the office before 4:30 p.m. the Tuesday before to be placed on the list. 
(d)  Transfer station hours of operation. Transfer station hours of operation are as follows: every Tuesday thru Friday (except for holidays), from 1:00 p.m. to 5:00 p.m. 
(Ord. No. 2013-12-01, exh. A, 12-10-2013; Ord. No. 2017-10-05, exh. A, 10-10-2017)  
Sec. 28-32. - Fee schedule for convention and civic center rental. 
The City Council hereby adopts the fee schedule for convention and civic center rentals, cleaning deposit, and cleaning fee attached to the ordinance from which this section is derived and incorporated by reference herein. 
(Ord. No. 2017-01-02, 1-10-2017)  
Sec. 28-33. - Court funds. 
(a)  Municipal Court Technology Fund. This fee shall be in the amount of $3.00. The fee shall be assessed against and collected from the Defendant upon conviction for a misdemeanor offense in the Municipal Court as a cost of court. 
(b)  Municipal Court Building Security Fund. The Municipal Court of the City (the "Municipal Court") is hereby authorized and required to assess a municipal court building security fee (the "fee") in the amount of $3.00 against all defendants convicted of a misdemeanor offense by the Municipal Court. Each misdemeanor conviction shall be subject to a separate assessment of the fee. 
(Ord. No. 2008-09-043, § 2, 9-9-2008; Ord. No. 2015-10-02, § 1(b), 10-27-2015)  
Chapter 30 - NATURAL RESOURCES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Oil and gas, V.T.C.A., Natural Resources Code, Chs. 51, 81, 91; lease of municipal oil, gas, or mineral land, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code, § 253.005; municipal authority to regulate exploration and development of mineral interests, V.T.C.A., Natural Resources Code § 92.007. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 30-1—30-18. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - OIL AND GAS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 30-19. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Applicant means any person, firm or corporation who applies for a permit under the provisions of this article. 
Drilling operation means the making of a hole in the earth for the purpose of discovery, exploration or production of oil, gas or minerals. 
Operator includes every person, and the agents, servants and employees of such person, engaged in operations for the drilling, reworking, redrilling, well service or plugging and abandonment of any well subject to this article and the production or transportation of any product therefrom. 
Permit means a permit granted pursuant to this article. 
Permittee means any person holding a permit granted pursuant to this article. 
Production unit means those areas surrounding a well designated as a unit by an operator. 
Railroad Commission, R.R.C., as used in this article means Railroad Commission of the State. 
Terminology. All words herein having accepted meanings in the oil and gas industry shall have the same meanings in this article. 
Unitize means the grouping of mineral interests in a given surface unit for the purpose of producing hydrocarbons as a unit. 
Well means any hole, excavation or bore downward from the surface, intended to extend 200 feet or more into the subsurface, made by any means or manner, for the purpose of exploring for, discovering, producing, or injecting hydrocarbons, water or other mineral, and which has not been officially plugged and abandoned. 
Well service operations means operations on a well, other than drilling operations or recompletion operations. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 2)  
Sec. 30-20. - Purpose. 
The City Council finds that there has been drilling and production operations for oil and gas within the corporate limits of the City, and that there is a likelihood of drilling and production operations and other operations incident to exploration, drilling and production, and incident to the existence of such operations, which should be regulated because of the fire hazards created by such operations, as well as the menace of unsanitary conditions, noise and possibility of injury to persons and property and threats to the health, safety and welfare of the public in general, for which the police power of the State which is delegated to the City, is to be and is hereby invoked, in aid of the enforcement of this article. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 1(1.1))  
Sec. 30-21. - Scope. 
This article shall govern the exploration, drilling, and production of hydrocarbons and matters incident thereto, in all areas of the City. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 1(1.2))  
Sec. 30-22. - Well locations. 
All wells drilled in search of oil and gas within the City limits shall be drilled in accordance with the requirements of this section. 
(1)  Streets, alleys, easements and City-owned water wells. No well shall be drilled within, or at any location nearer than 50 feet from any street, alley, or utility easement. No well shall be drilled nearer than 1,000 feet from any City-owned and operated water well. 
(2)  Distance from residences, buildings or structures. No well shall be drilled at any location which is nearer than 300 feet from any residence or permanent structure intended for humane occupancy, unless the applicant furnishes to the City Manager written waivers executed by all owners of such residences and such structures which are located within 300 feet from the proposed location whereby the owners waive objections to the location and, unless the applicant furnishes to the City Manager evidence of reasonable appropriate written notification furnished by the applicant to the occupants of all such residences and structures, or said owner by lease has contracted otherwise. 
(3)  Location near schools, hospitals, etc. No well shall be drilled at any location which is on, or within 400 feet from any exterior boundary line of, land used by any school, hospital, or public building. The City Manager is authorized to grant a variance to this requirement, if the applicant presents written evidence to the City Manager that the owners or the governing body of such school, hospital, church or public building, have consented and agreed in writing to the proposed well location. 
(4)  Location near cemeteries and parks. No well shall be drilled at any location which is less than 175 feet from the exterior boundary line of lands utilized for cemeteries or public parks without prior approval of the cemetery association in the case of cemeteries. 
(5)  Surface rights. Neither this article nor any permit issued hereunder shall be interpreted as granting any right or license to the permittee to enter upon or use any land nor shall it limit or prevent the free right of the owner of such land to contract for any payment of any kind for damages or for rights or privileges with respect thereto. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 3)  
Secs. 30-23—30-47. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - DRILLING AND OPERATING PERMITS 
 
Sec. 30-48. - Permits required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, acting either for himself or as an agent, employee, independent contractor, or servant of any other person, to commence to drill, to drill or to operated any well or to assist in the drilling, completing, or operating of any such well for which a permit has not been obtained. In addition to other requirements of this section, a new permit is required to re-enter any well which has been plugged and abandoned as though the plugged and abandoned well were a new well and it shall be unlawful for any person, acting either for himself, or as agent, employee, independent contractor, or servant of another, person, to re-enter such a well without first obtaining a permit therefor. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 4(4.1))  
Sec. 30-49. - Application for drilling permit. 
An application for a drilling permit shall be filed in duplicate in the Office of the City Manager for each well to be drilled. Such application shall be signed, and the accuracy of the contents thereof and exhibits attached thereto shall be sworn to before a notary public by the applicant having legal authority to enter into contracts binding upon the applicant, and shall include, as exhibits constituting a part of same, where appropriate,) the following: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant, and if the applicant, is a corporation, the name and address of the person upon whom process may be served for such corporation, and if the applicant is a partnership, the names and addresses of the general partners. 
(2)  The name, address and telephone number of a person, other than the applicant, designated as the local agent of the applicant to receive for the applicant all process, citation, notices and demands hereunder. If appropriate, more than one telephone number should be furnished. 
(3)  Designation of a drilling block or production unit to be covered by the application with a metes and bounds description as reflected by the official survey thereof or plat thereof where previously subdivided, and a statement to the effect that to the best of the knowledge and belief of the applicant his application for a permit to drill complies with all of the requirements of this division. 
(4)  In addition to the designation of the unit by plat, the applicant shall file a proposed surface location of the well, together, with distances from said well to the exterior boundary lines of the drilling unit certified to by a surveyor licensed by the State. Said plat shall show distances from the proposed surface well location to any residences or structures intended for human occupancy which are located within 300 feet from said surface well location and shall show whether or not such well location is in compliance with other sections of this article and shall be attached as exhibit 1. 
(5)  Proposed total depth of the well. 
(6)  A true copy of the Railroad Commission form and Railroad Commission drilling permit, if issued, shall be attached as exhibits 2 and 3, respectively. 
(7)  An insurance certificate dated not more than ten days prior to the filing of the application shall be attached as exhibit 4. This certificate shall indicate that the applicant has complied with at least the minimum insurance requirements specified herein. 
(8)  A copy of the bonds required by this article shall be attached as exhibit 5. If no bond is required, the applicant shall attach as exhibit 5 a statement to the effect that no bond is required with a brief statement pertaining to the reason for the exception to the bond requirement. 
(9)  Each application shall be accompanied by a list of the names and last known addresses of all record owners of interests in and to oil, gas, and other minerals under the property included within the drilling block on which the proposed well is to be located. Said list shall be attached as exhibit 6 and shall specify the fractional share of operating rights within the drilling unit by each of said owners. This requirement can be waived by the City Manager provided that the operator agrees to furnish the City a true and correct copy of the division order contract once it is executed by all interested parties. Said division order contract shall be furnished to the City within six months following completion of a well. 
(10)  The permit application shall include a statement by the applicant authorizing the City to expend such funds as may be necessary, under the circumstances, to regain well control in accordance with the terms and provisions hereinafter set out regarding wells that are out of control. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 4(4.2))  
Sec. 30-50. - Well service operations. 
No applications or reports are required for well service operations. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 4(4.3))  
Sec. 30-51. - Application in compliance with requirements granted by City Manager. 
Upon receipt of an application for a permit to drill and operate a well, the City Manager shall date and set up a file for this application and examine same for compliance with this division. If the application is found in compliance with all requirements of this division, the City Manager shall publish a notice of the intention to grant such application unless a written protest in opposition thereto is filed within seven days from the date of publication. If the application is in compliance with all provisions of this division, and no written protest in opposition to the granting of the permit is filed, based upon one or more of the grounds set fourth herein, then the City Manager will, in accordance with this division, within ten days after dates of publication of notice, issue a permit. If a written protest in opposition to the application is filed within seven days from the date of publication of the notice, and the City Manager determines that the protest is not well founded, he will, after three days' notice to the protestant, issue the permit unless the protestant, within such three days, files notice of appeal to the City Council. In the event the City Manager has found cause to deny the permit, then the City Manager shall, within ten days of the filing of said application, inform the applicant in writing of reasons for such denial, and return the original copy of the application and filing fee to the applicant. In the event of a written protest on grounds which are found sufficient by the City Manager followed by the denial of the permit, the City Manager shall return the original copy of the application and filing fee to the applicant and inform the applicant in writing of his reasons for such denial. In either case the applicant may rectify the reason for denial of the permit and resubmit the same to the City Manager or appeal to the City Council through the procedure herein described. In the event of appeal by the protestant, the City Council shall set a date for hearing and publish notice as provided herein and inform the applicant of the date of such hearing. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 4(4.4))  
Sec. 30-52. - Application denied by City Manager; appeal procedure. 
If the City Manager does not grant a permit and the applicant desires to appeal to the City Council, the applicant shall comply with the following procedure. The original copy of the application, accompanied by the filing fee and a copy of the City Manager's written denial, shall be presented to City Council by the City Manager. The City Manager shall set the hearing for the next regular meeting of the City Council after seven days from notice of appeal and publish a notice of such hearing at least five days prior to the date of hearing. Provided, however, where it is shown by the application, without contradiction by the City Manager, that all of the land within 300 feet of the proposed surface drilling site is under lease to the applicant and no residence building or other permanent structure intended for human occupancy is within 300 feet of the proposed drilling surface site, no notice shall be necessary under this division, and a hearing may be held by the City Council at any time after filing of the application with the City Manager. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 4(4.5))  
Sec. 30-53. - Hearing notice. 
Notice of the filing of an application and hearing to be held either by the City Manager or the City Council, as the case may be, shall be by publication, one time, in a newspaper published in the City at least five days prior to the date of the hearing. Such notices shall essentially name the applicant subject of the application, property affected and state that the application, and maps reflecting the unit and drilling location are on file in the Office of the City Council for inspection during regular office hours. Notice of the day, time and place of the meeting shall be given in such notice. Proof of publication of such notice shall be made by the printer or publisher of the newspaper publishing the same by affidavit shall be prima facie evidence of such publication. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 4(4.6))  
Sec. 30-54. - Refusal of application for permit. 
(a)  The City Council shall have the power to refuse any application for a permit to drill and operate any well at any particular location within any area of the City where by reason of such particular location and the character and value of the permanent improvements already erected on or approximately adjacent to the particular location in question, and the use to which the land and surroundings are adapted for school, hospital, park or civic purpose, or for health or safety reasons or any of them, the drilling or operation of such well on the particular location might be injurious or a disadvantage to the City or to its inhabitants as a whole, or to a substantial number of its inhabitants or visitors as a group; or the Council may grant a permit, as it may deem necessary, on such reasonable conditions as to protect all persons who, and property which, may be affected by the drilling and production operations. When the Council refuses to issue a permit for the particular drilling location as applied for by the applicant, it may, in lieu thereof, designate as the drilling location a different drilling site subject to the applicant obtaining all requisite leases, contracts and surface permission for the designated substituted drilling site. 
(b)  The City Manager shall inform the applicant of the action of the City Council within three days after the Council has made a decision. If, for any reason, the permit as applied for is not granted or if the applicant refuses the permit because of any condition imposed therein, the application and filing fee shall be returned to the applicant. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 4(4.7))  
Sec. 30-55. - Transfer of permit. 
A permit validly in force may be transferred from the permittee to another operator upon written application to the City Manager upon proper showing that such new operator has acquired by assignment or contract the operating rights of the permittee, has assumed all of the obligations of the permittee under this division and has complied with the insurance, bond, and all other requirements of this division. Upon approval by the City Manager of such application, the City Manager shall issue a substitute permit to such new operator and cancel the original permit without notice to third parties. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 4(4.8))  
Sec. 30-56. - Effect of drilling permit. 
A drilling permit properly applied for and issued in accordance with this division is permission to the permittee to drill such well in accordance with the application and conditions of the permit and is also permission to produce the well and erect necessary facilities or equipment to handle its production all in accordance with the terms and conditions of this division. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 4(4.9))  
Sec. 30-57. - Tenure of drilling permit. 
The term of a drilling permit shall be for a period of one year, unless within such year operations are commenced, in which event the term shall continue as long thereafter as production is obtained or drilling, reworking or well service operations are conducted, with no cessation of all such production and operations for more than 90 consecutive days, and until the well is plugged and abandoned in accordance with this division. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 4(4.10))  
Secs. 30-58—30-87. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - RULES FOR DRILLING AND PRODUCING OPERATIONS 
 
Sec. 30-88. - Compliance with laws, rules and regulations. 
Any violation of any valid law, rule, regulation or requirement of any State or federal regulatory body or having jurisdiction with reference to drilling, completing, equipping, operating, producing, maintaining, or abandoning oil or gas wells or related appurtenances, equipment of facilities, or with reference to firewalls, fire protection, blowout protection or safety of persons or property shall be a violation of this division. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 5(5.1))  
Sec. 30-89. - Earthen pits. 
The use of earthen pits for drilling operations shall be permissible; however, upon completion of drilling, all material in said earthen pit shall be removed and the pits backfilled with good soil. In no event shall said pits be left open for more than three weeks after the drilling rig has been taken off the well. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 5(5.2))  
Sec. 30-90. - Derricks and rigs. 
No operator shall use or operate in connection with the drilling or reworking of any well, any wooded derrick or steam-powered rig, or permit any drilling rig or derrick to remain on the drilling site for a period longer than 60 days after the completion or abandonment of any well. All engines shall be equipped with effective mufflers. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 5(5.3))  
Sec. 30-91. - Drilling fluid. 
The bore hole of any well while being drilled or reworked shall at all times contain drilling fluid of a weight and viscosity which a reasonably prudent operator would use to keep the well under control. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 5(5.4))  
Sec. 30-92. - Blowout preventers. 
Adequate blowout preventers of the type used in the industry in drilling wells to the formations shall be used by the operators. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 5(5.5))  
Sec. 30-93. - Casing. 
All wells shall be properly cased and cemented so as not to contaminate any freshwater sands. The casing shall be cemented and shall extend to a depth of 100 feet beyond any freshwater sands in accordance with the requirements of the State Water Development Board and any other governmental agency having jurisdiction. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 5(5.6))  
Sec. 30-94. - Drill stem tests. 
No operator shall conduct or allow to be conducted swabbing operations or the taking or completion of any drill stem test except during daylight hours. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 5(5.7))  
Sec. 30-95. - Pressurization. 
No pressurization of formation shall be conducted except during daylight hours. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 5(5.8))  
Sec. 30-96. - Pipelines. 
Before any excavation or construction work is commenced on any pipeline to move oil, gas, water or other product to or from any well site, on, over, under, along, or across any City street, sidewalk, alley, or other City property, a franchise shall first be obtained from the City Council. All pipelines shall be laid only in accordance with the provisions of such franchise, this division and other ordinances of the City. All pipelines used in this connection shall be new pipes meeting U.S. Department of Transportation Pipeline Safety Studies. No operator shall interfere with or damage any existing storm sewer, drainage facility, water line, sewer line, gas line, or facility of a public utility located on, under or across the course of any such pipeline. Temporary lines may be laid under revocable easements. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 5(5.9))  
Sec. 30-97. - Storage facilities. 
Stall storage tanks shall be used for the storage of liquid hydrocarbons and shall be constructed, installed and maintained in a good and workmanlike manner. Each tank or tank battery, as the case may be, shall be surrounded by an earthen firewall located at such a distance from the tanks and of sufficient height to hold and retain at least 1½ times the maximum capacity of such storage facilities. An operator may use, construct and operate steel conventional separators and such other appurtenances as are reasonably necessary for treating oil, condensate, or gas at each tank battery location. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 5(5.10))  
Sec. 30-98. - Fired vessels. 
No fired vessels or open flame shall be located nearer than 150 feet from any well or storage tank. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 5(5.11))  
Sec. 30-99. - Fences. 
All wells and production facilities shall be adequately protected by a fence constructed so as to prevent easy entry. Safety precautions normally taken by reasonably prudent operators shall be observed. Fences to prevent easy entry shall be approved by the City Manager. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 5(5.12))  
Sec. 30-100. - Pumping unit prime movers. 
Only electric prime movers shall be permitted for the purpose of pumping wells. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 5(5.13))  
Sec. 30-101. - Vented gas. 
No operator shall allow gas to escape or be vented into the air except for bleed gas normally vented from standard gas operated controls and normal stock tank vapors. All gas burned shall be burned in a manner which does not create or constitute a fire hazard and the location of the torch, pipe or other burning device, the construction thereof, the maintenance thereof, and the operation thereof shall at all times be maintained in a good and sufficient manner. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 5(5.14))  
Sec. 30-102. - Salt water and wastewater disposal. 
All salt water shall be disposed of off of the premises or through a salt water injection well located upon the premises. No pits or unlined storage facilities for salt water shall be used. No person shall permit any crude oil, gas or other flammable petroleum product to spill over, overflow, leak, drain out, escape, or accumulate in any sewer or about the premises, or on the surface, or in any open surface ditch or any other exposed surface conduit, or handle any hydrocarbon in any manner or amount which creates a potential fire hazard, or permit any condition which may pollute any surface water or damage any publicly owned land. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 5(5.15))  
Sec. 30-103. - Production equipment. 
The operator shall maintain all production equipment in good condition. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 5(5.16))  
Sec. 30-104. - Premises to be kept clean. 
All surface areas utilized by on operator for production facilities shall be kept clear of high gross, weeds and combustible trash or other rubbish or debris that would, if allowed to accumulate, result in a fire hazard. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 5(5.17))  
Sec. 30-105. - Blocking of street or alleys. 
No street or alley shall be blocked or obstructed by any drilling or producing operations unless prior consent is obtained by the operator in the form of a resolution adopted by the City Council, except when necessary to protect life or property in connection with emergency operations. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 5(5.18))  
Sec. 30-106. - Abandonment procedure. 
Whenever any well is abandoned, it shall be the obligation of the operator to plug such well in accordance with the laws of the State and the rules of the Railroad Commission. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 5(5.19))  
Secs. 30-107—30-125. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - INSURANCE AND BONDS 
 
Sec. 30-126. - Insurance requirements. 
All operators shall maintain public liability insurance with bodily injury limits of not less than $1,000,000.00 for each person and $3,000,000.00 for each accident and property damage limits of not less than $100,000.00 for each accident and $200,000.00 for any number of accidents. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 6(6.1))  
Sec. 30-127. - Bond requirements. 
Each applicant shall file a bond with the City Manager, executed by the applicant as principal and by a good and sufficient corporate surety company licensed to do business in the State. Said bond shall provide that the principal will remedy any and all damages to streets, curbs, gutters, water lines, water wells, fire hydrants and other public property, occasioned in any manner by the principal, his agents, employees, servants and contractors, and that the applicant will reimburse the City for any expenditures made by the City under the authority granted herein. Such bond shall insure to the benefit of the City, shall be in a form acceptable to the City Attorney and shall be in an amount not less than $10,000.00 nor more than $100,000.00. Said amount to be determined by the City Manager at his discretion. The applicant shall not be required to post additional bonds if he has in effect by renewal on or before any expiration date unless the applicant is sooner released by the City Manager. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 6(6.2))  
Sec. 30-128. - Release of bonds and permits. 
The City Manager may release bonds and permits, as to the City, under the following conditions: 
(1)  When the permittee ceases all operations covered by this article, all wells for which the permittee holds permits have been plugged in accordance with the terms hereof, including the removal of all equipment and machinery, and files a request for release with the City Manager, the City Manager shall furnish a release, as to the City, of all the permittee's bonds pertaining to the particular well. 
(2)  If the permittee assigns all of his interest in the drilling unit covered by a bond or bonds, such assignor shall be released from such bond as to that drilling unit, except as to any liability then existing, after the assignee has fully complied with the bond and insurance requirements of this division, and the issuance of a substitute permit as provided shall constitute a release of the original permit. 
(3)  Any permittee who has plugged and abandoned a well in accordance with the requirements of this article and complied with all other requirements of this article may, upon request to the City Manager, be furnished with a release of the permit pertaining to such well. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 6(6.3))  
Sec. 30-129. - Well control. 
In the event of the loss of control of any well the operator shall immediately take all reasonable steps to regain control of such well regardless of any other provisions of this article and the City and its forces may take such actions as deemed necessary to protect adjacent properties and the public from such well, if it deems that the operator is not taking or is unable to take the steps to regain control of such well. Any expenses in this regard shall constitute a valid lien against the interest in the well of all working interest owners who have voluntarily joined in the drilling of such well, to secure payment of any expenditure made by the City pursuant to such action. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 6(6.4))  
Secs. 30-130—30-156. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - ENFORCEMENT 
 
Sec. 30-157. - Administrative enforcement and supervision. 
Administrative enforcement of the terms of this article shall be by the City Manager and to that end he is hereby vested with police authority. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 7(7.1))  
Sec. 30-158. - Enforcement. 
In addition to any other penalty provided by this article, the Council may direct the City Attorney to initiate an action in any court having competent jurisdiction to enjoin any violations of the provisions of this article or for an injunction to compel compliance with any provisions of this article. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 7(7.2))  
Sec. 30-159. - Public excluded. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, unless authorized by the operator, to enter a fenced area around any well or production facility. It shall be unlawful for any person, unless authorized by the operator to touch any well or production equipment. Notwithstanding any other provision hereof, the City Manager shall have the right to enter the area of any drill site at any time. In the event any fence surrounding any well or production facility shall be kept locked, upon request of the City Manager, the key shall be furnished to him for use in access to the premises. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 7(7.4))  
Sec. 30-160. - Waiver by City Council. 
Any and all provisions of this article may be waived by the City Council upon a showing by the applicant to the satisfaction of the City Council that the planned manner of operations by the applicant or the equipment to be used by the applicant will adequately protect the public health, safety and welfare. 
(Ord. of 3-17-1976, § 7(7.8))  
Chapter 32 - NUISANCES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Authority of home rule city to define and declare nuisances, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 217.042; persons not to permit abandoned property to become public health nuisance, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 341.013; municipality authority to require the owner of a lot in the municipality to keep the lot free from weeds, rubbish, brush, and other environmental nuisances, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 342.001 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 32-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Brush includes all trees or shrubbery under seven feet in height not cultivated and cared for by the person owning or controlling the premises. 
Developed area means any new City block which is divided into more than four lots or parcels under separate ownership or occupancy, upon which buildings exist on more than 25 percent of such lots or parcel; and in addition, shall include any new City block not meeting the above definition of developed area if at least 50 percent of its perimeter is adjacent to or across a road, street, or alley from a new City block which is divided into more than four lots or parcels under separate ownership or occupancy, upon which buildings exist on more than 25 percent of such lots or parcels. 
Lot includes the land within its boundaries and all land adjacent to and extending beyond the property line to the curbline of adjacent streets and, where no curb exists, to the existing street surface. The term "lot" shall also include all land lying between the property line of any lot and the center of adjacent alleys. 
Owner includes any tenant, lessee, or other occupant of property under an existing agreement or understanding with the owner thereof. 
Parcel means any tract of land which has not been subdivided into lots, but shall also include, in addition to the land within its boundaries, all land adjacent to and extending beyond the property line to the curbline of adjacent streets, and where no curb exists, to the surface of an adjacent public street or road. Parcel shall also include all land lying between the property line and the center of any adjacent alley. 
Rubbish includes all trash, refuse, tin cans, old vessels of all sorts, discarded auto parts, useless articles, inoperative appliances, discarded clothing and textile of all sorts, and all litter and other debris. 
Weeds includes all rank and uncultivated vegetable growth or matter which has grown to more than 12 inches in height, or which, regardless of height, is unsightly. 
(Ord. of 2-10-1999, § 1)  
Sec. 32-2. - Penalties. 
Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished according to the general penalties described in section 1-13, and each and every day's violation shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. In case the owner or occupant of any lot or premises under the provisions of this article shall be a corporation, and shall violate any provisions of this article, the president, vice-president, secretary, or treasurer of such corporation or any manager, agent, or employee of such corporation shall be also severally liable for the penalties herein provided. 
(Ord. of 2-10-1999, § 13)  
Sec. 32-3. - Prohibited acts. 
The following are hereby declared to be nuisances and, as such, are liable to abatement: 
(1)  All cellars, vaults, drains, pools, privies, yards, grounds or premises which have for any cause become foul, nauseous, offensive or injurious to health or unpleasant to adjacent residents or to persons passing by. 
(2)  All carcasses, decaying flesh, fish, fowl, or vegetables, all deposits of manure or other unwholesome substances or flesh of any kind or description whatever and all filthy or offensive water or slops in any private yard or premises or when thrown or conducted into or upon any street, alley, public ground or any enclosure, so as to be unwholesome or offensive, or are liable to become unwholesome or offensive. 
(3)  All privies that are offensive from use, all markets, cellars, laundries, stores, or other buildings or places which are not kept clean and free from filthy or unwholesome substances and odors and all deposits or substances that are offensive or liable to endanger disease. 
(4)  Every trade, business or occupation injurious to the health or comfort of those who reside in the vicinity and any lot or receptacle whatever, containing water or slops suffered to become stagnant or offensive or unwholesome from any cause. 
(5)  Depositing filth or any foul, offensive, nauseous or injurious substances upon any sidewalk, street, alley or other public place. 
(6)  Sweeping or depositing any trash, paper, rubbish, weeds, or grass into or upon any street, alley, sidewalk, or other public place within the City and allowing the same to remain in such place for more than six hours. 
(7)  Permitting or allowing any weeds, filth, or rubbish of any kind to remain on any sidewalk in front or at the side of any premises owned by him or in the street to the middle thereof the rear or side of any lots or premises owned or controlled by him. 
(8)  Hauling, conveying, or transporting of any meat or slaughtered or dead animals or fish through the streets of the City without having the same entirely covered, screened or protected from dust and the public view. 
(9)  Allowing any wastewater or slop of any kind to drain or run over, into or upon any street, sidewalk, or alley of the City. 
(10)  Scattering of any advertisements, circulars, handbills, printed or written announcements or papers of like character or of any medicines upon the streets, sidewalks, alley or within the public buildings or grounds within the City. 
(11)  Posting, writing, printing, or tacking of any kind of sign or advertisement or any kind of written or printed matter of any character upon any telephone, electric light, or telegraph pole within the City. 
(12)  Cutting of any telephone, electric light, or telegraph pole, or of any wall of any building, or of any fence, or any kind of property in the City with any object whatever. 
(13)  Allowing any privy to become dilapidated or out of repair was to expose its contents or any persons using it. 
(Ord. of 2-10-1999, § 2)  
Sec. 32-4. - Owner, occupant responsibility. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, permit, or suffer any nuisance upon any premises, lot, or in any building occupied or controlled by him, or in any street, alley, sidewalk, or gutter immediately adjacent to such premises. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the owner or his agent or the occupant of any lot, building, or place of any kind in this City where any nuisance may exist to remove, abate, or destroy the same without delay. 
(Ord. of 2-10-1999, § 3)  
Sec. 32-5. - Issuance and service of abatement notice. 
(a)  Whenever the Zoning Administrator receives information of the existence of any property not meeting the standards set out in section 32-3, he or any building inspector or sanitary officer assigned such responsibility shall serve the owner of the property with a written notice informing the owner of such condition and directing that action be taken to bring the property into compliance within 15 days. 
(b)  The notice shall be in writing; will state the nature of the public nuisance and that it must be removed and abated within 15 days after receipt of notice; state that a request for a public hearing to determine whether or not a public nuisance exists, as defined herein, must be made to the Zoning Administrator or an agent appointed to receive such request before expiration of 15 days after receipt of such notice; and state that in the event no request for a hearing is received, criminal charges of maintaining and permitting a public nuisance to exist, such public nuisance constructing a public nuisance to exist, such public nuisance constructing a public nuisance may be filed in the municipal court. 
(Ord. of 2-10-1999, § 4)  
Sec. 32-6. - Service of notice. 
(a)  Notice may be served by personal delivery to the owner if he can be located within the City limits, but if he cannot be so located or served after reasonable effort, notice may be served by certified letter addressed to such owner at his post office address, but if such address cannot be served, by publication as many as two times within ten consecutive days in a newspaper of general circulation published in the City. In case of community property, service upon either the husband or the wife shall be deemed sufficient notice hereunder. 
(b)  If the property owner is a corporation, service may be made by delivery of same to any office or place of business of such corporation or any officer of the corporation if such office, place or business or officer can be located within the City limits, but if such office, place of business or officer cannot be so located after reasonable effort, service may be made by certified letter addressed to its corporate headquarters' post office address, but if such address cannot be ascertained after reasonable effort, the notice may be served by publication as many as two times within ten consecutive days in a newspaper of general circulation published in the City. 
(Ord. of 2-10-1999, § 5)  
Sec. 32-7. - Form of notice. 
Whether delivered personally, by mail or by publication, the notice provided for in section 32-5 shall be addressed to the owner, but if the owner is not known, service may be made by publication addressed to the owner of legal description of property. The notice shall give the legal description of the property, state the condition which constitutes a violation hereof and shall state that upon failure of the owner to rectify the situation within 15 days from the date the notice is delivered, or within 15 days from the date of the second publication if notice is served by publication, a criminal complaint may be filed in the Municipal Court of the City for violation of this article, stating the penalties for violation. In addition, the notice shall advise that the City may cause the correction and abatement work to be done on its own and charge the owner for the expense involved, and upon failure of the owner to pay the City for such expense, file a lien on the property for the expense involved as provided for in section 32-9. 
(Ord. of 2-10-1999, § 6)  
Sec. 32-8. - Unlawful noncompliance; providing notice. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or tenant of any land within the City to fail to have any weeds, brush, or rubbish mowed, cut, removed, or other actions to bring the property into compliance with the standards set forth in sections 32-3 and 32-4, within 15 days after notice is received, or published, directing that such standards be met. 
(b)  Upon failure of the owner, occupant, or person in control of the property to comply with sections 32-3 and 32-4, it shall become the responsibility of the Zoning Administrator to have the weeds cut. 
(c)  Before having the weeds or grass cut or to have rubbish, debris, or garbage properly disposed of the Zoning Administrator shall notify the owner of the premises to bring the premises into compliance with sections 32-3 and 32-4 within ten days or, if hardship exists, 25 days. The notice must be in writing and may be served on the owner in accordance with sections 32-5, 32-6, and 32-7. 
(Ord. of 2-10-1999, § 7)  
Sec. 32-9. - Abatement by City; payment of costs by owner; impose lien for nonpayment; removal of trees for access. 
(a)  In addition to the remedy provided for in section 32-8, the City may also cause the work necessary to bring any property into compliance herewith to be done, if the owner has failed to either do such work or cause work to be done within 15 days from the date notice has been received, or public shed, and to charge to the owner for the costs incurred by the City. A statement of the costs incurred by the City to abate such condition shall be mailed to the owner of such premises, if the owner and mailing address is known, and if not known, may be published in a newspaper. The statement shall demand payment within 30 days from the date of receipt or publication. 
(b)  If such statement has not been paid within such period, the City Manager may cause a statement to be filed with the County Clerk of the expenses incurred to abate and correct such condition on the premises to be filed in the deed records, and the City shall have a privileged lien upon the lot, parcel or tract of land where such expenses were incurred, second only to tax liens and liens for street improvements, together with ten percent interest per annum on the delinquent amount from the date such payment was due. For any such expenditures and interest, as aforesaid, suit may be instituted and foreclosure made in the name of the City; and the statement so made, as aforesaid, or a certified copy thereof; shall be prima facie proof of the amount expended in any such work. 
(c)  Although large trees are not covered hereby, and are not felt to be a nuisance or a hazard, it may be necessary at times to remove trees or parts thereof in order for the City crews or contractors to effect entry of mowing or clearing equipment to property or portions of property not meeting standards established in this article, In such case, the removal of such trees or parts thereof as is found necessary shall be done and is hereby authorized, and the cost of this work shall be included in the cost charged to the owner. 
(d)  The City may abate the property for noncompliance. In the event the City does abate and the owner fails to pay for costs incurred in such abatement the City shall have the right to add these costs on the monthly utility bill of said person. 
(Ord. of 2-10-1999, § 8; Ord. No. 2011-06-112, § I, 6-14-2011)  
Sec. 32-10. - Administrative hearing. 
(a)  The owner or occupant of any premises, on which a public nuisance exists in violation of this article, may within 15 days after receipt of notice to remove or abate same, request of the Zoning Administrator or his agent, either in person or in writing, and without the requirement of bond, that a date and time be set when he may appear before the Zoning Administrator for a hearing to determine whether or not a condition then existing on the landowner's property is a public nuisance. The hearing shall be administrative in nature. A record shall be made which shall include: 
(1)  The names of those appearing before the Board; 
(2)  A description of the lot or premises; 
(3)  The decision as to whether or not a public nuisance exists on the premises. 
(b)  Upon determination by the Zoning Administrator that the condition is a public nuisance and therefore in violation of this article, the owner or occupant of the premises where the public nuisance is located shall be ordered to abate the condition within ten days, or where hardship is found to exist, within 25 days. 
(c)  During the pendency of any of the above actions, the cited property owner, tenant, or occupant shall have the right to receive a public hearing to protest to the Planning and Zoning Commission any of the following: 
(1)  The determination that the property is in violation of standards set out in this article; 
(2)  The cost to rectify the situation; 
(3)  The adequacy of the notice; 
(4)  Whether a lien should be placed on the property. 
(d)  This protest to the Planning and Zoning Commission must be made by filing a written notice within ten days following the Zoning Administrator's administrative hearing. If the person so ordered fails to abate the condition declared to be a public nuisance within the period specified, the Board shall turn over the record of the case to the Chief Prosecutor of the Municipal Court, and he shall file criminal charges under the penal provision of this article in the Municipal Court. 
(Ord. of 2-10-1999, § 9)  
Sec. 32-11. - Wrongful conduct to be penalized. 
It shall be unlawful to do or perform any act prohibited hereby, and it shall be unlawful to fail to do or perform any act required hereby. Conviction of any violation within this article shall be punished in accordance with section 32-2. 
(Ord. of 2-10-1999, § 10)  
Sec. 32-12. - Award of bid by City. 
The City may award any quantity of work under section 32-8 to any person whose bid shall be accepted by the City Manager as being the best for completing such work. 
(Ord. of 2-10-1999, § 11)  
Sec. 32-13. - Remedies not exclusive. 
The enumeration of remedies for the suppression of nuisance, as provided in this chapter, are not to be deemed as exclusive, but as cumulative. In particular, prosecution for the offense described in section 32-4 shall not affect the right of the City to abate the nuisance in the manner provided by this chapter, nor shall abatement by the City be a bar to prosecution for the offense described in section 32-4. 
(Ord. of 2-10-1999, § 12)  
Secs. 32-14—32-44. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - MOSQUITO CONTROL 
 
Sec. 32-45. - Prevention and destruction of mosquito breeding areas. 
For the prevention of breeding, and for the destruction of mosquitoes, it shall be required that any and all wells, tanks, underground cisterns, vessels, or ponds containing water where mosquitoes may live, breed, or raise and where they are breeding and raising, shall be protected by thorough screening or by the use of oil in such sufficient quantity to destroy and prevent them from breeding and raising. 
(Ord. of 3-11-1910(1), § 1)  
Sec. 32-46. - Duty of City. 
It shall be the duty of the City to furnish the oil and also to pay a man whose duty it is to see by making such investigation as may be necessary to ascertain whether or not mosquitoes are breeding or raising in any well, tank, cistern, or other place or vessel containing water, and to apply oil to all such wells, tanks, cisterns, or vessels or places containing water in such quantity and manner as may be required to destroy and prevent the breeding of mosquitoes. 
(Ord. of 3-11-1910(1), § 2)  
Sec. 32-47. - Exempt areas. 
That provided any person owning or controlling a well, tank, or cistern in which they keep fish so as to prevent the breeding or raising of mosquitoes, such well, tank, or cistern shall be exempt from the use of oil; if without it is proven that such well, cistern, or tank does breed or contain mosquitoes, then it shall be subject to the use of oil as are all others. 
(Ord. of 3-11-1910(1), § 3)  
Sec. 32-48. - Right of entry. 
Any person who may refuse to allow his wells, tank, or cistern examined to ascertain whether or not they contain or that mosquitoes are breeding therein, or who shall refuse to allow the inspector to use oil in his well, tank, or cistern for the purpose of destroying and preventing the breeding of mosquitoes shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction therefor shall be subject to a fine not exceeding $100.00, and each day that any person shall refuse to obey or object to complying with the requirements of this article, shall constitute a separate offense and shall be subject to a fine for each and every offense. 
(Ord. of 3-11-1910(1), § 4)  
Secs. 32-49—32-69. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - UNFIT BUILDINGS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Municipal authority regarding substandard buildings, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 214.001 et seq. 
 
Sec. 32-70. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Dangerous premises means all premises, buildings or structures which have any or all of the structures which have any or all of the following defects: 
(1)  Those buildings or structures whose interior walls or other vertical structural members list, lean or buckle to such an extent that a plumb line passing through the center of gravity falls outside of the middle third of its base. 
(2)  Those buildings or structures which, exclusive of the foundations, show 33 percent or more of damage or deterioration of the supporting member, or 50 percent of damage or deterioration of the nonsupporting enclosing or outside walls or covering. 
(3)  Those buildings or structures which have improperly distributed loads upon the floors or roofs or in which the same are overloaded, or which have insufficient strength to be reasonably safe for the purpose used. 
(4)  Those buildings or structures which have been damaged by fire, wind or other causes so as to have become dangerous to life, safety, or the general health and welfare of the occupants or the people of the City. 
(5)  Those buildings or structures which have become or are so dilapidated, decayed, unsafe, unsanitary or which so utterly fail to provide the amenities essential to decent living that they are unfit for human habitation or, the condition of which is likely to cause sickness or disease, so as to work injury to the health, safety or general welfare of those living therein or to persons or property in the vicinity. 
(6)  Those having light, air and sanitation facilities which are inadequate to protect the health, safety or general welfare of human beings who occupy or live or may live therein. 
(7)  Those having inadequate facilities for egress in case of fire or panic or those having insufficient stairways, elevators, fire escapes or other means of communication. 
(8)  Those which have parts thereof which are so attached that they may reasonably be expected to fall and injure members of the public or property. 
(9)  Those which, because of their condition, are unsafe, insanitary or dangerous to the health, safety or general welfare of the people of the City. 
Lot includes, in addition to the land within its boundaries, all land adjacent to and extending beyond the property line to the curbline of adjacent streets, and, where no curb exists, to the existing street surfaces.
