Sec. 44-46. - Separate connection and meter. 
Each consumer of water living in a separate house must have a separate connection and meter for each house. Except, that where a residence is not within reach of a City water main, arrangements may be made, at the option of the City, to secure water from another user of City water, in which case, the minimum monthly charge shall be made for each additional residence taking water through such meter. The regular minimum, the additional minimum and all water used over the minimum by such consumer shall be charged to the customer having the meter. 
(Ord. of 7-25-1983(2), § 7)  
Sec. 44-47. - Payment due. 
All charges for water service furnished or rendered by the City Water Works Department shall be due and payable in accordance with this article and this chapter. 
(Ord. of 7-25-1983(2), § 10)  
Sec. 44-48. - Plumbing regulations. 
(a)  There shall be a cut-off valve six inches from the water meter on the house side to control all water in the building. Each commode shall be controlled with a stop above the floor. 
(b)  To prevent the possibility of back siphonage, every outlet, opening, or termination of any hot or cold water piping, including every faucet, stopcock, ball cock, valve, or similar appliance through which water is discharged, shall be not less than three-quarter inch above the level at which the fixtures would overflow on the floor. 
(c)  Water heaters shall not be installed in bedrooms, bathrooms, or attic, or in closets opening into same. If the water heater is set in a closet not prohibited by this section, the closet shall be vented at the bottom of the door or wall with either holes or grill to give at least 30 square inches of ventilation. The heater vent which is usually located at the top of the heater will be vented to the outside of the house. 
(Ord. of 7-25-1983(2), § 12)  
Sec. 44-49. - City Manager to impose methods and fees. 
The City Manager is hereby authorized and directed to impose methods and fees as prescribed by this chapter. 
(Ord. of 9-11-1990, § 1)  
Sec. 44-50. - New service. 
(a)  Connect fee. A new service connect fee shall be assessed for every customer who makes application for new services and this fee shall be collected prior to services being connected. The new service connect fee shall be assessed for any customer transferring services to another location within the utility service area for services at the new location, and this fee shall be collected prior to services being transferred. 
(b)  Application. The City shall require any new customer or any present customer transferring services to a new location to sign a new service application prior to the services being connected. A customer whose signature appears on an application for service connect shall be responsible for any balance due on the service account regardless of who benefits from the use of such service. Each account shall remain active until such time as the account balance is paid and the account is closed by the customer whose signature appears on the application. 
(c)  Method for disconnect. The City shall require any customer closing a utility service account or transferring services to another location to sign, before a witness of the utilities office, the authorization to disconnect service at the current location before an order for disconnect is issued. A customer unable to sign the authorization before a witness of the utilities office shall be mailed, or on the customer's request, delivered, a form authorizing a service disconnect. The City shall accept such authorization only if it is signed in the presence of a notary public and returned to the utilities office. 
(d)  New service deposit fee. Deposits shall be required for all new services and shall be collected prior to services being connected. 
(Ord. of 9-11-1990, § 2)  
Sec. 44-51. - Methods, penalties and fees for billing. 
(a)  Billing for services. 
(1)  All charges for services furnished or rendered by the City shall be due and payable upon receipt. Each customer has 17 days to present to the City the balance due on the account without being assessed a late penalty. After the 17th day, delinquent accounts shall be assessed a five percent late penalty that is in addition to the balance owed. 
(2)  Every reasonable care shall be exercised in the proper delivery and mailing of utility bills and notices of disconnect; however, failure of a customer to receive a bill or notice shall not relieve the customer of the responsibility for payment of service charges within the prescribed period nor exempt the customer from any discount forfeiture for delinquency in the payment thereof. 
(3)  Utility customers that receive utility assistance payments for the billed months from the Community Service Agency will not be assessed the late penalty fee. 
(b)  Partial payment. Partial payments shall be accepted until the cut-off date. Once the cut-off date has passed, partial payments will not be accepted. Charges for water, sewer, gas and garbage collection services provided by the City shall be due and payable concurrently. Payment for one service only would be considered a partial payment and shall not be accepted as such. 
(c)  Disconnection for failure to pay. Accounts that remain unpaid 25 days after charges are due and payable shall be designated on a listing ordering disconnects for failure to pay, and such orders for disconnect shall be executed by designated employees of the City. The City reserves the right to disconnect and discontinue all utility services provided by the City to any premise for which an account is delinquent without further notice, and same shall not be reconnected and no additional service furnished until all delinquent accounts and charges are paid in full. 
(d)  Payment extensions. 
(1)  A customer unable to present the balance due in an account within 25 days may apply for an extension to avoid service interruption. The customer shall demonstrate by application to the City that an unusual financial condition exists to necessitate such an extension. An extension that is granted shall automatically become a payment agreement. An application for extension shall be accompanied by 20 percent of the amount of the bill and shall include the ten percent late penalty. 
(2)  An approved extension agreement shall allow ten days for the customer to present the account balance in full. No extension shall be granted after 5:00 p.m. on the business day preceding the scheduled date for disconnect orders to be issued, and no further extensions shall be granted during the same billing cycle. Failure to comply with an extension agreement shall cause service interruption to the address on the account, and the customer shall be subject to all methods and fees relevant to disconnects for failure to pay. 
(3)  Customers shall be allowed two extensions per calendar year, subject to the considerations outlined in this section. 
(e)  NSF checks. Any checks found to be without sufficient funds will be charged a fee. After two such offenses the customer will be prohibited from making any further payment with checks. From then onward, the customer shall pay exclusively in cash or C.O.D. 
(f)  Method for reconnection. Collection fees shall be assessed to every customer on the disconnect list on the date service is scheduled to be disconnected. The collection fee is in addition to the reconnect fee that shall be charged if the account is disconnected. Services shall be reconnected only upon receipt of all applicable charges and fees. 
(g)  Disconnection and prorated utility bills. Customers who are disconnecting utility services shall be charged the full month of garbage service if the request is after the reading date for the month. A customer service account shall be charged a pro-rated charge depending on the day; or the billing period after the reading date. The customer's gas and water bills shall be based on usage. If the customer's bills does not meet the minimum base rate amount, the customer shall be charged a pro-rated scale according to the day of the billing period. Garbage service will not be prorated but will be charged the full amount to the customer. 
(Ord. of 9-11-1990, § 3; Ord. of 12-13-2000, § 1; Ord. of 9-10-2002, § 1)  
Secs. 44-52—44-83. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - CROSS CONNECTION AND BACKFLOW PREVENTION 
 
Sec. 44-84. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Health means any conditions, devices or practice which, in the judgment of the Department of Public Works, may create a danger to the health and well being of the potable water consumers. 
Plumbing means a plumbing type cross connection that is not properly protected by an approved backflow prevention assembly. 
Pollution means an actual or potential threat to the physical facilities of the public water supply which, although not dangerous to health, would constitute a nuisance or be aesthetically objectionable, or could cause damage to the system or its appurtenances. 
System means an actual or potential threat which may cause severe damage to the physical facilities of the public potable water supply system or which may have a protracted effect on the quality of the potable water in the system. 
(Ord. of 6-11-2002, § 1)  
Sec. 44-85. - Misdemeanor. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful and punishable as a misdemeanor for any person to bypass or remove a backflow prevention assembly without the approval of the Department. 
(b)  Each separate act or omission, which constitutes a violation, and each day's violation of a continuing nature, shall constitute a separate offense. 
(c)  The maximum fine for each offense hereof shall be $2,000.00. 
(Ord. of 6-11-2002, § 9)  
Sec. 44-86. - Customer service inspections. 
A customer service inspection certification shall be completed prior to providing continuous water service to new construction or any existing service when the City has reason to believe that cross connections or other unacceptable plumbing practices exist, or after any material improvement, correction, or addition has been made to the private plumbing facilities. 
(1)  Individuals with the following credentials shall be recognized as capable of conducting a customer service inspection certification. 
a.  Plumbing Inspectors and Water Supply Protection Specialists licensed by the State Board of Plumbing Examiners. 
b.  Certified Waterworks Operators and members of other related professional groups who have completed a training course and passed an examination administered by the Commission or its designated agent. 
c.  Licensed Plumbers, at the discretion of the water purveyor, may perform customer service inspections on single-family residential services. 
(2)  As unacceptable plumbing practices are discovered, they shall be promptly eliminated to prevent possible contamination of the water supplied by the public water system. The existence of a serious threat to the integrity of the public water supply shall be considered sufficient grounds for immediate termination of water service. Service can be restored only when the source of potential contamination no longer exists, or until sufficient additional safeguards have been taken. 
(3)  Copies of properly completed inspection certifications must be kept on file by the water purveyor and made available, upon request, for Commission review. These certifications shall be retained for a minimum of ten years and shall certify the following: 
a.  No direct connection between the public water supply and a potential source of contamination exist. Potential sources of contamination are isolated from the public water system by an air-gap or an appropriate backflow prevention assembly in accordance with state plumbing regulation. Additionally, all pressure relief valve and thermal expansion devices are in compliance with state plumbing codes. 
b.  No cross connection between the public drinking water supply and a private water source (e.g., wells) exists. Where an actual air-gap is maintained between the private and public water supply, an approved reduced pressure-zone backflow prevention assembly is properly installed and a service agreement exists for annual inspection and testing by the recognized backflow prevention assembly tester. See 30 Tex. Admin. Code § 290.44(4). 
c.  No connection exists which would allow the return of water used for condensing, cooling, or industrial process back to the public water supply. 
d.  No pipe or pipe fitting which contains more than eight percent lead exists in private plumbing facilities installed on or after July 1, 1998. 
e.  No solder or flux, which contains more than 0.2 percent lead, exists in private plumbing facilities installed on or after July 1, 1988. 
(Ord. of 6-11-2002, § 2)  
Sec. 44-87. - Interconnection. 
No physical connection between the distribution system of the public drinking water supply shall be permitted unless the other water supply is of safe, sanitary quality and the City approves the interconnection. 
(Ord. of 6-11-2002, § 3)  
Sec. 44-88. - Backflow prevention required. 
(a)  An approved backflow prevention assembly shall be utilized or installed at every service connection to a customer's water system when the City Water Department (Water Department or Department) determines the potable water supplied by the public potable water system may be subject to contamination, pollution or other deterioration in sanitary quality by conditions within the customer's water system. 
(b)  The backflow prevention assembly to be utilized or installed shall be the determination by the Water Department. The method required by the Department shall be sufficient to protect against the potential degree of hazard, as determined by the Department, to the public potable water supply from the customer's water system. 
(Ord. of 6-11-2002, § 4)  
Sec. 44-89. - Backflow prevention assemblies approved. 
(a)  A backflow prevention assembly shall be any assembly or other means designed to prevent backflow. The following are the recognized backflow prevention methods, which the Department requires: 
(1)  Air-gap. The unobstructed vertical distance through the free atmosphere between the opening of any pipe or faucet supplying portable water to a tank, plumbing fixture or other device and the flood level rim of said tank, plumbing fixture or other device. An air-gap should be at least double the diameter of the supply pipe or faucet and in no case less than one inch. 
(2)  Reduced pressure assembly (RP). An assembly containing two independently acting approved check valves together with hydraulically operating, mechanically independent pressure differential relief valve located between the check valves, and at the same time below the first check valve. The assembly shall include properly located test cocks and tightly closing shutoff valves at each end of the assembly. 
(3)  Double check valve assembly (DC). An assembly composed of two independently acting approved check valves, including tightly closing shutoff valves located at each end of the assembly and fitted with properly located text cocks. 
(4)  Pressure vacuum breaker assembly (PVB). An assembly containing an independently operating located check valve and an independently operated, loaded air inlet valve located on the discharge side of the check valve. The assembly shall be equipped with properly located test cocks and tightly closing shutoff valve located at each end of the assembly. 
(b)  Backflow prevention assemblies required for specified activities: 
(1)  Animal clinics/grooming shops: RP. 
(2)  Any premises where a cross-connection is maintained: RP. 
(3)  Automotive repair with steam cleaner, acid cleaning equipment, or solvent facilities: RP. 
(4)  Auxiliary water systems: RP. 
(5)  Bottling plants: RP. 
(6)  Breweries: RP. 
(7)  Buildings greater than three stories or greater than 34 feet in height from curb level: DC. 
(8)  Buildings with house pumps/or potable storage tank: DC. 
(9)  Buildings with landscape fountains, ponds, baptismal tanks: RP or Air-gap. 
(10)  Buildings with sewage ejectors: RP. 
(11)  Canaries, packing houses, reduction plants: RP. 
(12)  Car wash facilities: RP. 
(13)  Centralized heating and air-conditioning plants: RP. 
(14)  Chemical plants: RP. 
(15)  Chemically treated potable or non-potable water systems: RP. 
(16)  Civil works (Government owned or operated facilities not open for inspection by the Department): RP. 
(17)  Commercial laundries: RP. 
(18)  Dairies and cold storage plants: RP. 
(19)  Dye works: RP. 
(20)  Film processing laboratories: RP. 
(21)  Schools and colleges: RP. 
(22)  Holding tank disposal stations: RP. 
(23)  Hospitals and mortuaries: RP. 
(24)  Medical and dental buildings, sanitariums, rest and convalescent homes engaged in diagnosis, care or treatment of human illness: RP. 
(25)  Irrigation systems (not to include single-family detached residences): 
a.  Premises having separate systems used in elevated areas or with drip irrigation: RP. 
b.  Premises having nonpotable water piping (lawn sprinklers) two inches and smaller: PVB. 
(26)  Manufacturing, processing, and fabrication plants using toxic or nontoxic materials: RP. 
(27)  Laboratories using toxic materials: RP. 
(28)  Mobile home parks: DC. 
(29)  Multiple services, interconnected: DC. 
(30)  Oil/gas production facilities: RP. 
(31)  Paper and paper production plants: RP. 
(32)  Portable insecticide and herbicide spray tanks: RP or Air-gap. 
(33)  Power Plants: RP. 
(34)  Restricted, classified, or other closed facilities: RP. 
(35)  Sand and gravel plants: RP. 
(36)  Shopping centers: DC. 
(37)  Car wash facilities: An approved air-gap or a reduced pressure principal backflow prevention assembly shall be installed at the service connection to any premises where a car wash facility is operated or maintained. In addition, where a domestic water system is on the property and supplied by a single service connection an approved air-gap or a reduced pressure principal backflow prevention assembly shall be installed on the industrial line at the point of takeoff from the domestic line. Most automatic car washes utilize a recirculating system as well as soap or wash aspirating system. Coin-operated car washes shall provide backflow protection with installation of a reduced pressure principal backflow prevention assembly or an air-gap. 
(c)  When two or more of the activities listed in subsection (b) of this section are conducted on the same premises and served by the same service connection, the most restrictive backflow prevention method required for any of the activities conducted on the premises shall be required to be utilized or installed at the service connection. The order of the most restrictive backflow prevention methods shall be as follows: 
(1)  Air-gap (most restrictive). 
(2)  Reduced pressure principal assembly (RP). 
(3)  Pressure vacuum breaker assembly (PVB). 
(4)  Double check valve assembly (DC) (least restrictive). 
(Ord. of 6-11-2002, § 5)  
Sec. 44-90. - Backflow assembly installation requirements; location. 
(a)  Backflow prevention assemblies shall be installed by the customer, at the customer's expense and in compliance with the standards and specifications adopted by the City at the service connection. The assembly shall be installed, tested, and maintained by the owner. The signed and dated original inspection form must be submitted to the City within five working days of the test. 
(b)  The assembly shall be in an accessible location approved by the Department. A reduced pressure principal assembly and pressure vacuum breaker assembly shall be installed above ground. A double check valve assembly may be installed, at the service customer's option, below ground in a vault with standard specifications established by the City. 
(c)  When a customer desires a continuous water supply, two or more backflow prevention assemblies shall be installed to one another at the service connection to allow a continuous water supply during testing of the backflow prevention assemblies. When backflow prevention assemblies are installed parallel to one another, the sum of the areas of the diameters of the assemblies shall be at least equal to the area of the diameter of the service connection. 
(Ord. of 6-11-2002, § 7)  
Sec. 44-91. - Discontinuance of water service. 
(a)  If the Department discovers that a customer has not installed a required backflow prevention assembly, that a backflow prevention assembly has been improperly tested or maintained, bypassed or removed, or that an unprotected cross connection exists in the customer's water system, the water service to that service connection shall be disconnected if the situation is not remedied within the time specified in the notice sent to the customer as required by this section. The service shall not be restored until the condition is remedied. 
(b)  Prior to disconnecting any water service because a condition set forth in subsection (a) of this section exists, the Department shall send a notice to the customer that the condition must be remedied within 45 days after mailing of the notice by the City. If such condition is not remedied within said 45-day period, the City shall send a second notice, by certified mail, to the customer notifying the customer that water service will be disconnected in 15 days if the condition is not remedied within such time period. 
(c)  The City may disconnect, without notice, water service to any customer when the Department discovers that the customer's water system is contaminating the public water supply. 
(Ord. of 6-11-2002, § 8)  
Secs. 44-92—44-110. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - WASTEWATER 
 
Sec. 44-111. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Approving Authority means the City Manager or designee. 
BOD (Biochemical Oxygen Demand) means the quantity of oxygen by weight, expressed in mg/l, utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory conditions for five days at a temperature of 20 degrees centigrade. 
Building sewer means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal, also called the house lateral and house connection. 
City Manager means the City Manager or designee. 
COD (Chemical Oxygen Demand) means measure of the oxygen consuming capacity of inorganic and organic matter present in the water or wastewater expressed in mg/l as the amount of oxygen consumed from a chemical oxidant in a specific test, but not differentiating between stable and unstable organic matter and thus not necessarily correlating with biochemical oxygen demand. 
Control manhole means a manhole giving access to a building sewer at some point before the building sewer at some point before the building sewer discharge mixes with other discharges in the public sewer. 
Control point means point of access to a course of discharge before the discharge mixes with other discharges in the public sewer. 
Garbage means animal and vegetable wastes and residue from preparation, cooling and dispensing of food; and from the handling, processing, storage and sale of food products and produce. 
Industrial waste means waste resulting from any process of industry, manufacturing, trade, or business from the development of any natural resource, or any mixture of the waste with water or normal wastewater, or distinct from normal wastewater. 
Industrial waste charge means the charge made on those persons who discharge industrial waste into the city's sewerage system or wastewater facility. 
Milligrams per liter (mg/l) means the same as parts per million and is a weight-to-volume ratio; the milligram-per-liter value multiplied by the factor 8.34 shall be equivalent to pounds per million gallons of water. 
Natural outlet means any outlet into a watercourse, ditch, lake, or other body of surface water or groundwater. 
Normal domestic wastewater means wastewater excluding industrial wastewater discharged by a person into sanitary sewers and in which the average concentration of total suspended solids is not more than 250 mg/l and BOD is not more than 250 mg/l. 
Overload means the imposition of organic or hydraulic loading on a treatment facility in excess of its engineered design capacity. 
pH means the logarithm (base ten) of the reciprocal of the hydrogen ion concentration. 
Public sewer means pipe or conduit carrying wastewater or unpolluted drainage in which owners of abutting properties shall have the use, subject to control by the City. 
Sanitary sewer means a public sewer that conveys domestic wastewater or industrial wastes or a combination of both, and into which stormwater, surface water, groundwater, and other unpolluted wastes are not intentionally passed. 
Slug means any discharge of water, wastewater or industrial waste which in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow, exceeds for any period of duration longer than 15 minutes more than five times the average 24-hour concentration or flows during normal operation. 
Standard Methods means the examination and analytical procedures set forth in the latest edition, at the time of analysis, of "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater" as prepared, approved, and published jointly by the American Public Health Association, the American Water Works Association, and the Water Pollution Control Federation. 
Storm sewer means a public sewer which carries storm and surface water and drainage and into which domestic wastewater or industrial wastes are not intentionally passed. 
Stormwater means rainfall or any other forms of precipitation. 
Suspended solids (SS) means solids measured in mg/l that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in, water, wastewater, or other liquids, and which are largely, removable by a laboratory filtration device. 
To discharge includes to deposit, conduct, drain, emit, throw, run, allow to seep, or otherwise release or dispose of, or to allow, permit, or suffer any of these acts or omissions. 
Trap means a device designed to skim settle, or otherwise remove grease, oil, sand flammable wastes or other harmful substances. 
Unpolluted wastewater means water containing: 
(1)  No free or emulsified grease or oil; 
(2)  No acids or alkalis; 
(3)  No phenols or other substances producing taste or order in receiving water; 
(4)  No toxic or poisonous substances in suspension, colloidal state, or solution; 
(5)  No noxious or otherwise obnoxious or adorous gases; 
(6)  Not more than an insignificant amount in mg/l each of suspended solids and BOD, as determined by the State Department of Water Resources; and 
(7)  Color not exceeding 50 units as measured by the Platinum-Cobalt method of determination as specified in Standard Methods. 
Waste means rejected, unutilized or superfluous substances in liquid, gaseous, or solid form resulting from domestic, agricultural, or industrial activities. 
Wastewater means a combination of the water carried waste from residences, business buildings, institutions, and industrial establishments, together with any ground, surface, and stormwater that may be present. 
Wastewater facilities includes all facilities for collection, pumping, treating, and disposing of wastewater and industrial wastes. 
Wastewater service charge means the charge on all users of the public sewer system whose wastes do not exceed in strength the concentration values established as representative of normal wastewater. 
Wastewater treatment plant means any City-owned facilities, devices and structures used for receiving, processing and treating wastewater, industrial waste, and sludges from the sanitary sewers. 
Watercourse means a natural or manmade channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
(Ord. of 7-16-1986, § 1; Ord. No. 2019-10-1 , § 2, 10-15-2019)  
Sec. 44-112. - Penalty. 
In addition to proceeding under authority of section 1-13, the City is entitled to pursue all other criminal and civil remedies to which it is entitled under authority of statutes or other ordinances against a person continuing prohibited discharges. 
(Ord. of 7-16-1986, § 23)  
Sec. 44-113. - Failure to pay. 
In addition to sanctions provided for by this division, the City is entitled to exercise sanctions provided for by the other ordinances of the City for failure to pay the bill for water and sanitary sewer service when due. 
(Ord. of 7-16-1986, § 24)  
Sec. 44-114. - Penalty for criminal mischief. 
The City may pursue all criminal and civil remedies to which it is entitled under authority of statutes and ordinances against a person negligently, willfully or maliciously causing loss by tampering with or destroying public sewers or treatment facilities. 
(Ord. of 7-16-1986, § 25)  
Sec. 44-115. - Prohibited discharges. 
(a)  No person may discharge to public sewers any waste which by itself or by interaction with other wastes may: 
(1)  Injure or interfere with wastewater treatment processes or facilities; 
(2)  Constitute a hazard to humans or animals; or 
(3)  Create a hazard in receiving waters of the wastewater treatment plant effluent. 
(b)  All discharges shall conform to the requirements of this division. 
(Ord. of 7-16-1986, § 2)  
Sec. 44-116. - Chemical discharges. 
(a)  No discharge to public sewers may contain: 
(1)  Cyanide greater than 1.0 mg/l; 
(2)  Fluoride other than that contained in the public water supply; 
(3)  Chlorides in concentrations greater than 250 mg/l; 
(4)  Gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil, or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid or gas; or 
(5)  Substances causing an excessive Chemical Oxygen Demand (COD). 
(b)  No waste or wastewater discharged to public waters may contain: 
(1)  Strong acid, iron pickling wastes, or concentrated plating solutions whether neutralized or not; 
(2)  Fats, wax, grease, or oils whether emulsified or not, in excess of 100 mg/l or containing substances which may solidify or become viscous at temperature between 32 and 150 degrees Fahrenheit (0 and 65 degrees centigrade); 
(3)  Objectionable or toxic substances, an exerting and excessive chlorine requirement, to such degree that any such material received in the composite wastewater treatment works exceeds the limits established by the Approving Authority for such materials; or 
(4)  Obnoxious, toxic or poisonous solids, liquids, or gases in quantities sufficient to violate the provisions of section 44-115(a). 
(c)  No waste, wastewater, or other substance may be discharged into public sewers which has a pH lower than 5.5 or higher than 9.5 or any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment, and/or personnel at the wastewater facilities. 
(d)  All waste, wastewater, or other substance containing phenols, hydrogen sulfide, or other taste-and-odor producing substance, shall conform to concentration limits established by the Approving Authority. After treatment of the composite wastewater, concentration limits may not exceed the requirements established by State, federal, or other agencies with jurisdiction over discharges to receiving waters. 
(Ord. of 7-16-1986, § 3)  
Sec. 44-117. - Hazardous metals and toxic materials. 
(a)  No discharges may contain concentrations of hazardous metals other than amounts specified in subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  The allowable concentrations of hazardous metals, in terms of milligrams per liter (mg/l), for discharge to inland waters, and determined on the basis of individual sampling in accordance with Standard Methods are: 
Metal 	Not To Exceed 
	Average 	Daily Composite 	Grab Sample 
Arsenic 	0.1 	0.2 	0.3 
Barium 	1.0 	2.0 	4.0 
Cadmium 	0.05 	0.1 	0.2 
Chromium 	0.5 	1.0 	5.0 
Copper 	0.5 	1.0 	2.0 
Lead 	0.5 	1.0 	1.5 
Manganese 	1.0 	2.0 	3.0 
Mercury 	0.005 	0.005 	0.01 
Nickel 	1.0 	2.0 	3.0 
Selenium 	0.05 	0.1 	0.2 
Silver 	0.05 	0.1 	0.2 
Zinc 	1.0 	2.0 	6.0 
 
Note— These concentration parameters and rules governing same are promulgated under authority of V.T.C.A., Water Code §§ 5.127, 5.132 - HAZARDOUS METALS and in accordance with rules established by the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality) 
(c)  No other hazardous metals or toxic materials may be discharged into public sewers without approval from the Approving Authority specifying conditions of pretreatment, concentrations, volumes, and other applicable provisions. 
(d)  Prohibited hazardous materials include, but are not limited to: 
(1)  Antimony; 
(2)  Beryllium; 
(3)  Bismuth; 
(4)  Cobalt; 
(5)  Molybdenum; 
(6)  Uranium; 
(7)  Rhenium; 
(8)  Strontium; 
(9)  Tellerium; 
(10)  Herbicides; 
(11)  Fungicides; and 
(12)  Pesticides. 
(Ord. of 7-16-1986, § 4)  
Sec. 44-118. - Particulate size. 
(a)  No person may discharge garbage or other solids into public sewers unless it is shredded to a degree that all particles can be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers. Particles greater than one-half inch in any dimensions are prohibited. 
(b)  The Approving Authority is entitled to review and approve the installation and operation of any garbage grinder equipped with a motor of three-fourths horsepower (0.76 hp metric) or greater. 
(Ord. of 7-16-1986, § 5)  
Sec. 44-119. - Stormwater and other unpolluted drainage. 
(a)  No person may discharge to public sanitary sewers: 
(1)  Unpolluted stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff or subsurface drainage; 
(2)  Unpolluted cooling water; 
(3)  Unpolluted industrial process waters; 
(4)  Other unpolluted drainage; or 
(5)  Make any new connections from inflow sources. 
(b)  In compliance with the Texas Water Quality Act (V.T.C.A., Water Code, § 21.001 et seq.) and other statutes, the Approving Authority may designate storm sewers and other watercourses into which unpolluted drainage described in subsection (a) of this section may be discharged. 
(Ord. of 7-16-1986, § 6)  
Sec. 44-120. - Temperature. 
No person may discharge liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than 150 degrees Fahrenheit (65 degrees centigrade), or any substance which causes the temperature of the total wastewater treatment plant influent to increase at a rate of ten degrees Fahrenheit or more per hour, or a combined total increase of plant influent to 110 degrees Fahrenheit. 
(Ord. of 7-16-1986, § 7)  
Sec. 44-121. - Radioactive wastes. 
(a)  No person may discharge radioactive wastes or isotopes into public sewers without the permission of the Approving Authority. 
(b)  The Approving Authority may establish, in compliance with applicable State and federal regulations, regulations for discharge of radioactive wastes into public sewers. 
(Ord. of 7-16-1986, § 8)  
Sec. 44-122. - Impairment of facilities. 
(a)  No person may discharge into public sewers any substance capable of causing: 
(1)  Obstruction to the flow in sewers; 
(2)  Interference with the operation of treatment process of facilities; or 
(3)  Excessive loading of treatment facilities. 
(b)  Discharges prohibited by subsection (a) of this section include, but are not limited to, materials which exert or cause concentrations of: 
(1)  Inert suspended solids greater than 250 mg/l including, but not limited to: 
a.  Fuller's earth; 
b.  Lime slurries; and 
c.  Lime residues; 
(2)  Dissolved solids greater than 500 mg/l including, but not limited to: 
a.  Sodium chloride; and 
b.  Sodium sulfate; 
(3)  Excessive discoloration including, but not limited to: 
a.  Dye wastes; and 
b.  Vegetable tanning solutions; or 
(4)  BOD, COD, or chlorine demand in excess of normal plant capacity. 
(c)  No person may discharge into public sewers any substance that may: 
(1)  Deposit grease or oil in the sewer lines in such a manner as to clog the sewers; 
(2)  Overload skimming and grease handling equipment; 
(3)  Pass to the receiving waters without being effectively treated by normal wastewater treatment processes due to the nonamenability of the substance to bacterial action; or 
(4)  Deleteriously affect the treatment process due to excessive quantities. 
(d)  No person may discharge any substance into public sewers which: 
(1)  Is not amenable to treatment or reduction by the processes and facilities employed; or 
(2)  Is amenable to treatment only to such a degree that the treatment plant effluent cannot meet the requirements of other agencies having jurisdiction over discharge to the receiving waters. 
(e)  The Approving Authority shall regulate the flow and concentration of slugs when they may: 
(1)  Impair the treatment process; 
(2)  Cause damage to collection facilities; 
(3)  Incur treatment costs exceeding those for normal wastewater; or 
(4)  Render the effluent unfit for stream disposal or industrial use. 
(f)  No person may discharge into public sewers solid or viscous substances which may violate subsection (a) of this section if present in sufficient quantity or size including, but not limited to: 
(1)  Ashes. 
(2)  Cinders. 
(3)  Sand. 
(4)  Mud. 
(5)  Straw. 
(6)  Shavings. 
(7)  Metal. 
(8)  Glass. 
(9)  Rags. 
(10)  Feathers. 
(11)  Tar. 
(12)  Plastics. 
(13)  Wood. 
(14)  Underground garbage. 
(15)  Whole blood. 
(16)  Paunch manure. 
(17)  Hair and fleshings. 
(18)  Entrails. 
(19)  Paper products, either whole or ground by garbage grinders. 
(20)  Slops. 
(21)  Chemical residues. 
(22)  Paint residues. 
(23)  Bulk solids. 
(g)  No person may collect, dispose, or discharge industrial waste into a wastewater facility unless the following requirements are met: 
(1)  A person seeking to collect, dispose, or discharge industrial waste into a wastewater facility must obtain a permit from the Approving Authority; 
(2)  The industrial waste must not contain any chemical, hazardous, toxic, or otherwise prohibited materials under this chapter; 
(3)  Must pay the required industrial waste charge as provided under section 44-129; and 
(4)  The industrial waste must be transported at no cost to the City to a wastewater facility designated by the Approving Authority. 
(h)  A non-transferable permit allowing a person to collect, dispose, or discharge industrial waste into a wastewater facility may be issued by the Approving Authority if the following requirements are met: 
(1)  The applicant must complete an application provided by the Approving Authority; 
(2)  Submit with the application a copy of the application's current registration issued by the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality, pursuant to 30 TAC § 312.142, to collect and transport liquid waste; 
(3)  Submit with the application a copy of the state registration license receipt issued to each vehicle that applicant wants to register under this permit; 
(4)  Submit with the application proof that the applicant's vehicles which will be registered under this permit are insured in at least the minimum amounts as required by state law, or under self-insured as provided by state law to secure payment of all lawful and proper claims arising out of the operation of each vehicle; and 
(5)  Submit payment for permit fee. 
(i)  An applicant who has been denied a permit to collect, dispose, or discharge industrial waste into a wastewater facility may submit a written appeal within 30 days to the City Council, and shall have the opportunity to present evidence and oral argument during a regular City Council meeting following the 30-day appeal period. In the event that an applicant files an appeal, the Approving Authority shall prepare and submit to the City Council a written report outlining its reasons for denying the requested permit. 
(j)  The City Council shall set a permit fee for each registered vehicle. 
(k)  The Approving Authority shall number the permits consecutively, and each permit holder shall cause to be displayed on each side of each vehicle in a color contrasting with the background in three-inch letters or larger the business name, state regulatory authority registration number and the regulatory authority's permit number. 
(l)  The permit holder shall keep the permit receipt, or a copy, in the vehicle at all times. 
(Ord. of 7-16-1986, § 9; Ord. No. 2019-10-01, § 2, 10-15-2019)  
Sec. 44-123. - Compliance with existing authority. 
(a)  Unless exception is granted by the Approving Authority, the public sanitary sewer system regulations shall apply to all persons discharging: 
(1)  Wastewater; 
(2)  Industrial waste; 
(3)  Polluted liquids. 
(b)  Unless authorized by the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality no person may deposit or discharge any waste included in subsection (a) of this section on public or private property or into or adjacent to any: 
(1)  Natural outlet; 
(2)  Watercourse; 
(3)  Storm sewer; 
(4)  Other area within the jurisdiction of the City. 
(c)  The Approving Authority shall verify prior to discharge that wastes authorized to be discharged will receive suitable treatment within the provisions of laws, regulations, ordinances, rules and orders of federal, State and local governments. 
(Ord. of 7-16-1986, § 10)  
Sec. 44-124. - Approving Authority. 
(a)  If discharges or proposed discharges to public sewers may deleteriously affect wastewater facilities, processes, equipment, or receiving waters; create a hazard to life or health; or create a public nuisance, the Approving Authority shall require: 
(1)  Pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to the public sewers; 
(2)  Control over the quantities and rates of discharge; and 
(3)  Payment to cover the cost of handling and treating the wastes. 
(b)  The Approving Authority is entitled to determine whether a discharge or proposed discharge is included under subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  The Approving Authority shall reject wastes when it determines that a discharge or proposed discharge does not meet the requirements of subsection (a) of this section. 
(d)  The Approving Authority has the sole discretion to suspend or terminate, without notice, the collection, disposal, or discharge of industrial waste by authorized third parties under section 44-122 of this chapter, as amended, at any wastewater facility, when such suspension or termination is for the protection, health, or safety of the general public and public facilities. 
(Ord. of 7-16-1986, § 11; Ord. No. 2019-10-01 , § 3, 10-15-2019)  
Sec. 44-125. - Approving Authority review and approval. 
(a)  If pretreatment or control is required, the Approving Authority shall review and approve design and installation of equipment and processes. 
(b)  The design and installation of equipment and processes must conform to all applicable statutes, codes, ordinances and other laws. 
(c)  Any person responsible for discharges requiring pretreatment, flow equalizing, or other facilities shall provide and maintain the facilities in effect operating condition at his own expense. 
(Ord. of 7-16-1986, § 12)  
Sec. 44-126. - Requirements for traps. 
(a)  Discharges requiring a trap include: 
(1)  Grease or waste containing grease in amounts that will impede or stop the flow in the public sewers; 
(2)  Oil; 
(3)  Sand; 
(4)  Flammable wastes; and 
(5)  Other harmful ingredients. 
(b)  Any person responsible for discharges requiring a trap shall at his own expense and as required by the Approving Authority: 
(1)  Provide equipment and facilities of a type and capacity approved by the Approving Authority; 
(2)  Locate the trap in a manner that provides ready and easy accessibility for cleaning inspection; and 
(3)  Maintain the trap in effective operating condition. 
(Ord. of 7-16-1986, § 13)  
Sec. 44-127. - Requirement for building sewers. 
Any person responsible for discharges through a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall, at his own expense and as required by the Approving Authority: 
(1)  Install an accessible control manhole; 
(2)  Install meters and other appurtenances to facilitate observation sampling and measurement of the waste; 
(3)  Install safety equipment and facilities (e.g., ventilation, steps) where needed; and 
(4)  Maintain the equipment and facilities. 
(Ord. of 7-16-1986, § 14)  
Sec. 44-128. - Sampling and testing. 
(a)  Sampling shall be conducted according to customarily accepted methods, reflecting the effect of constituents upon the sewage works and determining the existence of hazards to health, life, limb, and property. (Note: The particular analysis involved will determine whether a 24-hour composite sample from all outfalls of a premise is appropriate or whether a grab sample or samples should be taken. Normally, but not always, BOD and suspended solids analyses are obtained from 24-hour composites of all outfalls. Where applicable, 16-hour, eight-hour or some other period may be required. Periodic grab samples are used to determine pH and oil and grease.) 
(b)  Examination and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes required by this division shall be: 
(1)  Conducted in accordance with the latest edition of Standard Methods; and 
(2)  Determined from suitable samples taken at the control manhole provided or other control point authorized by the Approving Authority. 
(c)  BOD and suspended solids shall be determined from composite sampling, except to detect unauthorized discharges. 
(d)  The Approving Authority shall determine which users or classes of users may contribute wastewater which is of greater strength than normal domestic wastewater. All users or classes of users so identified shall be sampled for flow BOD, TSS and pH at least annually. 
(e)  The City may select an independent firm or laboratory to determine flow, BOD, and suspended solids, if necessary. Flow may alternately be determined by water meter measurements if no other flow device is available and no other source of raw water is used. 
(Ord. of 7-16-1986, § 15)  
Sec. 44-129. - User charge system. 
(a)  Persons making discharges of industrial waste into the City wastewater collection and/or disposal system, including the wastewater treatment plant, shall pay a charge designated by the Approving Authority and approved by the City Council. 
(b)  When discharges of any waste into the City system are approved by the Approving Authority, the City or its authorized representatives shall enter into an arrangement providing: 
(1)  Terms of acceptance by the City; 
(2)  Payment by the person making the discharge, in accordance with the user charge system as established in subsection (e) of this section; 
(3)  Sewer connection procedures and requirements shall be in accordance with the Uniform Plumbing Code as promulgated by the International Association of Plumbing and Mechanical Officials; 
(4)  A sewer application approved with connection fee paid; and 
(5)  Construction of sewer connections shall be approved by City inspectors prior to sewer use. 
(c)  Each user of the wastewater treatment system will be notified at least annually, in conjunction with a regular sewer bill, of the rate and that portion of user charges which are attributable to the operation and maintenance of the wastewater treatment system. 
(d)  The City will apply excess revenues collected from a class of users to the cost of operation and maintenance attributable to that class for the next year and adjust the rates accordingly. 
(e)  User charge rates. There shall be a charge for sanitary sewer service in the City for each month. 
(Ord. of 7-16-1986, § 16; Ord. of 6-13-2001, § I; Ord. No. 2019-10-01 , § 4, 10-15-2019)  
Sec. 44-130. - Continuation. 
A person discharging wastes into public sewers prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this division is derived may continue without penalty so long as he: 
(1)  Does not increase the quantity or decrease the quality of discharge without permission of the Approving Authority; 
(2)  Has discharged the waste at least six months prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this division is derived; 
(3)  Complies with section 44-131. 
(Ord. of 7-16-1986, § 17)  
Sec. 44-131. - Condition. 
(a)  The City may grant permission to discharge to persons meeting all requirements of section 44-130 provided that the person: 
(1)  Submits an application within 120 days after the effective date of the ordinance from which this division is derived on forms supplied by the Approving Authority; 
(2)  Secures approval by the Approving Authority of plans and specifications for the facilities when required; 
(3)  Has complied with all requirements for agreements or arrangements including, but not limited to, provisions for: 
a.  Payment of charges; 
b.  Installation and operation of the facilities and of pretreatment facilities, if required; 
c.  Sampling and analysis to determine quantity and strength when directed by the City; and 
(4)  Provides a sampling point, when requested by the City, subject to the provisions of this division and approval of the Approving Authority. 
(b)  A person applying for a new discharge shall meet all conditions of subsection (a) of this section. 
(Ord. of 7-16-1986, § 18)  
Sec. 44-132. - Power to enter property. 
(a)  The City Manager or designee and other duly authorized employees of the City bearing proper credentials and identification are entitled to enter any public or private property at any reasonable time for the purpose of enforcing this division. 
(b)  Anyone acting under this authority shall observe the establishment's rules and regulations concerning safety, internal security, and fire protection. 
(c)  Except when caused by negligence or failure of person to maintain safe conditions, the City shall indemnify the person against loss or damage to their property by City employees and against liability claims and demands for personal injury or property damage asserted against the person and growing out of the conduct of the City employees conducting sampling operation. 
(d)  The City Manager or designee and other duly authorized employees of the City bearing proper credentials and identification are entitled to enter all private properties through which the City holds a negotiated easement for the purpose of: 
(1)  Inspection, observation, measurement, sampling or repair; 
(2)  Maintenance of any portion of the sewerage system lying within the easements; and 
(3)  Conducting any other authorized activity. All activities shall be conducted in full accordance with the terms of the negotiated easement pertaining to the private property involved. 
(e)  No person acting under authority of this provision may inquire into any processes including metal surgical, chemical, oil, refining, ceramic, paper or other industries beyond that point having a direct bearing on the kind and source of discharge to the public sewers. 
(Ord. of 7-16-1986, § 19)  
Sec. 44-133. - Authority to disconnect service. 
(a)  The City may terminate water and wastewater disposal service and disconnect a customer from the system when: 
(1)  Acids or chemicals which may damage the sewer lines or treatment process are released to the sewer, potentially causing accelerated deterioration of these structures or interfering with proper conveyance and treatment of wastewater; 
(2)  A governmental agency informs the City that the effluent from the wastewater treatment plant is no longer of a quality permitted for discharge to a wastewater, and it is found that the customer is delivering wastewater to the City's system that cannot be sufficiently treated or requires treatment that is not provided by the City as normal domestic treatment; or 
(3)  The customer: 
a.  Discharges waste or wastewater that is in violation of the permit issued by the Approving Authority; 
b.  Discharges wastewater at an uncontrolled, variable rate in sufficient quantity to cause an imbalance in the wastewater treatment system; 
c.  Fails to pay monthly bills for water and sanitary sewer services when due; or 
d.  Repairs a discharge of prohibited wastes to public sewers in violation of sections 44-115 through 44-122. 
(b)  If service is discontinued pursuant to subsection (a)(2) of this section, the City shall: 
(1)  Disconnect the customer; 
(2)  Supply the customer with the governmental agency's report and provide the customer with all pertinent information; and 
(3)  Continue disconnection until such time as the customer provides pretreatment/additional pretreatment or other facilities designed to remove the objectionable characteristics from its wastes. 
(Ord. of 7-16-1986, § 20)  
Sec. 44-134. - Notice. 
Except as provided under amended subsection 44-124(d), the City shall serve persons discharging in violation of this division with written notice stating the nature of the violation and providing a reasonable time limit for satisfactory compliance. 
(Ord. of 7-16-1986, § 21; Ord. No. 2019-10-01 , § 5, 10-15-2019)  
Sec. 44-135. - Continuing prohibited discharges. 
No person may continue discharging in violation of this division beyond the time limit provided in the notice. 
(Ord. of 7-16-1986, § 22)  
Secs. 44-136—44-153. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - WATER USE REDUCTION 
 
Sec. 44-154. - Drought contingency plan. 
The City of Pearsall, Texas, drought contingency plan attached to the ordinance from which this division was derived and which is on file in the City offices and incorporated herein for all intents and purposes, and made part hereof for all purposes be, and the same is hereby, adopted as the official policy of the City. 
(Ord. of 9-13-2000, § 1; Ord. of 9-6-2011)  
Sec. 44-155. - Implementation. 
The Mayor and the City Council hereby designates the City Manager to implement the applicable provisions of the drought contingency plan upon determination that such implementation is necessary to protect the public health, safety, and welfare. 
(Ord. No. 2015-08-01, § 1, 8-11-2015)  
Sec. 44-156. - City Manager designated. 
The Mayor and the City Council designates and authorizes the City Manager to initiate or terminate drought or other water supply emergency response measures as described in the drought contingency plan. 
(Ord. No. 2015-08-01, § 2, 8-11-2015)  
Sec. 44-157. - Enforcement. 
The Mayor and the City Council hereby designates and authorizes the following City personnel to enforce and to issue citations for violations of the applicable provisions of the drought contingency plan: 
(1)  City Manager. 
(2)  City Code Enforcement Officers. 
(3)  Public Works Director. 
(4)  Water system supervisors. 
(5)  Water system assistants to supervisors. 
(6)  City Police Department law enforcement officers. 
(Ord. No. 2015-08-01, § 3, 8-11-2015)  
Sec. 44-158. - Sole authority. 
The Mayor and City Council shall retain their sole authority to modify the drought contingency plan. 
(Ord. No. 2015-08-01, § 4, 8-11-2015)  
Secs. 44-159—44-176. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - WELL PROTECTION 
 
Sec. 44-177. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Wells means the water wells owned and operated by the City, which are more specifically identified and described in exhibit A attached and made a part of the ordinance from which this article was derived. 
(Ord. of 4-28-2003, § 2)  
Sec. 44-178. - Purpose. 
(a)  This article sets forth uniform requirements for the uses and the construction of facilities in or on land within 150 feet of the wells in order to promote sanitary conditions in and around such wells, to secure all such land from pollution hazards, and to enable the City to comply with all applicable State and local regulations. 
(b)  The objective of this article is to prevent certain uses and the construction of facilities in or on land surrounding the wells, which might create a danger of pollution to the water produced from such wells. 
(Ord. of 4-28-2003, § 1)  
Sec. 44-179. - Prohibited activities. 
The following activities are prohibited within the designated areas of land surrounding the wells: 
(1)  Construction and/or operation of underground petroleum and/or chemical storage tanks and liquid transmission pipelines, stock pens, feedlots, dump grounds, privies, cesspools, septic tanks, sewage treatment drainfields, absorption beds, evapotranspiration beds, improperly constructed water wells of any depth, and all other construction or operation that could create an unsanitary condition is prohibited within, upon, or across all areas of land within a 150-foot radius of the wells. For the purposes of this article, improperly constructed water wells are those wells that do not meet the surface and subsurface construction standards for a public of the wells. 
(2)  Construction of tile or concrete sanitary sewers, sewer appurtenances, septic tanks, storm sewers, and cemeteries is specifically prohibited within, upon, or across any area of land within a 50-foot radius of the wells. 
(3)  Construction of homes or buildings upon any area of land within a 150-foot radius of the wells is permitted, provided the restrictions described in subsections (1) and (2) of this section are met. 
(4)  Normal farming and ranching operations are not prohibited by this article; provided, however, livestock shall not be allowed within a 50-foot radius of the wells. 
(Ord. of 4-28-2003, § 3)  
Sec. 44-180. - Right of entry. 
City employees, or authorized representatives of the City, bearing proper credentials and identification, shall be permitted to immediately enter upon any premises located within a 150-foot radius of any well to conduct any inspection or observation necessary to enforce this article. 
(Ord. of 4-28-2003, § 4)  
Secs. 44-181—44-201. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - GAS SERVICE 
 
Sec. 44-202. - Director of Public Works. 
(a)  There shall be appointed by the City Manager a Director of Public Works, who shall be the administrative officer of the gas distribution system. The Director of Public Works shall have general supervision over all employees of the gas distribution system and shall be responsible for all property, machinery, and equipment used in, or connected with, the gas distribution system, including, but not limited to, gas station apparatus pipe lines, meters, wrenches, testing equipment and all gas inventory. He shall make frequent trips of inspection, as may be necessary from time to time, over all pipe lines and all other property used in or connected with the gas distribution system, and shall direct repairs deemed necessary and consistent with his duties. 
(b)  He shall also report all violations of this article to the City Manager or his designated representative and the City Manager shall forthwith proceed to prosecute offenders as set forth in this article or any amendment hereto. He shall also control the gas pressure supply and at all times ensure the sufficiency thereof and shall, except in cases of emergency, notify the City Manager or his designated representative, whenever he learns of the necessity to shut off the gas from any line of the system for the purpose of making repairs, extensions, connections, etc. The Director shall inspect and reinspect all such house piping, appliances, fixtures, and apparatus and the installation, construction, alteration or repair thereof whenever and as often as he shall deem it necessary in order to minimize danger of fires and accidents or injuries to persons or property; and the said City Plumbing Inspector and his assistants are hereby authorized, empowered and directed to cause enforcement thereof to be such as not to cause fire or accidents or injury to life or property. 
(c)  In the performance of his duties as required by this section, the Director shall be subject at all times to the ordinance from which this article is derived and the rules and regulations of the City. He shall serve for such term and receive such compensation as may be fixed by the City Manager. 
(d)  It shall hereafter be unlawful for any person to do, commit, or assist in committing or doing, any of the following things or acts within the corporate limits of the City: 
(1)  Opening and closing valves or stopcocks. To open or close any valve or stopcock connected to the gas distribution system of the City without the permission of the Director of Public Works, except in case of fire, and then under the direction of officers of the Fire Department. 
(2)  Injuring, destroying, etc., property of the gas distribution system. To interfere with, destroy, deface, impair, injure, or wantonly force open any valve gate or stopcock, or in any way whatsoever injure or destroy any of the buildings, appurtenances, fences, fixtures or property pertaining to the gas distribution system. 
(3)  To resort to any fraudulent device or arrangements for the purpose of procuring gas for himself or others from private connection on premises contrary to the City regulations or ordinance from which this article is derived. 
(4)  To interfere with or injure any reservoir, cock, valve, or other apparatus pertaining to the gas distribution system, or to turn on or off without authority the gas in any street valve or other gas fixtures, or to hitch or tie an animal thereto. 
(5)  To make or permit to be made any connections with the main or service pipes of the gas distribution system, or to turn off or on the use of the gas of said system without first obtaining a permit therefor. 
(6)  To remove any gas meter that has been placed by the City or in any manner change, interfere with or tamper with any gas meter, providing that the provisions of this section shall not apply to the employees of the City when acting in their official capacity; except to effect repairs in an emergency (e.g., home owner, plumbing). 
(7)  To turn on the gas supply to any building or to any supply pipe where the supply has been turned off for the nonpayment of the monthly charge or for the violation of any rule or ordinance governing the gas distribution system. 
(Ord. of 7-25-1983(1), § 2)  
Sec. 44-203. - Tapping fee. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to make any connection to the mains or pipes of the gas distribution system of the City without first making application to the City, stating fully the several and various uses for which gas is requested, and upon the payment of the tapping fee, the Director shall make, or have made, the necessary connections and furnish a cut-off valve, meter and meter couplings, the cost of which is included in the tapping fee, and every premises connected with any gas main or being supplied with any gas from the gas distribution system shall have a separate service connection. All fees and charges shall be paid for at amounts and rates fixed by this article or by resolution of the City Manager. 
(Ord. of 7-25-1983(1), § 3)  
Sec. 44-204. - Gas leaks. 
It shall be the duty of all employees of the City to report to the Director of Public Works, any leaks or unnecessary waste of gas that may come to their attention, and any violations of this article. 
(Ord. of 7-25-1983(1), § 6)  
Sec. 44-205. - Meter. 
All gas meters shall be set by employees of the City. If the meter gets out of order and fails to operate and register, the consumer will be charged at the average daily consumption, as shown by the meter when it was in order. 
(Ord. of 7-25-1983(1), § 7)  
Sec. 44-206. - Minimum monthly charge. 
Each consumer of gas living in a separate house must have a separate connection and meter for each house. Except, that where a residence is not within reach of the City gas main, arrangements may be made, at the option of the City, to secure gas from another user of City gas, in which case, the minimum monthly charge shall be made for each additional residence taking gas through such meter. The regular minimum, the additional minimum and all gas used over the minimum by such consumer shall be charged to the customer having the meter. 
(Ord. of 7-25-1983(1), § 8)  
Sec. 44-207. - No refund. 
None of the tap fees or one-time rental fees as herein provided shall be refundable to the consumer upon termination of the gas service. 
(Ord. of 7-25-1983(1), § 12)  
Sec. 44-208. - Pipe extension. 
For each service connection tap on noncommercial, permanent, single-family dwellings within the corporate limits of the City constructed in accordance with the City housing code, the gas distribution system shall furnish, if necessary, 200 feet of pipe extension, or pipe extension to the service connection property line, whichever is less, at no charge to the consumer. If more than 200 feet of pipe extension are necessary, the customer will pay for the difference at actual cost. Any customer desiring gas service outside the City limits will be required to furnish all pipe materials and labor needed. The construction of gas mains and service lines shall be exercised only by City personnel and under no circumstances shall a private citizen handle repairs and/or construction of gas mains and service lines. An exception to this case shall be only when a private contractor has a written contract with the City. The customers desiring gas service outside the City limits shall comply with all of the rules and regulations herein provided or the service will not be extended. 
(Ord. of 7-25-1983(1), § 13)  
Sec. 44-209. - Standards. 
That hereafter all pipes placed for the convenience of natural gas in any house, residence, building or structure in the City or connected to the gas distribution system shall meet the Natural Gas Pipeline Safety Act (49 USC 60101) and Safety Rules and Regulations of the Railroad Commission of Texas Gas Utilities Division (16 Tex. Admin. Code § 8.1 et seq.). 
(1)  Steel pipe. All pipe used for the installation, extension, alteration, or repair of any gas piping shall be new, standard weight wrought iron black steel, or galvanized steel, free from splits, internal obstructions, or other defects. Burred ends shall be reamed to the full bore of the pipe. 
(2)  Thermoplastic pipe shall be ASTM specification D2513 "Standard Specification for Thermoplastic Gas Pressure pipe, tubing and fittings." 
(3)  All materials, fittings, valves and methods of installation of all natural gas lines in the City must also conform to the specifications mentioned in chapter 22 of the City plumbing code as passed by the City Council on May 11, 1967. 
(Ord. of 7-25-1983(1), § 14)  
Sec. 44-210. - Inspections. 
Permits, fees and inspections regarding installation of natural gas piping and fittings shall be as set out in chapter 19 of the City plumbing code. 
(Ord. of 7-25-1983(1), § 15)  
Sec. 44-211. - Turn off for inspection. 
Whenever any alterations or repairs are made in any line or gas pipe leading from the meter to any house, residence or structure or any fitting therein, except setting stoves or lights and necessary fittings, the gas shall be turned off, and shall not be again turned on until inspected as provided in section 44-210 and approved. 
(Ord. of 7-25-1983(1), § 16)  
Sec. 44-212. - Permit required. 
It is unlawful for anyone not having a permit from the City Plumbing Inspector to turn gas on or off at, or to interfere in any way with, the meter or regulator. 
(Ord. of 7-25-1983(1), § 17)  
Sec. 44-213. - Plumbing regulations. 
(a)  After all pipes placed for the conveyance of natural gas in any house, residence, building or structure in the City shall be of sizes as follows, for houses of five rooms or less: 
(1)  Main line to meter: one inch. 
(2)  Meter to small boiler or furnace: not less than 1¼ inch. 
(3)  Meter to first opening, three fires or less: one inch. 
(4)  Meter to first opening, more than three fires: one inch. 
(5)  First to second opening: one inch. 
(6)  Second to fourth opening: three-quarter inch. 
(b)  For houses of five to ten rooms the pipe from main line to meter small be 1½ inch. 
(c)  All fittings used in any such houses, buildings, or structure, shall be of safe design, all pipes shall be wrought iron and all fittings malleable iron, brass or bronze and shall be free from defects. Every connection of pipe and fittings shall be made by the joining by means of thread or iron pipe, brass, or bronze fittings. All space heaters must be connected with Fire Underwriters approved connections. 
(d)  Bushings must not be used. 
(e)  Three-way valves are not permitted in any case. 
(f)  Unions or running thread shall not be used on concealed gas piping, either in original installations or repair. 
(g)  When necessary to connect two sizes of pipe, a reducing coupling shall be used. 
(h)  All branch outlet pipes shall be taken from top or sides of main supply lines and never from below. 
(i)  No paint, cement, preparation of dope of any kind shall be used on said pipe or fittings to close cracks, openings or defects, except pure white lead shall be used on the threads of every joint connected, or other approved thread lubricants. 
(j)  Ranges, hot plates, etc., used in hotels, restaurants, and hamburger stands, where gas is used for fuel, must be provided with canopies properly vented into brick, tile, or metal flues extending to open air at least two feet above the roof. 
(k)  Vents to gas appliances, concealed inside of partitions, under floors or enclosed in any manner so that the said vent pipes are in contact with wood, shall be air tight, and shall be made of at least No. 22 gauge galvanized iron, and properly covered with asbestos paper. 
(l)  Vent pipes in attics may connect with a flue; or extend through the roof to open air at least two feet above the roof, and terminate with a screened cap. Such vent pipes in attics and above roof shall be of at least No. 22 gauge galvanized iron; exposed vent pipes in rooms of at least No. 26 gauge galvanized or black iron. 
(m)  Wood partitions through which vent pipes pass must be protected by a thimble with a proper air space, except that no vent pipe shall pass through any closet or pantry used for the storage of clothing household goods, or any combustible material. 
(n)  Water heaters and gas appliances having pilot burners must be provided with down draft devices above the fixture in the vent, near the appliances. 
(o)  Plumbers and gas fitters stopping vents in walls or in attics will be subject to the penalty as specified in section 1-13. 
(Ord. of 7-25-1983(1), § 18)  
Sec. 44-214. - Test. 
When the fitter has completed the system of piping and has all branch and bracket extensions and heater openings firmly and permanently fastened, he shall test the piping and if found tight shall make application for test with the City Plumbing Inspector. The Plumbing Inspector, or one of his assistants, will call and inspect the piping and witness the test, and if he finds the piping tight and the sizes and work in accordance with the provisions of this article then the City Plumbing Inspector or such assistant will deliver the meter connect fitting. 
(Ord. of 7-25-1983(1), § 19)  
Secs. 44-215—44-240. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - FACILITIES 
 
Sec. 44-241. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
City means the City of Pearsall as a governmental entity and utility purvey or that locates, installs, owns, operates, repairs, replaces, adjusts, relocates, maintains and/or removes utility facilities. 
Person means any individual, partnership, joint venture, firm, association, joint stock company, trust, corporation, or developer/subdivider that installs Utility Facilities and then conveys ownership of such facilities to the City or other Public Utility. 
Public utility means any person, firm, mutual and cooperative association, partnership, corporation, river authority, cooperative corporation, water or sewer supply corporation, or any general law or special act district that locates, installs, owns, operates, repairs, replaces, adjusts, relocates, maintains and/or removes utility facilities in order to provide utility service and which is granted a franchise by the City to provide such service within the municipal boundaries of the City. 
Public way means the surface of, and the space above and below, any public street, highway, freeway, bridge, land path, alley, court, boulevard, sidewalk, parkway, way, lane, public way, drive, circle, or other public right-of-way including, but not limited to, public utility easements, dedicated utility strips, or rights-of-way dedicated for compatible utility uses located within the municipal boundaries of the City. 
Utility facilities means water transmission mains and distribution lines, and related facilities; waste water collection lines and transmission mains, and related facilities; stormwater collection and transmission lines; conduits and related facilities; electric transmission and distribution lines, and related facilities; telephone lines and related facilities; gas distribution mains, lines and related facilities; cable television lines and related facilities; telegraph and telecommunications lines and related facilities; and any other utility system facilities. 
(Ord. of 4-13-1994, § 1)  
Sec. 44-242. - Permitted location of utility facilities. 
All utility facilities, whether installed by a public utility, the City and/or any person, shall be installed in the nonpaved portion of a public way. Current operating utility facilities not located in the nonpaved portion of a public way do not have to be moved unless the City requests the public utility and/or any person to move such utility facilities. The location of any utility facilities in a public way not currently existing, shall be subject to the City's approval. All future utility facilities that are installed for the first time or alternatively are being replaced and/or relocated shall be installed in the nonpaved portion of a public way. The City may, in its discretion, approve an alternative location within the public way. It shall be the obligation of the public utility, and/or any person to provide the necessary unpaved right-of-way within the public way prior to the installation, replacement and relocation of utility facilities. All such utility facilities installed or erected shall be located so as to cause a minimum of interference with the proper surface and subsurface use of the public way and with the rights and reasonable convenience of property owners who own property that adjoins any such public way. No such public utility shall have the right to locate, install, own, operate, repair, replace, adjust, relocate, maintain and/or remove utility facilities within the municipal boundaries of the City unless it has obtained a franchise from the City to locate, install, own, operate, repair, replace adjust, relocate, maintain and/or remove such utility facilities and obtained all other necessary licenses, permits and authorizations as may be required in order to carry on its respective utility service. 
(Ord. of 4-13-1994, § 2)  
Sec. 44-243. - Utility facilities under streets, avenues or alleys. 
All utility facilities approved by the City to pass, or cross under, a street, avenue or alley shall be installed at the proper depth and location before the street, avenue or alley is paved. If the street, avenue or alley is already paved, the utility facilities shall be installed only after boring under the street, avenue or alley, unless otherwise authorized by the City. When it is deemed necessary by the City that utility facilities pass, or cross under, any street, avenue or alley pavement, they shall be extended to a point at least three feet beyond the edge of the pavement to allow protection and access of same. 
(Ord. of 4-13-1994, § 3)  
Sec. 44-244. - Height of overhead utility facilities. 
Overhead utility facilities crossing an alley shall be a minimum of 15 feet in height. Overhead utility facilities crossing a street shall be a minimum of 25 feet in height. 
(Ord. of 4-13-1994, § 4)  
Sec. 44-245. - Easements required within subdivided platted area. 
Except where alleys, not less than 20 feet in width, are provided by a developer/owner, easements, not less than ten feet in width, shall be retained on every rear lot line when platting and subdividing real property within the municipal boundaries and extraterritorial jurisdiction of the City, so as to create at least a ten-foot, and in cases of abutting properties, a cumulative 20-foot permanent easement between the rear of lots. Where additionally necessary to accommodate utility facilities' placements, easements, not less than ten feet in width, on either or both sides of side lot lines shall be retained for utility facilities. Such permanent easements may be required across the interior parts of lots, other than as described above upon recommendation of the City Engineer. Where the proposed platted area adjoins another unplatted area, a full 20-foot alley or 20-foot permanent easement width may be required along the rear of lots adjoining the unplatted area. 
(Ord. of 4-13-1994, § 5)  
Sec. 44-246. - Restoration of public way. 
If during the course of the location, installation, operation, repair, replacement adjustment, maintenance, relocation and/or removal of utility facilities, there occurs a disturbance of any public way by a public utility, the City and/or any other person, such public utility, City and/or person shall, at its expense, replace and restore such public way to a condition reasonably comparable to or better than the condition of the public way existing immediately prior to such disturbance to the satisfaction of the City and for a period of one year from the date the public way is disturbed. No public way shall be encumbered for a longer period than shall be necessary to execute the work. 
(Ord. of 4-13-1994, § 6)  
Sec. 44-247. - Relocation of public utility's facilities at request of City. 
(a)  Upon its receipt of reasonable advance written notice, not to be less than 30 days, a public utility and/or any person shall, at its own nonreimbursable expense, and subject to the provisions of section 44-242, protect, support, temporarily disconnect, relocate in the public way, or remove from the public way, any property, including utility facilities, of the public utility and/or any person, when lawfully required by the City by reason of traffic conditions, the health, safety and welfare of its citizens, street widening, straightening or abandonment, freeway and street construction, change or establishment of the street grade, installation of other utility facilities, or any other types of structures or improvements by the City. The failure of the City to give proper notice shall not excuse the public utility and/or any person from protecting, supporting, temporarily disconnecting, relocating or removing any utility facilities of the public utility and/or any person's nonreimbursable expense.
